debateinfo.title: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN IN THE WORKPLACE AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Ms Macklin moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading the House expresses its concern about the nature of the bill and its contribution to the stripping back of Government support for Australian women and the community organisations that represent them, in particular:

(1) the weakening of industrial relations legislation and organisations that aim to improve women's employment prospects and workplace treatment, particularly through the Workplace Relations Act and reductions in the power of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission;

(2) the weakening of organisations that exist to provide women with suitable avenues of redress for discrimination, including the Affirmative Action Agency and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission;
(3) failure to respond to major reports, particularly the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Report, Pregnant and Productive ;

(4) failure to send appropriate representation to international forums discussing women's policy, particularly to the recent International Labour Organisation's conference on maternity leave provisions;
(5) the weakening of the role of government organisations that aim to improve the sensitivity of government policies to women, particularly the Office of the Status of Women;
(6) the de-funding of community groups which represent women, including the Girl Guides, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Older Women's Network and the Catholic Women's League;
(7) failure to consult with a wide range of women's organisations, particularly through the reduction in the numbers now attending the national round table consultations;
(8) cuts to child care, education and health-services which women depend upon to be able to work, to raise a family and to improve their living standards;
(9) the development of taxation policies which do not deliver an equal benefit to women and which redistribute more of the burden of taxation onto women through the Goods and Services Tax; and

(10) the de-funding of the social safety net by stealth which impacts significantly on women as women are more dependent upon social security and the Government's refusal to release a secret welfare discussion paper containing plans to cut payments to sole parents and people with disabilities."

talk.start.para: —I will continue with the points I was making last night. Last night I was addressing the question of gender pay equity in looking at the setting in which this Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 is to be considered. I had just referred the House to an excellent paper that has been generated in Western Australia called `The future is bleak: enterprise bargaining and gender wage equity'. I was saying that this paper, when looked at closely, gives us a good window on what will happen on the question of gender pay equity should the second wave industrial relations legislation of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business pass through this place.

speech.para: This analysis is a decomposition analysis. That is a statistical method whereby you look for a difference, you control for the variables that are known and you then get the truly unexplained difference. So you look at the gender gap in wages, control for the variables that are known and get the unexplained difference. Then you are able to look for the factors that might explain that difference. This decomposition analysis has been done in respect of pay rates for men and women in 1991 and 1996. As we know, Richard Court's legislation, which was the forerunner to the kind of legislation this minister is seeking to inflict on us nationally, was passed and became operative in the period between 1991 and 1996.

This analysis looks at the question of pay differentials between men and women and then goes through a relatively complex statistical process. I will not delay the House with too many details of that—not everybody has the same passion for statistics that some of us might. It controls for explainable factors: for example, human capital endowments—that is the difference predominantly in education levels and labour market experience between the male work force and the female work force—demographics, overtime, the sector of the labour force in which people are engaged, industry and occupation. So all of the things that might explain a gender wage differential are statistically acknowledged and taken out.

But, even when you go through all the factors that might explain why women continue to earn less than men, you are left with an increasing gender wage differential. That is, in the period between 1991 and 1996 in Western Australia, the gender gap—the amount which women earn less than men—has become worse. The conclusion of this study is as follows:
In this paper we—
that is, the academic authors—

take a `peek' at the future through the window of Western Australia. Western Australia has already implemented many of the reforms proposed in Reith's (1999) recent discussion paper and legislation amendment bill.
That, of course, is a reference to the second wave industrial relations legislation. It continues:

Developments at the state level therefore provide an excellent indication of what to expect in a more decentralised Federal environment. For women the future is bleak. The results in this paper show that since 1991 the gender wage gap in Western Australia has increased 5.5 percentage points, from 17.5 per cent at August 1991 to 23 per cent at August 1998. Analysis of Census data from 1991 and 1996 shows that changes arise entirely as a result of adverse wage structure effects and not because of changes in the productivity characteristics of males and females. Women in Western Australia have, in fact, improved their relative human capital endowments but the gains made here were not enough to offset the deterioration in their relative returns brought about by institutional transformations.

The clear conclusion of this study is, even if other labour market factors, and in particular the question of education levels, are getting better for women in the work force, we can expect the gender pay differential to increase if the institutional setting—that is, the degree of industrial relations regulation—is rolled back.

The experience in Western Australia is that women in Western Australia are going back in relative pay levels as opposed to their male counterparts. That is exactly the same conclusion that we will get to should this minister's industrial relations legislation pass this place. That is, once we have the second wave industrial relations legislation in place, once the institutional setting is changed, we can expect to see women, in relative terms, go backwards in their earnings compared with men. For a government that is seeking actively to impose that agenda on working women in Australia to present to this House something boldly titled Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 I suggest is bordering on the ironic.

If we are going to seriously talk about the question of equal opportunity in the workplace in this debate, clearly fundamental to that is the question of equal pay. But also fundamental is the question of accessing the workplace. As we all know, for many women whether or not they can access the workplace depends entirely on the availability of accessible, affordable, quality child care. When we look at the record of this government on the child-care question, once again we see policies in place which do anything but ensure that there is equal opportunity in the work place.

I recommend to every member of the House a recent excellent study by the Australian Services Union on child-care provision throughout Australia. I focused on the Victorian results, but there are results in that survey which detail what has happened in other states. This survey by the Australian Services Union shows just how detrimental this government's approach to child care has been, particularly in lower income areas such as Melbourne's west where my seat is located.

The survey identified that in Victoria 70 community child-care centres have closed in the last two years, with further centres identified for closure in December this year. Disturbingly, the survey has identified that the highest level of closure has occurred in Melbourne's west, an area of high disadvantage. Specifically, the survey has found that in the local government district of Hobson's Bay, which is one of the municipalities located within my electorate, the cost of long day care has increased by 10 per cent. This increase has been in circumstances where 70 per cent of the families accessing local government long day care earn less than $35,000 per annum. So there has been an increase in child-care costs targeted at or specifically impacting on those who have the least capacity to pay for it.

Indeed, of the families who seek access to long day care services, 55 per cent are single parent families and 35 per cent are from non-English speaking backgrounds. It seems to me incredible that, when this government is clearly winding up for an assault on single parent families and will be putting to single parents that they ought to move back into the work force as soon as possible—as soon as they are able to leave their children—and when they are going to rejig the benefits structure to force people back into the work force, it could be knocking out from under them one of the fundamental supports to allow them to go back into the work force, which is access to affordable child care.

Let there be no mistake: the Australian Services Union survey shows in stark detail that cost is a key factor affecting people's ability to access care, sufficient hours of care or quality care. Of the child-care centres surveyed, 99.3 per cent said children had been withdrawn from their child-care centre because of cost; 59.3 per cent reported that some families had had to give up work to care for their children at home because the rising cost of child care made the work equation no longer economical; 68.7 per cent reported families had reduced working hours because of increasing child-care costs; and 71.8 per cent said families had decreased booked hours because of costs.

That is the child-care setting we are dealing with. What can that boldly titled piece of legislation, Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill, possibly be about if it is not being dealt with in a setting where women seeking to access the workplace can get affordable, accessible and quality child care? As we see very clearly from the survey, in Victoria—and the equation holds true for the other states—that is not happening under the policies of this government.

Turning to the specific provisions of the bill, against a general record of failure for women in the area of equal opportunity in the workplace we find this bill contains another litany of failures. The bill waters down the requirement of employers to promote equal opportunity. Employers will now have to only contribute to the achievement of equal opportunity—quite a different thing. The minister has decided to lock unions out of the process, irrespective of their expertise in dealing with equal opportunity issues.

The reporting regime has been cut back so you can report less frequently. And, indeed, you can report confidentially, when always key to the equal opportunity programs in the workplace has been the threat of public exposure if you do not do the right thing. Now you will have the ability to sneak in confidential reports. There is no continuing requirement that a senior manager run the equal opportunity plans in the workplace. This bill is a record of another round of failures for equal opportunity for women in the workplace. This legislation is therefore flawed. It comes from a government with a bad and worsening record on equal pay, a bad and worsening record on child care and, if this bill is passed in its present form, a bad and worsening record on equal opportunity for women. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 is about anything other than developing a working environment that will ensure equal opportunity for women. How can we trust a government that actively legislates to support the most powerful businesses, the most powerful organisations and the most powerful people in this country at the expense of ordinary Australians and those Australians who are disadvantaged in any way? This is a government that actively pursues anything but equal opportunity for anyone other than their friends in high places.

speech.para: The government has a sorry record when it comes to empowering and providing services for women. It has failed in the past, and this legislation is doomed to fail again for women. The government has actively discouraged women from entering the workplace by cutting child care and making it accessible only to the wealthy in our community. This is a government with an elite approach to every area of government. It cannot be trusted to create an environment that will deliver equal opportunity to women in the workplace.

The elitist approach of this government is evident in every area. As the previous speaker noted, the cost of child care has now become something that only those people who earn a substantial amount of money can afford. We have viewed the education debate that has taken place in this House over the last week, and we have seen the direction in which this government would like to push education—once again making it the prerogative of only those people who have a lot of money, who are wealthy, who are their friends and who do not need extra assistance to be able to access that education.

One of my first experiences after being elected to federal parliament was being involved in a 60 Minutes program that looked at women in politics. That was a very interesting experience because, whilst I think the program itself should be condemned, it showed the very strong difference between the attitudes of members on this side of the House to women and the attitudes of members of the other side of the House to women. We on this side appreciate that women need a little extra assistance to be able to succeed. On the other side, women strongly argued that if a woman were good enough that woman would succeed.

How can members of a government that puts forward that sort of an ideology—that is committed to the philosophy that a person will succeed if they are strong enough—be prepared to make a commitment to equal opportunity for women in the workplace? Members on the other side of the House are locked into a cult of the individual and a philosophy of the survival of the fittest. We definitely cannot trust a government that puts forward legislation saying, `We're about equal opportunity for women in the workplace, but we're going to erode the current legislation to make sure that women don't actually get that equal opportunity.'

It was a Labor government—the Hawke Labor government—that was responsible for the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunities for Women) Act 1986. The Labor government recognised that women were at a disadvantage and that action was needed to create an environment that would lead to equality for women in the workplace. That is the history of this legislation and that was why it was introduced. It is also interesting to note that it was under Labor that women actually ended up getting equal pay. I remember when I first started work. I did the same job as a male who may not have performed at the same level as I did in my HSC. That same person received a higher salary than I did, not because they did a different job but simply because they were male and I was female.

Over the years, the Labor Party has had this commitment to creating an environment where women can achieve equal opportunity. The Liberal philosophy really works against this because it is dictated by the belief that, if you are good enough, you will achieve—if you are good enough, you will be able to have that equal opportunity. The members on the other side of this parliament, the government of this country, do not recognise that anybody needs extra assistance, be it women, somebody who is looking for a job or a pensioner. That really goes against their ideology.

The aim of this legislation is to make the equal employment opportunity for women act more effective and efficient for business and for women. I can see a conflict there. How can this legislation make the act more effective and efficient both for business and for women? I see that there can often be a conflict in achieving these two goals. The aim of business is to decrease costs and increase profit. I also see that there can be a conflict for the nation as a whole because, if women are not in a position where they achieve equal opportunity, a significant proportion of our population will be underutilised. For women to obtain equality in the workplace, there may be a cost involved with training, maternity leave and supplying child care. For a government to make a commitment to ensure that women do get this equality, it may require business to make a commitment that may increase their costs.

How can both business and women achieve that effectiveness and efficiency? I thought this bill was about creating equal opportunity, not about effectiveness and efficiency. Equality for this government is not about creating an environment that is conducive to equal opportunity. What it means to this government is competing on an equal footing with men. Equality with men means that you are allowed to go in there and compete with men. It does not take into account the old-school syndrome and the meeting at the club syndrome, and it does not take into account all those extra things that women need to reach that point where they can actually compete equally with men in the workplace.

This legislation also states the goal of creating flexibility. We all know that for this government flexibility means looking after their friends. And who are their friends? Their friends are business, the elite and those people in powerful positions in our community—not women and not workers. We have only to look at the recent legislation that passed through this House—the `More Jobs, Better Pay' legislation.
Dr Lawrence interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, a most inappropriate title. Under this legislation women are particularly disadvantaged, because what group in the work force is more involved in the lower paid jobs, the casual jobs, the part-time jobs and the jobs where there are fewer unions? It is women. That is a demonstration of how this government attacks the least powerful people in the community, how it seeks to erode the conditions of workers and lower the pay of workers. The people who will be bearing the brunt of that are women. You just have to look at the percentage of women who are in permanent employment. It is 68 per cent for women as opposed to 77.4 per cent for men. Thirty-two per cent of women are working in casual positions as opposed to 22 per cent of men. You can really see the imbalance that exists there in the workplace. No action that this government can take will bring about any change that will benefit women in the work force because, let us face it, it is philosophically opposed to it.

speech.para: This legislation is also about complementing a workplace relations framework based on cooperation. What does cooperation mean to the government of Australia? Cooperation means the workers agreeing to everything that the employers want. The government is anti-union. It has locked the unions out of the process of industrial relations and every decision it takes is to move away from protecting workers in this country.

Similarly, this legislation does that to women. It is an attack on women. It is about creating an imbalance of power by putting more power in the hands of employers and businesses, which really opposes the whole philosophy behind equal opportunity. It is also about reducing the employer's obligation to women. The changes made by this government are generally—I think you would almost say exclusively—about looking after employers and big business. They are not in any way about women, people who are unemployed or anyone who suffers any disadvantage within the work force or within our society, and that is very sad.

Since the introduction of the original legislation in 1986—which, I might add, a number of members on the other side of this House opposed when they were in opposition—there has been an increase in the number of women in SES positions, on boards, in management positions and in CEO positions. But since this government has come to power this move has stagnated and, in many cases, declined. There are still no female CEOs in Australia among the top 25 older or newer CEOs. That would be a logical progression. You would assume that if this government had a commitment to equal opportunity then this would change.

As recently as January this year, an article in the Financial Review stated that the glass ceiling was still firmly in place, `with only 12 per cent of firms reporting that half of their senior managers were women'. The government has done nothing to encourage businesses to make that commitment to women, and this legislation will be a disincentive.

Women earn 61c compared to every dollar men earn. Once again, this is not acceptable. It is anything but acceptable. It is also interesting to look at the Australian financial industry. This government is always talking about its commitment in the areas of finance and business. The Australian financial industry executive commitment to promoting women to senior executive ranks has declined remarkably, because the government has done nothing to encourage businesses to move down that path.

It is interesting to compare the academic record of young girls in the HSC with that of boys. Sixty-five per cent of the top 99 students in 1999 were girls. Fifty-four per cent of the total enrolment were girls. But the figures that I have just quoted do not transfer in any way to the most highly paid positions and the positions of power in our community. They are not reflected in the number of women on boards or in SES positions, they are not reflected in the number of CEOs, and they are certainly not reflected in the ministerial positions on the other side of this House.

This amended legislation will not facilitate an increase in the number of women in these positions. It will go no way towards encouraging any firm in this country to lift their game. It does nothing to create equal opportunity for women. The government's record is appalling in the area of equal opportunity for women and workers in Australia. The government has been very silent on the recently released Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report, Pregnant and productive. The most notable feature of the government's response to the report is its inaction. It has done nothing. If its action in relation to equal opportunity reflects anything, I think we can continue to expect inaction.

The report highlights the appalling treatment of women, treatment that has not changed since I was a young woman in the work force. I remember when I applied for a job not long after I had been married the first questions I was asked were, `Will you get pregnant? Are you going to have a child?' Some nine months later I actually became pregnant and very silently left that job because there was that pressure on women. I think that pressure is still there. Unless the government picks up all of the recommendations of that report, that pressure will still be there and will still disadvantage women. It will make sure that pregnancy disadvantages a woman, her family and her career.

The government does not understand what equality of opportunity means. It does not understand what it means for workers and people with disabilities, and it certainly does not understand what it means for women. It has no commitment to equality of opportunity for women or any worker who is not part of its elitist clique. Any government that promotes the goal of creating efficiency and effectiveness in the workplace as conducive to creating an environment that will lead to equality in the workplace for women does not have the slightest understanding of the concept. It is a 1950s government that believes a woman's place is in the home. That is why it will not remove the artificial barriers that prevent women competing with men on an equal footing.

talk.start.para: —What we see in the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 is another example of the coalition government's retrograde steps in policies and programs affecting women. Whether borne out of malice or neglect, the effect is the same. We have seen significant cuts to child care, which have made child care more expensive, especially for the least well off in our community. We have also seen cuts to labour market programs of nearly $2 billion that again affect women trying to re-enter the work force. We have seen cuts to university funding and a higher HECS, and now there is the monster scheme we have heard about in recent days, which may be amended but which would have created—and probably still will in due course—insurmountable debts, and they would fall particularly heavily on women leaving the work force for some period of time to have children.

speech.para: We have also seen threats to universal health coverage, an additional cost to the family budget in this area. We are also about to see the introduction of the GST, which falls heavily on those who are on low incomes, represented by a preponderance of women. We have seen too a combination of income tax and social security changes which mean that women are hit with very high effective marginal tax rates when they attempt to return to work or to increase their hours of work. We have also seen movement around the country under conservative governments to individual workplace agreements, and that has been particularly deleterious to women. The second wave, which is threatened, will leave women even more exposed to the much greater bargaining power that employers have.

Part of this government's agenda also has been the threats to single mothers exercising their choice in balancing paid work and family responsibilities—threats to force them into the labour market prematurely. We have also seen an effective neutering of the Office of the Status of Women, if I can use that word in relation to the office. Funding has been halved and the office has been sidelined; its advice is simply not listened to—and we have seen a series of calculated insults to women and women's organisations. I think women are seen by this government as a noisy minority. It is a funny minority—52 per cent of the population.

We saw the significant delay in the appointment of a Sex Discrimination Commissioner. We have seen the delay, and then the cancellation, of invitations to key women's groups to roundtable discussions. There are people who are insiders and outsiders with this government. We have seen significant cuts to funding to those community organisations, and the funds have actually gone to groups who can afford to raise funds themselves, like the business and professional women, who have indicated they could quite happily raise the money themselves.

We have seen a failure to include a woman, at least one, in the delegation to the ILO conference considering the issue of pregnancy in work force participation. Perhaps not surprisingly, therefore, we saw them support the employers' right to pregnancy test a woman before taking her on as an employee. The fact that it was in breach of our own antidiscrimination laws appears to have escaped them. We have seen some recent publicity about the Prime Minister's confusion of women's netball with hockey and of hockey with cricket. He does not seem to make those mistakes when it comes to men's involvement in sport. All of this shows that the cuts to the Office of the Status of Women and the appointment of a compliant CEO have all had their effect.

This legislation further threatens the position of women in the work force by diluting the responsibility of firms to promote equal opportunity in the workplace, by removing the requirement for employers to consult with trade unions and employees on the development of affirmative actions plans—you would have thought that was central really—and by weakening the reporting provisions and any public consequences of failing to perform. It is all to go underground.

This legislation and these changes that we have seen to date ignore women's views about what the government should be doing. Surveys around the country tell us that women are much more likely to support government involvement in the economy and community development and that they are more likely to be alarmed at the roll-back of government that we have seen here, and in Victoria most recently, in services like education and health, in contracting out and in the sale of community assets.

Women are more likely than men to report that their personal economic situation is worse as a result of four years of a Howard government. In a recent poll on the quality of life undertaken by the Australia Institute, fewer women than men reported that life was getting better—indeed, only 19 per cent of them thought it was. Asked in the same survey what was important in improving the quality of their lives, women indicated that spending more time with family and friends, being under less pressure and being able to do more for the community were more important to them. Women have all experienced the effects of the Howard government policies on our work and family lives.

The most significant changes, of course, have resulted from the prescription to deregulate the labour market—we have seen this experiment carried out around the country now—to make the work force more `flexible', to contract out and to privatise the public sector, and all this in the face of the fact that Australia was already the most exposed to market forces of all the OECD countries. As early as 1987, Australia already had a very flexible labour force, with one of the shortest lengths of stay in jobs of any OECD country. Women are the most exposed to these pressures, which are accelerating under the current regime—and there are threats of more.

Michael Pusey, as part of his middle Australia project, interviewed 400 of what he called `middle Australians'—people in the work force, people at home, people with families. Of these, 63 per cent said that their incomes and job prospects were falling, half thought that the quality of life was declining generally, and 60 per cent thought that ordinary people—not the elites but the people out there slogging it out—were losers. As Pusey puts it, they were really asking the question: if the economy is up, why is the country down?

While the government have been intent on delivering what they call workplace flexibility to management, effectively to improve competitiveness and their profit bottom line, this has often been achieved by eroding many of the working time standards achieved over the last century of struggle within the union movement, and women have typically been at the blunt end of these changes. As the polling I outlined earlier suggests, they are aware of this decline but not always of the reasons for it.

We need to understand that both the structure and the number of working hours in Australia have changed profoundly and in a way which disadvantages most workers but particularly women with family responsibili ties. These changes have seriously eroded the time available for recreation and for leisure pursuits that I think are essential to optimum physical and mental health. Many of the changes have also compromised health and safety in the workplace.

This so-called flexibility has often failed to deliver the promised balance between work and family life—it has given flexibility to the employer but not to the employee. In fact, it has increased unpredictability for workers, with workers having less control over the hours worked, the shifts and their periods of employment and unemployment. The feelings of helplessness which are engendered in this case are characteristic precursors of illness and depression, and there is a lot of research to show that that is what eventuates. Increased stress levels have been reported in a lot of recent studies and they are not compensated for, by and large, by any proportional increases in income.

There is a lot of evidence that women are increasingly having to choose between having a job and having a family: it should not be a choice that they have to make. As a result, the age when a woman has her first child is steadily increasing while her fertility rate is declining. The irony is that this trend is likely to accelerate—indeed, it is accelerating—under the regime of the very government which purports to cherish families and family values. As Australian demographer Professor McDonald points out:

Economic policies . . . such as cuts to government expenditure of family services and increased insecurity of employment, tend to depress fertility even further by making family life even less sustainable.

It is a warning this government should heed. Of course, this is exacerbated by discrimination, as reported in the HREOC investigation into pregnancy and work. Women are being discriminated against either because they are pregnant or because they might become pregnant, and the government contributed to that in its recent ILO decision. This clearly requires remedy by amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act as outlined by our shadow minister. I think it is worth having a look at how these legislative changes we are talking about today feed into the working time changes that women are experiencing in this country.

Our current labour market is characterised simultaneously by high unemployment, especially for older workers, and by overwork for others. We also see increasing numbers of full-time workers working longer and longer hours. A recent survey by the Australian Centre for Industrial Relations Research found that a third of full-time workers surveyed worked over 49 hours a week. In general, over a third of the total labour force work excessively long hours. On the other hand, a third want more hours and they cannot get them. There has also been a steady increase in the proportion of employees required to take part in shift work, and that is not good for families.

A recent survey of the manufacturing and service industry employees commissioned by the ACTU showed that almost half of the nearly 3,000 respondents had undertaken unpaid overtime each week. Other surveys have reported proportions as high as 60 per cent working overtime for free. As a result, for all of those people, there is a reduced connection between hours worked and earning—they simply have to work overtime to keep their jobs. Generally speaking, and this is also true for women, unpredictable, irregular and insecure hours are increasing. One employee in four is now casual—that is up from 15 per cent in the mid-1980s. For women, of course, the rates are even higher, increasing from 28.4 per cent in 1995 to 32 per cent in 1998—a rapid escalation. For many, the hours that are worked are increasingly intense—typically, there are fewer workers to do the same job.

In 1995, over 50 per cent of workers reported an increase in the intensity of work over the previous 12 months; they are working harder. They reported that these changes were, for them, creating illhealth, fatigue and a poor quality of working life. This intensification, as the academics are inclined to call it, results from staff cuts and a failure to recruit at appropriate skill levels. In the survey referred to above, the most common perceptions of workers about change in the workplace were that there had been an increase in the amount of work: 65 per cent of them said that. Two-thirds said there was an increase in stress and the pace of work. They did indicate that there was an increase in total pay but that they were working more overtime to achieve it. Overall, a third reported a significant decrease in job satisfaction, a decline in job security and a decline in employee numbers in their workplaces.

Together with these observations about change, 56 per cent of employees surveyed said they were concerned—and this is very important for the wider community—that they were unable to provide the right amount of service or the quality of performance because of increases in the workload. They are working harder and producing a lower quality, in their own eyes. They also reported that, with increasing amounts of overtime, they had no time for sports, hobbies, community activities and family life. Women, as a group, are the most susceptible to these forces. All women take part in the paid work force at some time in their lives—whether before they have children, during or after—and they often have to juggle work and family responsibilities so they can support their families and provide for their own and their family's future economic security.

Given the recent push for reform of the workplace that we have seen around this country, and I use the word `reform' in inverted commas in many cases, it is timely to examine whether the momentum toward equality in women's wages and conditions that we saw in the 1980s and early 1990s has been maintained. Australia's pay gender gap was, until recently, one of the smallest in the world, second only to the Nordic countries and well ahead of the USA and Japan. Over recent years, changes to state and federal laws have removed many of the measures designed to advance wage equality and protect all workers' conditions. They were deliberately designed to do that. We have been told that individual workplace agreements would enable `greater flexibility' and help us to better balance work and family responsibilities—as I have outlined, that clearly is not the case—and all without making anyone worse off. What is the reality? Unfortunately, data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that women still earn less than men do. Indeed, despite the introduction of equal pay provisions 30 years ago, women earn 66 per cent of the male average.

Part of the reason for that gap, obviously, is the higher percentage of women who work part-time—44 per cent of females, up from 26 per cent in 1970, and 13 per cent of males. Even so, when you look at the average full-time female wage, it is $128 a week less than men's—a gap of 16 per cent. That position has deteriorated since this time last year and is getting worse as we speak. In the hospitality industry, there has been a 4 per cent increase in the gap between male and female full-time earnings—11 per cent when overtime is added. We are seeing a deterioration, not an improvement, in that gap. In my own state, which now has the least regulated wages system in the country—courtesy of the conservative government there—women are the worst paid group in the whole of Australia, worse than the female average. Women in Western Australia earn a whopping $300 less than their male colleagues.

At the same time, the figures show that 13,000 women left the labour force in January 1999. They simply gave up looking for work. As I found in a survey of my electorate, one of the reasons for this exit is that child-care costs have rocketed and financial assistance has been withdrawn. There is clear evidence that both men and women are working longer and less predictable hours without increased pay. I think it is fair to conclude that there are worrying signs that many of the gains made in the last 30 years since the first successful equal pay case are being eroded. Women are working longer and more fragmented hours, with reduced security of employment and less government support. Their position relative to male workers has deteriorated; the evidence shows that it has. It is time to press governments to pay a lot more attention to equality in the workplace and a fair go for working women. We have heard all the rhetoric but we have not seen any results. Gregory suggests that as Australian incomes become more unequal—and they are—and cash and non-cash benefits are being withdrawn to exacer bate that, the male-female gap will widen, with women on lower incomes likely to come out the worst of all.

I want to briefly look at some of the effects of these changes and the intensification of work, not just on the working and family lives of women but on workers generally. Research that I am well aware of suggests that both overwork and unemployment are likely to have very deleterious effects on health. This is not just a matter for the individual; it is a matter for the community. As well as the social and economic effects, sustained unemployment, as we are well aware, has been linked to increases in stress and anxiety and to various health risk factors like smoking, obesity, poor diet and lack of social support. Similarly—and I hope the ministers responsible understand this—the experience of losing a job through so-called outsourcing and downsizing can produce devastating health consequences for both the employees and their partners, and their families are affected as well.

There is a lot of evidence as well that fear of unemployment—something that this government uses as a weapon and that is a common feature of contemporary labour markets—is also related to poor health. Of concern to me is the observation that those with the greatest anxiety about unemployment are the ones most likely to avoid visiting doctors and taking care of themselves for fear of missing out on work and therefore losing their jobs. This fear of unemployment is fed by the current economic imperatives of downsizing and contracting out. We are seeing it in one of our major banks at the moment. Media reports of business closures and worker lay-offs, and persistent unemployment and evidence of insecure employment all play a role in this.

There is no doubt that there are detrimental effects from unregulated increases in hours worked and shift work. People are not pieces on a chessboard; they react to these changes. A lot of these changes in working conditions include declining occupational health and safety because people are working excessive hours. We see it in the mining industry in Western Australia with bizarre shifts. This results in fatigue, stress, ill health and a sense of isolation. We see a decrease in and degradation of common leisure time; families cannot actually find time to get together. There is less time with others and less capacity for group activities. If you want to see why the community is declining, it has a lot to do with our patterns of work.

The reduction in the value of wages—as hours increase without a proportionate increase in wages—means that people have a distinct sense of unfairness about the arrangements. There is a reduction in the premiums paid for unsocial and irregular hours, and this generally underestimates the real costs associated with shiftwork and irregular work. We have seen an increasing encroachment of work into family, community and social life with things like mobile phones and computer link-ups. Of course there is then a corresponding deterioration of the quality of life and civil society. These things are all linked; we cannot ignore those links. We have seen a loss of control by workers as managers assume greater control over the hours of work and shifts and pit workers one against the other.

I hope it is clear from what I say that I think it is time for a change. We should not be accelerating these work force changes; we should be moving in the other direction. These trends in our economy and our workplaces are not inevitable. They are about ideology, and they can be modified by sound public policy. They have been in the past and they are being modified in other places. It is also important to recognise that measures which improve the economic status of the least well off, particularly amongst women, which increase employment, reduce inequality and civilise the workplace are likely to produce significant improvements in our society as a whole, and particularly for women and their families.

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable members who have spoken in the debate on the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 . This bill had its genesis in an independent review of the effectiveness and efficiency of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986. The regulatory review was part of a review of Commonwealth legislation undertaken in order to meet the 1995 competition principles agreement which was put in place by the previous Labor administration. After a process of broad-ranging consultations, the committee developed a comprehensive report on its findings titled Unfinished business: equity for women in Australian workplaces . This bill gives effect to the majority of recommendations made in the report that required legislative amendment.

speech.para: The opposition has criticised the bill and attacked the government's commitment to ensure that women's rights to equal opportunity in the workplace are protected. The opposition refuses to recognise that legislation that is more business friendly and flexible will actually improve equal opportunity for women, because it will be well understood and easier to put in practice at the workplace level.

The opposition have proposed delaying the progress of the bill. How serious is the opposition's commitment to equal opportunity when they propose to deliberately delay sensible progress for women and workplaces in achieving equal opportunity? The opposition have clearly signalled that they are not very interested in protecting women at work. Their proposed knee-jerk reaction to implementing the HREOC Pregnant and productive report by delaying the progress of this bill is demeaning to the very cause they purport to support. The Pregnant and productive report contains 46 recommendations and, in my view, they deserve careful consideration. The government will, of course, sensibly and appropriately respond to that report.

On the other hand, the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill has been the subject of extensive consultations—including with the advisory board, which has a diverse membership—and is a well thought out, balanced and responsive piece of legislation. It is ready for passage in the parliament. There seems no sensible reason why this particular legislation should be delayed.

Unlike the opposition's rhetoric, this bill will secure real and enduring protection and promotion of women's rights in the workplace. The opposition has suggested that the bill will water down the act and reduce the powers of the agency. How can the opposition seriously suggest this, when the sanctions for employers who breach the act will remain the same and include the capacity to name those employers in parliament; when the target audience of the act will remain the same, in that all employers covered by the existing act would be covered by the act after the making of the proposed changes; and when those employers who meet the criteria for having their reporting requirements waived will continue to be covered by the act—and waiving is not to be open-ended but will only be able to be granted for a specified period? The list of employment matters, as the opposition acknowledges, has actually been extended to take in termination of employment, work organisation and arrangements for dealing with sex based harassment.

The rating system is not being removed from the legislation. It was never in the legislation to begin with. It was only ever an administrative measure. In addition, the independent review committee reported perceptions that the rating system could be `arbitrary in its application, with no transparent relationship to the requirements of the act'. The disuse of the rating system does not, as the opposition argues, mean that incentives for achievement in this area will be reduced. The agency will continue to publish a list of high achieving employers and to publicly recognise leading practice.

The opposition has a short-sighted focus on affirmative action representatives. The opposition appears to confuse the seniority of the officer responsible for equal opportunity with the commitment of a chief executive officer to equal opportunity. The government believes that its amendments, which will enable organisations to integrate equal opportunity with other organisational strategic planning priorities, are a much more effective way of gaining chief executive officer commitment and involvement. The opposition has failed to substantiate this aspect of its claim. We are quite happy to have an open debate about it. But, when you make claims which are simply not right and which are easily refuted, it is only fair for us to assume that you are simply opposing for the sake of opposition.

Likewise, how can the opposition seriously suggest that the bill is watering down the act? It is clearly not; and the claims that you have made are clearly refutable by reference to the proposal. Employers are still required to develop workplace programs. The opposition has presented these changes as if they allow free rein to employers to walk away from equal opportunity for women. The government does not want this, nor do most businesses—

talk.start.para: —You are watering it down.
—The interjecting continues, but it is clearly not right and, when you put the facts to the shadow minister she just says,` Oh, that's not right.' I am quite happy, Jenny, to debate it with you—
—No, no. Debate it through me, please.

—I am happy to debate it with you, Mr Acting Speaker; but, quite frankly, you would be prepared to debate it on what we are proposing and not on a figment of the imagination of the shadow minister. All productive businesses recognise that the relationship with their employees is fundamental. What employers require is clear objectives but flexibility in ensuring how those objectives are met in the employer's workplace—and that is what this bill provides. The clear objective will be set out in section 6 of the amended act:

speech.para: Relevant employers will be required to develop and implement a workplace program that is designed to ensure that appropriate action is taken to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and measures are taken to contribute to achieving equal opportunity for women in relation to employment matters.

Further direction is given in section 8 of the amended act and I again ask the shadow minister to read the proposal so that she might understand it. In preparing a workplace program, relevant employers are required to prepare factual information about the employer's work force, analyse the issues that need to be addressed to achieve equal opportunity, take actions in relation to the priority issues and evaluate the effectiveness of actions. Flexibility arises because it is the employer who analyses issues and identifies priorities about what needs to be fixed or improved at the particular workplace. Even the opposition should recognise that these issues can only be effectively identified and implemented at the workplace level.

How can it be said that the act is being weakened? The bill will not remove requirements on business to take action to support equal opportunity but it will remove the overly prescriptive approach used in the earlier act and replace it with requirements that will encourage attention to the real issues that are identified at the workplace level. This government is not interested in requiring glossy but ineffective policies. We want to ensure an outcome focused process where genuine issues are addressed and equal opportunity for women becomes a workplace reality.

The opposition has chosen to overlook the benefits of our proposed reforms. One benefit for business will be that the programs which are in place and which are ongoing will only have to be reported on biennially. This will reduce the paperwork for business without diminishing the effectiveness of the programs. By only having to report every other year, employers will be able to put more effort into actually implementing the programs at the workplace level. Surely this is an objective even the opposition would accept. However, the opposition has conveniently forgotten that a move to biennial reporting was a key recommendation of the independent review committee's report.

While the changes to reporting requirements are less onerous in terms of paperwork, they are no less onerous with respect to the need for organisations to demonstrate actions taken in respect of equal opportunity for women. In addition, the bill provides a safeguard for cases where an employer's report or workplace program appears to be flawed. The agency is entitled to request information from an employer about any aspect of a workplace program or a report or the preparation of a report.

Much has been said about the revised provision for waiving employer obligations to report under the act. The provision allows waiver for a specified period if the agency is satisfied that the employer has taken all reasonably practicable measures to address the issues relating to equal opportunity for women in the employer's workplace. This is a balanced legal test using the objective standard of a reasonable employer but recognising that what is practicable for that employer may depend on the constraints and limits arising at a particular workplace. In deciding whether to grant a waiver, the agency can be expected to consider the workplace program that has been developed and to consider the factual issues relevant to each particular organisation.

The opposition claims that the powers of the agency are being weakened. These claims are absolutely groundless. Far from reducing the powers of the agency, the bill preserves and strengthens its powers. The director's discretion in relation to evaluating reports for naming and for waiver is retained. Similarly, the discretion to identify best practice companies in the agency's annual report is retained. How is the director's power being reduced? In fact, the bill will broaden the agency's capacity to require information from employers, from after an employer has failed to comply with the act to any stage of the process.

In addition, the introduction of biennial reporting will increase the agency's discretion to redirect its resources away from processing forms and towards activities that educate and assist employers with the implementation of equal opportunity for women in the workplace. This is what the agency does best, as the opposition has acknowledged, and where change—both cultural and procedural—can be best brought about. I think that is a sensible approach. It would be in everybody's interests if the opposition took a more constructive attitude to the issues.

In recognition of this enhanced role, the government has provided the agency with an additional $700,000 over three years. This funding is supplementary to the agency's existing funding arrangements. Of the $700,000, $310,300 is being provided to implement measures directly related to changes to the legislation, such as the marketing and promotion of changes to the act, the design and dissemination of guidelines to assist employers to comply with the revised requirements of the act and the development of a new optional report form. The remaining $390,000 will fund activities relating to the establishment and support of the new advisory board and to assist the agency in refocusing its activities in the area of education and client service. So how is the agency being weakened? On any reasonable basis, we have maintained the strength of the agency and continued the constructive approach which characterises much of its work.

The new Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Act 1999 will be capable of delivering substantial gains to women and desirable outcomes for business in an efficient and effective way. The act, of course, does not act alone. Antidiscrimination law at the federal, state and territory level continues to make discrimination in employment unlawful and the Workplace Relations Act 1996 also has a role to play in helping to eliminate discrimination. This bill will assist business in identifying and addressing systemic issues within their businesses that may be working against equal opportunity for women. It will also assist in meeting the government's commitment to cut paperwork for business. The bill is designed to ensure that employers will develop workplace programs that deliver real outcomes in terms of equal opportunity for women. I therefore commend the bill to the House.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Ms Macklin's amendment) stand part of the question.
