The circumstances in which we find ourselves in the consideration in detail stage ought to be understood as the Treasurer scurries from this chamber after having just congratulated his deputy minister, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, on the sham and the shonk they have perpetrated on this parliament this morning. We have 454 amendments to their GST bill, to the dog's breakfast of a tax, and they have allowed less than 130 minutes to debate them—that is, 20 seconds an amendment. What a disgraceful performance from a government that says it wants greater accountability.

There was no mention to the opposition of their intention to gag this debate. There was no indication to me leading this debate on our side that that was their intention. In fact, my office got an indication that this was the intention only whilst I was on my feet during my speech in the second reading debate. This is unheard of in this place, and it goes to show the extent to which this government will go to hide the details of this unfair tax.

One of the amendments that I have just moved seeks again to get this House to consider a requirement that if we are going to get the GST it should not be hidden. At the moment the government has said that it wants to get rid of hidden taxes and that that is what the GST will replace. The problem is that the way its legislation has been introduced the amount of the GST will be hidden. We have moved an amendment in this place that all receipts should show the amount of GST that a person pays whenever they make a purchase. We know that every time people go into a shop, into a supermarket, Peter Costello's and John Howard's hands will be there in their pockets taking 10 per cent of almost everything purchased, but they do not want to put that on the receipt.

The amendments that they are putting here today create an environment in which small businesses can have a proportionality determined for the purposes of what they pay the tax office—not in terms of what individuals know they are paying GST on but in terms of what the small business pays. `We have not got detail of the proportionality, but certainly there is no requirement in this for consumers to know what they are paying.' They have been dudded. Just as small business has been dudded by this tax, consumers in particular have been dudded. So the amendments that we have moved seek to put before this House again a requirement that if we have this tax its details should be disclosed on all receipts.

We will see how members sitting opposite who hold marginal seats—and I see the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, Mr McGauran, sitting opposite, who after the Victorian election is getting very close to a marginal seat—
Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Quite safe in Gippsland, is it? Ask him. Who represents Gippsland now in the parliament? It is an independent; it is not the government, this invincible government of Jeff Kennett. It was a massive vote against that government. Mr McGauran is the minister from Gippsland. He is a minister who has been complicit in imposing a 10 per cent tax on just about everything you buy, but he wants to hide it. Well, we will be campaigning down in his seat outside supermarkets and outside shops, saying: what is Peter McGauran hiding from you? Having intro duced this brave new vision of a tax, why does he want to hide it?

speech.para: And we will not be stopping with you, brother. We will be doing it with every marginal seat in this parliament, because whilst you think that this issue has died it has not. The consequences of this GST still have to be felt. They will be felt when people have to pay this insidious, unfair tax from 1 July next year, when businesses between now and then have to expend fortunes without knowing what compensation they will get, if any, from the government to implement compliance procedures. They have already had to go through such an exercise with the Y2K, and they have copped it again with the GST. We will be requiring every member in this House to stick up their hand as to whether they want to hide it, and we will campaign against them on that basis. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We are not going to cop the rantings and ravings of the member for Hotham on this issue. Why don't you apologise to the people of Australia for not disclosing wholesale sales tax? Why don't you apologise to the people of Australia for all the wholesale sales tax that the Labor Party put in place over a number of years at six different rates—zero per cent, 12 per cent, 22 per cent, 32 per cent, 41 per cent, 45 per cent? Why didn't the Labor Party ever have that disclosed by business? I will tell you why: because the Labor Party knows, as we know, that the additional cost to business of displaying two prices is intolerable. So the hypocrisy of the member for Hotham, the hypocrisy of the Labor Party, have yet again come to the fore as Labor members come into this House and talk about transparency.

speech.para: Where was the transparency on wholesale sales tax? Where was it? All those who believe that wholesale sales tax was transparent put up your hand—not one hand. What a surprise! There are six different rates of wholesale sales tax going up to 45 per cent and the Labor Party, for 13 years in government, never once tried to have a proper display of prices in relation to wholesale sales tax.

talk.start.para: —Why would you? It is wholesale, not retail.

—The member for Chifley interrupts and says, `Why would you?' Well, you are sitting next to the member for Hotham—ask him. Whisper in his ear—instead of blowing in it, whisper in it. Ask him why he did not disclose it for 13 years. Was it coming in the 14th year or the 15th year?

speech.para: Already the humour has started to filter into the Labor Party about Victoria. Already they are crowing about their magnificent victory in Victoria. Well, we will wait and see how Steve Bracks copes with a hung parliament, how Steve Bracks copes with a hostile upper house. We will wait and see when the bad old days of Labor mismanagement of the economy start coming home to the people of Victoria. And here is another example of the hypocrisy of the Labor Party in opposition. In opposition they say one thing and in government they do another.

Let's talk about transparency again. Let's go back to that favourite theme of the Labor Party—transparency. Let's get them to explain why they did not tell the people of Australia about the increase in wholesale sales tax on products from 10 per cent to 12 per cent, from 20 per cent to 22 per cent. They come in here again and talk about compensation for tax increases. The Labor Party are masters of compensation; I do not recall any compensation package put in place by the Labor government when they increased wholesale sales taxes from 10 per cent to 12 per cent, from 20 per cent to 22 per cent, from 30 per cent to 32 per cent. Where was the compensation for everyday Australians in that? There was none—none at all.

So in yet another great example of hypocrisy in comes the member for Hotham ranting and raving in his usual fashion, playing up to the backbench, playing up to the numbers—there are a few opinion leaders there in the backbench. We can see them. The member for Lowe is new in the game but a bit of an opinion leader in caucus, I hear. The member for Hotham comes in here, playing up to the backbench and the new rising star of the Labor Party over here, the member for Hunter. I even offered to count his numbers for him in his leadership ambitions because he has the talent that the member for Hotham missed out on at birth.
The bottom line is that business does not want further complication. Business wants a very simple formula. The simple formula is this: of every price displayed one-eleventh is tax.

talk.start.para: —Oh, yeah.

—You cannot even count in your caucus. How could you work out a price in a supermarket? You would not have a chance. What we are saying is that we want simplification for business. We want to have an easy system that consumers understand: they pay one price, they have one price displayed. They know they are paying a tax because they are damned happy they are not paying the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax.

—The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation said that business does not want any more complications. This bundle of papers is the so-called streamlined new tax for the new century—here it is. The member for Lowe is in mortal danger if I happen to drop this because we have done an official weigh-in and this legislation, this streamlined new tax for the new century, weighs 4.4 kilograms. Up until this legislation came in, it weighed 4.2 kilograms. But if you add in the explanatory memorandum and the legislation itself, we are now up to 4.4 kilograms. And they complain about the 1930s ramshackle Botswana style wholesale sales tax. I have had an opportunity to read the Botswana sales tax and I can tell you that it is a lot simpler than this. This is it—the streamlined new tax for the new century and the minister says, `Oh, business doesn't want more complications.' They are going to get a headache. They are going to have to take Panadol just to read this legislation, to comprehend it.

speech.para: Just this morning I was talking to a chemist. In this legislation there are new rules for chemists: pharmaceuticals are GST free if they are pain relief products available in smaller packet sizes with a single active ingredient. Panadol does have a single active ingredient but Panadeine does not. So if you have a really big headache, if you are a business person reading this legislation and you have a really big headache, and you need some Panadeine and not some Panadol, you will pay GST. But if it is only a small headache and you need only Panadol, you will not pay GST. How ridiculous! This government is out of control.

The total number of amendments that the government is making to the streamlined new tax for the new century is 756. It has already made 302 amendments and in the legislation that we have been debating there are 454 amendments. That is right—454 amendments. This legislation is creating more and more anomalies, not solving them. I will point to some of the ridiculous provisions in this legislation: `Beverages must be for human consumption.' Are we getting into tax avoidance if you buy some milk, take it home and give it to the cat? Are we going to have the ACCC and the price monitors coming to our home saying, `That beverage was not for human consumption; you have just breached the law'? This is the nightmare on main street.

I have already talked about the Panadeine and Panadol fiasco. I will talk now about the payment of taxes, fees and charges. This is a very interesting amendment because they have added in the words: `any tax, fee or charge will be consideration for a taxable supply'. What that means is that any state government charge or any tax or fee is going to be subject itself to GST unless the government announces that it is not.

In my home state of Queensland, here are some of the fees: motor vehicle registration fee, fire levy fee, transport and traffic fees, other fees and levies, including land title fees, court fees, workplace registration fees and registration of business names fees. All of those will be subject to the GST. They say it is not a tax on a tax, but it is a tax on a tax unless the Treasurer deems that it is not a tax on a tax.

What happens to those fees, charges and taxes that apply now but go through past 1 July next year? State governments should be applying GST to those because, as it stands, none of those fees and charges is exempt, nor are local council fees and charges—for exam ple, fees to hire swimming pools, community halls or sporting fields. When people want to hire a sporting field, they will pay a GST on it. The government says this is a fair tax. It is a ridiculous tax and it should be thrown out completely.

What about the application for a building approval? If someone wants to put an extension on their home, they have to apply to a local council for a building approval and that will be subject to the GST because the Treasurer has not ruled it out. What a ridiculous piece of legislation this is. It defies belief that this government could come in here and say, `We have a streamlined new tax for a new century,' that weighs 4.4 kilos, involves a total of 756 amendments and measures, by the way, 16 centimetres high. So there you are: a streamlined new tax for a new century! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have a few questions about transparency that I would dearly like the minister to answer. `Taxes will be subject to the GST unless the Treasurer declares them exempt'—that is in the original act. That raises the related issue of double taxation and the GST treatment of some state levies and charges. We have had a bit of confirmation in this bill that all of those state taxes and charges may be subject to the GST.

speech.para: While the government has from time to time indicated its policy on the GST treatment of taxes, to date the Treasurer has made no declarations that any state taxes are exempt. Until lawful declarations are made in relation to some taxes, it will be difficult to say with any certainty that they are exempt. The Treasurer did say in parliament on 25 August this year:
. . . those services which are rendered for a fee are taxable. A fire service which is rendered for a fee can be taxable. I would have thought it was obvious.

Nowhere in this legislation is the test that a service is rendered for a fee specified. Normal practice is to classify as a government charge any payment which covers a reasonable assessment of the cost of providing a service. If the payment substantially exceeds the cost of providing the service, then it is treated as a tax. Essentially, that is why state liquor, tobacco and petrol franchise fees were struck down by the High Court. They were not a fee for a service; they were an excise, a tax.

With the mechanism that taxes which are exempt from the GST have to be declared by the Treasurer, that test may be somewhat arbitrary. But it is not just a case of the Treasurer being reluctant to declare taxes exempt. With the states receiving the GST revenue, they will have an incentive—at least the Liberal states will—to convert what are currently state taxes into fees for services. That way they can boost their own revenue.

Nowhere is there a more spectacular example of this process than South Australia's new emergency services levy. There was a fire services levy attached to insurance premiums which was collected by the state government and used to defray the cost of the state's fire services. Emergency services were also funded from consolidated revenue, from state taxes. Now the emergency services levy is being raised on the value of real estate and on motor vehicles, including cars, trucks, caravans and boats. On Mr Costello's definition of 25 August 1999, this will be treated as a fee for service and be taxable. The emergency services levy will be subject to GST. If these services had continued to be paid for from taxes which are declared exempt by the Commonwealth Treasurer, they would not be subject to the GST. In effect, the states will be getting an extra rake off of 10 per cent through the GST by converting services that are presently paid for using GST-exempt taxes into user-pays services with a fee or a charge which is subject to the GST.

The South Australian emergency services levy contains an anomaly with respect to its GST treatment. The levy covers a range of emergency services, including the Metropolitan Fire Service, Country Fire Service, State Emergency Service, parts of the surf lifesaving and coastguard operations, police rescue, parts of the state government communications network and the ambulance service. The ambulance service is a health service and therefore exempt. If the GST is levied on the full amount of the state government's emergency services levy, the GST will be being applied to a health service. I ask the minister whether he can come to the box and give me an answer on whether that will be the case. If it is not going to be the case, what administrative arrangements will the government institute to stop it being the case?

talk.start.para: —The introduction of the GST continues to concern most Australians. The Howard government and the Democrats continue to tell the Australian people that the GST will reduce their tax burden. Moreover, Australian voters are now beginning to understand what a regressive tax it is. They are beginning to understand that the regressive taxes they have to pay before they have earned a wage will make life very difficult for them. The story that a regressive tax will mean people paying lower tax over time will go down in Australia's history as one of the great confidence tricks of all time. Philosophers like Adam Smith proved a long time ago that regressive taxes will cause much pain and suffering to many people, especially to those who have only their labour to sell as well as to welfare pensioners and poor people. In fact, Smith said:

speech.para: The middling and superior ranks of people, if they understand their own interest, ought always to oppose all taxes upon the necessaries of life, as well as all direct taxes upon the wages of labour. The final payment of both the one and the other falls altogether upon themselves, and always with considerable overcharge.

The Howard government has not learnt from history. However, the Treasurer may have learnt from history. In this regard, I quote from an article by Tracey Aubin entitled `The nervous lieutenant: Could his own tax package kill Peter Costello's chance to follow the leader?' on page 49 of the first issue of The Eye Doesn't Lie dated 6 to 20 October 1999. By the way, Ms Aubin is also the author of the book titled Peter Costello Biography .

In her report, Ms Aubin says that the member for Higgins, Peter Costello, is afraid that the goods and services tax, the centrepiece of his extensive tax reform agenda, will cost him his chance to become Prime Minister. In recent weeks he has told friends and colleagues that he could become a scapegoat for the GST to be implemented on 1 July next year and he worries that a voter backlash will affect the coalition's re-election chances and his personal standing.

According to one confidant, a friend since university days, he sees a certain irony in the situation. `He said taxation reform was so necessary for the good of Australia, but he is worried he might now be forced to pay the price,' the friend said. Although the government is now in a strong position, it has a much reduced majority and the next election must be held by January 2002, when Australians will have had a year and a half of their new tax system. To use biblical parlance, of which the Treasurer is so fond, he may have to reap what he has sown.

The worry for the Treasurer is that the GST's impact will be immediate and dramatic, but the tax cuts designed to offset that impact will take time to flow through to taxpayers. A number of Mr Costello's friends and associates report that the leadership issue is a theme which he constantly returns to in conversations. With Mr Howard reportedly setting his sights on outlasting Malcolm Fraser's term of seven-plus years in office, the Treasurer is growing increasingly concerned that the opportunity to take the leadership may have passed him by.

The article leaves one with a very serious question mark about the Treasurer's bona fides regarding the GST, in that it says the Treasurer is acutely aware of the GST's potential to wreak havoc over Australia. He saw governments in New Zealand and Canada—countries with many similarities to Australia—lose office after introducing a GST.

An honest approach by the Treasurer would surely have resulted in full disclosures about the regressive tax to enable a reasonable person to say, `I like this regressive tax. I can see it doing me and my family and future generations a great deal of good,' or on the other hand they could respond to the proposal in the most honest and direct way as expressed by Senator Harradine.

Many Australians at this very moment live in deep fear of the GST. Australians are universally very serious about fairness, honesty and justice and expect their parliamentary leaders to conduct governance on this basis. If our current system of government is to endure, the decision making must be carried out with honesty, integrity and some empathy for ordinary Australians reeling under this government's uncaring economic policies. The term `mutual obligation' is already sounding like a clever facade to cover policy failure.

The Australian people require an honest and open answer from the member for Higgins about his reported fears of the GST. The idea that the Treasurer can implement such wide-ranging and regressive tax changes and at the same time harbour substantial doubt about his decision making is very serious. The article suggests that the Treasurer has serious misgivings about making Australians pay the GST. I call on the Treasurer to provide this chamber with an honest reply to Ms Tracey Aubin's report. After all, `The eye doesn't lie', and he cannot hide behind a facade. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the amendments moved by the member for Hotham. I have to say that the government's form is getting pretty bad when it denies the shadow minister for small business—
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. With the greatest of respect, I was actually on my feet when the honourable member for Lowe sat down. I would therefore expect the call.
—It is the custom to alternate speakers, but I did catch the honourable member for Hunter's eye first, or he caught my eye. I would be happy to call you on the next occasion.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a further point of order, with the greatest respect to you, Sir, a nod between you and the member for Hunter really has little or no relevance as to who should get the call. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would expect the call, in accordance with the custom of the House.

—I have ruled on the point of order that I did see the honourable member for Hunter rise first. There have not been speakers on the government side for a couple of occasions now; I would be more than happy to call the honourable member for Ballarat on the next occasion.

—As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted by the Chief Government Whip, it is pretty ordinary form on the part of government when it denies the shadow minister for small business an opportunity to make a contribution during the second reading debate on a bill the effect of which goes right through the small business community.

—Maybe the minister at the table wants to talk about speaking orders. We have three frontbenchers with an intense interest in this bill, the first being the shadow Treasurer; the second being the shadow Assistant Treasurer; and the third being the shadow minister for small business. It is pretty poor form when you deny the shadow minister for small business an opportunity to speak on this bill.

speech.para: There are few certainties in life beyond taxes and death, but there is one certainty surrounding the GST: it is absolutely bad for small business. That is a view held by not just me but the small business community itself. Every time I am in here the minister for financial services is at the dispatch box—I do not know what the story is; it seems we are on the same House order roster—and he is raving and ranting about the opposition. He has got personal views about the GST and its impact on small firms, but he comes in here with the same mantra every day. You have really got to wonder whether he ever speaks to a small businessperson.

I began by talking about certainties in life. This bill is not about certainties; this bill is about uncertainties. It will significantly contribute to the already significant amount of uncertainty that exists at the moment in the small business sector. Where do you go for evidence of my point that this is again adding to that uncertainty? You first go to the 107 pages of the bill itself, and then you could go to the 79 pages of the explanatory memorandum, and then you could go to the latest Yellow Pages small business survey, which shows that some 74 per cent of small firms in this country are concerned about the impact of the GST. Why wouldn't that be the case?

These latest changes, coming only a matter of weeks after the passage of the GST bills through the Senate, are on top of the changes being proposed by the Ralph Review of Business Taxation, on top of new FBT arrangements, on top of changes to do-it-yourself insurance, and on top of proposed entity taxation arrangements. I could go on and on and on. When will this come to an end? When will this government stop placing layer upon layer upon layer of complexity on the small business community and keep its pre-election promise to cut red tape by 15 per cent, a commitment which is now nothing less than farcical?

talk.start.para: —Members of the House may not be aware of the way in which the speakers lists operate in this place. The Chief Opposition Whip and I, along with our staff, swap the names of those who are going to be speaking on the bill so that we know roughly what the program is going to be. Mr Deputy Speaker, it may be of interest to you and the House—I am sure it will be of interest to one person in particular, whom I am just about to mention—that when that list came across to the Chief Government Whip's office yesterday, outlining who was going to speak on the bill, guess whose name was not there?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Chief Government Whip should be required to authenticate that document. We grant him leave to table it.
—There is no point of order. I call on the Chief Government Whip to address his remarks to the question before the chair, which is that the amendments be agreed to.

—What a scurrilous point of order from the shadow minister for small business. Indeed, his name was not on the list of speakers who were originally going to speak on this matter. Guess what happened this morning? All of a sudden we had a new list, and guess whose name was on that list? The shadow minister for small business. This is the man who expressed anger and outrage that he was not allowed to speak in the second reading debate. He was so concerned about the matter, he did not even put his name down originally to speak on the bill. So I think that that is probably a fair indication of where the ALP are coming from in relation to this matter. This is not a matter about the GST. The Labor Party know full well that the debate about the GST has passed them by. This is about their relationship in the political system and this is about the Australian Labor Party—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on the basis of the comments by the member himself, going to relevance. The member is saying that this bill is not about what this bill is about so, on his own point, he is out. Sit him down.
—There is no point of order. I call on the speaker to continue his remarks.

—I do not see the name of the honourable member who just took the point of order on the speaking list either. It is an indication of how important this matter is to the honourable member, along with the shadow minister for small business. The Labor Party's debate today is about their irrelevance in the political process. What they cannot come to terms with is the fact that the Australian Democrats are now the other political party in the main political game in this country. That can be the only reason why the member for Lowe—

—who would be most unwise to interject, because he is not in his seat—would talk about leadership in the context of these amendments moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Why would he talk about leadership in that context?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to relevance, because the article that I was referring to expressed the grave reservations that the Treasurer had in terms of the GST, and it was very relevant.
—There is no point of order. I call on the member to continue his remarks.

—I cannot believe that the Australian Labor Party are trying to deny me my right to speak on these amendments. I am quite appalled by the fact that they would be taking this course of action. The matter at stake here is the Australian Labor Party's failure to accept that this tax legislation is now part of Australian tax law. If they are genuinely going to play a part in the tax debate, it is incumbent upon them to start talking about it in the generalities of the Australian good. It is simply not appropriate to stand up in this place and start addressing anything except the nuts and bolts of taxation reform in Australia. You have got a choice: you either deal yourself back in or you are permanently dealt out. (Time expired)

—It was very interesting to hear what the previous speaker just said. He tried to make a point about who was not on the speakers list in this debate. It so turns out that the member for Hunter was on the list in terms of what is circulated in the parliament. But who was not on it? The member for Ballarat was not on it. Why did he feel obliged to get up and speak in this place? Because there is not one other backbench member in this parliament prepared to defend the government's GST. We know why the member for Ballarat is standing up in this place—because at the last state election, his party lost every seat in Ballarat. This is a person whose presence in this House is now dated. And he is a person who has said that the amendments before the House are irrelevant to constituents. We will tell you how relevant these amendments are.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I cannot see how the election result in Victoria is relevant to the amendments before the House. I ask that you bring the member for Hotham back to the substance of the bill, which he is not familiar with.

—I draw the attention of those on both sides of the House to the question before the chair, because I think there has been a bit of diversion from the question from those on both sides. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—There are 454 amendments that this government has introduced to the GST bill. That is on top of 302 amendments that have already been introduced in this House. That totals 756 amendments—one less than one of those Boeing aircraft flying around this country, the 757. This, from the new simple tax system. This is a government that does not know what it is doing on tax.

speech.para: The member for Ballarat, who has now left the chamber, has got three amendments which Labor wants to consider, one of which would require disclosure of the GST on receipts. This is a member who, with every other marginal member on that side, is going to vote against our amendment, we presume, that would require receipts to show what the GST is. If you are proud of the tax, Minister, why don't you disclose what it involves? If you think this is a great thing for the Australian people, why are you hiding it from them? Why do you hide it?

Between now and the next election, the member for Ballarat is going to have to deal in his seat with people outside his supermarkets and his shopping centres asking, as they go in and have their 10 per cent taken out by John Howard and Peter Costello, why he wants to hide it. That is one amendment that we are dealing with.

At the same time as this person and this government is responsible for imposing a 10 per cent tax on almost everything, do you know who they have given special exemption to? The high rollers in casinos. This is a great set of values, isn't it? Every ordinary punter in this country will have to pay 10 per cent on almost everything, but the high rollers in the casinos will get an exemption. We have an amendment before the House to reverse that decision. It is an absolute disgrace. We know which side these people's bread is buttered on. They are making special exemptions for them whilst they are imposing an iniquitous, unfair tax on the broad Australian public.

The other amendment we have moved goes to the question of antiavoidance. In this legislation and the previous legislation they watered down antiavoidance procedures. Previously, the legislation required it to be a principle of effect that a scheme entered into was there for the purpose of tax avoidance. They have changed one word—`a' to `the'. To get a tax avoidance scheme caught now, under their legislation, `the' principle purpose must have been tax avoidance not `a' principle purpose. So the Christopher Skases of the world can well devise a scheme which they can argue has as its principle purpose something other than tax avoidance and this legislation lets them off the hook. What you are putting before the parliament is an absolute disgrace and that is what we are trying to redress. That is what our amendments are about. The whip goes out of the House talking about a lack of procedure, where was due process in this regard? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In summary—
—In summary? You're gagging debate, are you?

—You bet we are. We reject the Labor Party's assertions about tax receipts. I want the people of Australia to know this: for 13 years the Labor Party never disclosed on any receipts the wholesale sales tax they charged on goods. I want everyone to know that they were paying tax rates of zero per cent, 12 per cent, 22 per cent, 32 per cent, 41 per cent, 45 per cent under the Labor Party and they were never, ever disclosed. In fact, instead of delivering the l-a-w tax cuts, Keating came back into government and increased wholesale sales taxes from 10 to 12 per cent, from 22 to 30 per cent and from 30 to 32 per cent without one dollar of compensation for Australians—without one dollar of compensation for the tax increases imposed by Labor. They come in here and lecture us and bore Australians to tears with their hypocrisy about transparency.

speech.para: It is simple. With a GST, one-eleventh of everything you pay will be tax. Australian consumers do not want to go the American way and have one price on the shelves and another one at the cash register. They have made that perfectly clear. The Labor Party have a history of high regulation. They say we should get businesses to run two cash registers. The Labor Party endorse that. Why? Because when you look across their front bench you find that no-one there has ever run a business.

The shadow minister is putting up his hand saying, `Why did I not get the call?' Because the Labor Party put five backbenchers before the shadow minister for small business. I know he sits at the end of the front bench, but he should not be forgotten there.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Given the procedural point of order that was taken on me, I can hardly understand what the purpose of the process of people in debate has to do with the detail of the amendments that are before the House. I would suggest to you that you require him to address the matter that is before the House. I am reluctant to take this point of order because I believe in freedom in this place, but they took it on me so it should go against them.
—I thank the member. Resume your seat.

—We have a jail-keeper over there who believes in freedom. There are two issues. One is that the honourable member for Rankin and the honourable member for Kingston raised the issue of the application of the GST to state charges. We are waiting on the states to provide us with advice on what services they want the GST applied to. We are waiting on the states to give us that information. The other is that, in relation to gambling, it is a fact that under the initial recommendation a higher tax rate would have been applied in individual hands. Under this circumstance we apply the appropriate level of tax.

speech.para: Finally, I come back to the issue of disclosure—an issue that the Labor Party is very nervous about. We reaffirm that we want Australian taxpayers to understand that when they go to their supermarket and their deli they know what they are paying for. One-eleventh of every price they pay will be tax, unlike the situation with the Labor Party where it could have been zero, 12, 22, 32, 41 or 45 per cent and then it depended on the mark-up of the retailer. It could have been every distortion. That is the great fallacy of the Labor Party's arguments in this debate, Accordingly, I move:
That the question be now put:
Question put.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Original question put:
That the amendments (Mr Crean's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aged Care. Isn't it a fact that section 63-2 of the Aged Care Act requires you to table in the parliament by 30 September a report which provides the following information: unmet demand for nursing home places; waiting times; accommodation bonds; building, upgrading and refurbishment of nursing homes; and the adequacy of Commonwealth subsidies? Has your department prepared this report? If so, why have you not tabled it? Have you got something to hide from older Australians, or is this just another example of incompetence in another portfolio area?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order No. 144. The first part of that question asks for a legal opinion; the last part quite clearly is of a frivolous nature and does not seek an opinion. I ask that you rule the entire question out of order.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: I put it to you that no question could be more quintessentially in order than the parliament asking a member of the executive whether she has complied with a piece of legislation for which she is responsible. It is quintessentially what question time is for, and it must be in order.

—As I am sure the Leader of the Opposition is aware from the eye contact I attempted to have with him, I deem the question to be in order but the latter part of it, in fact, to be unnecessarily provocative, and I think he was well aware of that. The question is in order, and I invite the Minister for Aged Care to respond.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, but I do not mind a bit of provocation.
—The minister will respond to the question.

—Subject to checking whether or not the particular section referred to by the Leader of the Opposition is accurate—because I, like my other colleagues here, would never take their word for it—I can say that there is a draft report which covers that sort of material which will be tabled in the parliament. I am sure that you will be looking forward to reading it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Will the minister inform the House of the status of the Health Insurance Commission's investigation into magnetic resonance imaging units?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I received some advice just before question time from the Health Insurance Commission. When I finish with it, I will be happy to table it for the benefit of honourable members. The Health Insurance Commission tells me that it has completed investigation into 29 MRI units. One matter has already gone to the Director of Public Prosecutions. A further 15 are to be cleared for referral to the DPP over the next two weeks on the basis of backdating or conditional nature of contracts. Thus, with over 50 per cent of the contracts examined, there has actually been found sufficient evidence to warrant referral to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Of the remaining 13 contracts, only six have been cleared and seven are expected to be cleared. With some of these there may be a degree of suspicion, but not enough to warrant referral to the Director of Public Prosecutions. I am happy to table this document for the benefit of honourable members.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aged Care. Minister, why has Aged Care Queensland been forced to take out paid advertising condemning your inaction in responding to the Productivity Commission report into nursing home funding? Are you aware that Uniting Community Services have said, `Your inaction is a time bomb.' Minister, why is the aged care sector still waiting for your response nine months after the report was handed to the government? Doesn't this show just how arrogant you have become in not protecting the interests of frail aged Queenslanders?
—The member for Lilley knows that he is advancing an argument in that part of the question.
—Minister, have you become—and I quote the Prime Minister—`too big for your boots'?
—The Minister for Aged Care will respond to the first part of the question only.
—I have been waiting for a question from the opposition on the Productivity Commission for some time. Obviously you have not wanted to know the information, otherwise you would have asked earlier.

answer.para: Mr Sidebottom interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Braddon has been a persistent interjector since question time started, which I admit was only a few minutes ago. I ask him to desist.

—Let me say that unlike the Labor Party, who commissioned the Gregory report into the need for capital funding and never responded to it ever, this government is responding to the Productivity Commission report which was commissioned by this government prior to the last election, delivered to the Treasurer and subsequently published on 31 March. Since that date, we have been consulting with the industry—and I might say two important discussions took place on Monday of this week—regarding aspects of that report so that when there is a published response, which I would remind the Labor Party they never did to the Gregory report, it will be one that has been thoroughly researched and consulted on.

answer.para: Let me say in the interim that one of the things mentioned in that report is the question of so-called coalescence, which is bringing to a national rate the subsidy that is paid for nursing homes, as they were called. The fact is this is yet another matter that we are having to fix up after the Labor Party, which funded every state at a different rate on the basis that it cost a different amount of money to run a facility in different states. This government decided that it was better to come to a nation al rate, as was done for hostels, and indeed the Productivity Commission has agreed with that proposition. How one achieves the national average rate is the point that is under discussion.

I simply say that in the period since the commission brought down that report this government has increased funding to residential aged care facilities. In the case of Queensland, since 1995-96—which is your last budget—we have increased funding to that state by 58 per cent. In other words, an enormous amount of additional money has gone in through the resident classification scale, which is delivering more money to all providers right across Australia. In your last budget you spent $2.5 billion, and in our last budget we are spending $3.5 billion—an increase of $1 billion into the residential aged care sector. That is commendable by anybody's yardstick.

A lot of that money has been put in since the report of the Productivity Commission. Nonetheless, we take seriously the matters raised in that report. We are consulting with industry; we are consulting with consumers. When the response comes down, it will not be an ad hoc response but properly researched and meeting the needs of the aged care community.

talk.start.para: —What is the government's response to the decision on East Timor taken overnight by the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly?

—As I am sure all honourable members are aware, last night the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly took a decision which effectively grants independence to the people of East Timor. It is a very important moment in the history of that country. It is a decision that will be widely welcomed throughout the world. It gives effect to the popular will of the people of East Timor. It will begin a new era in relations between the people of that territory and the people of what will soon be to them the rest of what used to be the same country; that is, Indonesia.

answer.para: The House will be aware of the backdrop against which this decision was taken. They will be aware of the leadership played by Australia in assembling a multinational force. They will be aware of the tragic circumstances in East Timor that led to the need for the assembly of that force. What we must now all do is look to the future. When Xanana Gusmao met me last week I indicated to him that, despite the difficulties that would be involved in the process of reconciliation and moving forward together, it was desirable that East Timor see its future as lying in a closer relationship with the people of Indonesia. East Timor in the near future—a small, fragile, highly vulnerable but nonetheless free country—will need the help of Australia; East Timor will need the help of the rest of the world; and East Timor, Indonesia and Australia, forever together in this part of the world, will need to work out a way of cooperating together into the future.

I believe that the decision taken by the Indonesian constituent assembly will make a positive contribution towards improving relations between Australia and Indonesia. It is inevitable that those relationships are strained at present because of Australia's proper role in East Timor. It is equally important and also inevitable in our own interests that we try to rebuild our relationship with Indonesia on a proper basis of mutual respect. I believe that, as the irritant of East Timor begins to recede into the past so far as the relationship between our two countries are concerned, we can start to build a better relationship with Indonesia. But it will be a different relationship. It will be a relationship instructed by the circumstances of our involvement in East Timor. It will be a relationship instructed and conditioned by the fact that Indonesia is now historically in the process of embracing democracy. As we meet in this question time, the same People's Consultative Assembly could well be voting on who will be the next president of that country, and whoever wins that ballot will be a person with whom the government I lead will seek to cooperate. That person will be installed as president as a result of a democratic process.

Whatever criticism may have been offered of Indonesia's conduct in recent times, it is a remarkable thing that a country of 211 million people, that has passed through many decades of authoritarian rule, should have embraced democracy. We should, as friends and neighbours, do all we can to facilitate the entrenchment of the democratic process in Indonesia.

I also take the opportunity of saying that Dr Habibie, the current President of Indonesia, is not a candidate for election as the next president of Indonesia. He has had his critics around the world, and he has had his critics within Indonesia, but it would be unfair and churlish of this House not to record the fact that it was Dr Habibie's decision which led to the ballot being held in East Timor that led to the people of East Timor voting for independence. For that, he does deserve acknowledgment and respect. He also deserves acknowledgment and respect for the fact that, after taking over from his predecessor, President Suharto, he did take Indonesia down a democratic path. It is very easy in retrospect to say that he had no alternative. It is even easier in retrospect to turn around and say, `Well, he shouldn't have done this, or he should have done it at another time.' The reality is that he did two very important things for which he will forever be entitled to credit—he gave the people of East Timor a vote on their future which their leader, Xanana Gusmao, said they would readily embrace, no matter what the pain and travail, and he also gave to the people of Indonesia the opportunity to embrace democracy.

At a time when in other parts of the region nations are unfortunately turning away from democracy, it is a very welcome trend indeed that Indonesia should be embracing it. All of us, whatever our politics and whatever our views about the minutiae of the debate on East Timor, who care about a close relationship between Australia and Indonesia based on mutual respect will hope that the democratic experiment succeeds. We will wish the new Indonesian President well, and it will be the obligation of this government and future governments of this country to work closely with the people and the government of Indonesia on a proper basis of mutual respect but, nonetheless, recognising that we have a destiny together forever in this part of the world.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, I refer you to an article in today's Bulletin , headed `Telstra: how we were short-changed' and `Telstra: the float that sank billions'. Do you still reject the Auditor-General's finding that the first sale of Telstra was clearly underpriced and that you effectively lost billions of dollars of taxpayers' money? Is it true that the independent advisers for the first Telstra sale, BZW, advised the government to sell Telstra at $3.30 and one day later were advising clients that Telstra shares were a good buy at $4.07? Don't you effectively admit in this article that you knew in advance that the price would be set too low because the firms running and advising the government on the sale were also advising clients to buy Telstra shares?

—I am delighted that the honourable member for Melbourne has asked me a question on Telstra because I noted some articles in the media in the last day or two which indicated very clearly that Mr Blount, the former CEO of Telstra, came to Australia only because he was promised by Labor that Labor would privatise Telstra.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The House will come to order, and the minister will come to the question.

—In fact, I think he indicated that the honourable Leader of the Opposition was present when that particular discussion took place. But what this government has done in any privatisation of Telstra and all of the other assets was to ensure that Labor's debt was paid off from the proceeds. Labor sold and used their money. They frittered it away on current programs. When it comes to Telstra 1, the price that was received at that time was the optimal return for that particular stock at that time. I do not criticise Labor who, under the now Leader of the Opposition, in June 1994 sold Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for $2.30 a share when the price of a Commonwealth Serum Laboratories share today is $18.

answer.para: Mr Tanner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Melbourne has asked his question.
—I do not criticise, because you should have sold it. That is $2.30 to $18.

answer.para: Mr Tanner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Melbourne is defying the chair.

—I do not criticise Labor for what happened when they entered the market on the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. The shares of the first tranche were sold at $5.40. These shares are trading at the present time at around $24. I accept the manner in which the market operates. I can recall some quotes from the former shadow Treasurer in the week leading up to the sale of Telstra 1 when he was out there saying, `This will be a fire sale. They will get $8 billion for it. They should pull it.' When it came to that sale a week later—and this is indicated very clearly by the process in the book build—the proceeds that were received for the sale of Telstra 1 were some $14.3 billion. That is on top of a recapitalisation a couple of months earlier whereby the taxpayers of Australia received the amount of $3 billion. That is a total of $17.3 billion.

answer.para: When you see a live market created and that spike, it is interesting to note that, in a comparison between Labor's sale of CBA 1 and this government's sale of Telstra 1, the increase over about the first 50 or 60 days ran parallel. CBA 1 went up about 24 per cent—but, of course, you had created a live market. When it came to setting the price, a range was stated—in order to generate the demand for Telstra 1—of between $2.80 and $3.30. Six days prior to the actual striking of the price in Telstra 1, I increased that by 10c. That was because, quite clearly, the demand had been created, and I was interested in getting the optimal return for the taxpayers of Australia. I have little doubt under the process that was adopted with an independent adviser—and the Labor Party never received independent advice on these matters—that the taxpayers of Australia received a maximum return. Sadly, as I have said so often, those proceeds had to be used to pay off Labor's debt, as have the proceeds of Telstra 2, which have been received as a result of those shares going to the market earlier this year.

So the taxpayers of Australia have been well served by the sale of both Telstra 1 and Telstra 2. It is all very well for someone coming in a few years later to talk about a price that can be explained on the basis of telcos around the world going up. They are a growth stock around the world, and Telstra is at the very top of the tree when it comes to that because it is a very dynamic Australian company. That is what brought out demand again on this occasion. Telstra is improving the telecommunications of this country and it is taking its rightful place at the head of the very solid companies that exist in this country. It is part of what has been a phenomenon around the world in recent years. As more and more of these telecommunication companies are going to the market, there is a demand in whatever that market might be.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer to the government's proposals to reform Australia's business taxation system. Would you advise the House of the likely impact of these reforms on compliance costs for small businesses?

—I thank the honourable member for Makin for her question. The great news is that legislation will come into the parliament tomorrow to cut company taxes and capital gains taxes, including the capital gains of all of those people who, incidentally, became shareholders in the Commonwealth Bank as a result of Labor's privatisation. The good news for all of those people—who have obviously had rather large capital gains under the Labor Party's policies; I think it was $5.40 to $22—who were introduced to privatisation by the Australian Labor Party is that, if the government's legislation goes through, the capital gains tax on that increase will be halved. If the Labor Party does not support this legislation, it will be taxing all of those millions of shareholders, which it introduced to the market on very generous terms, at double the rate which they need to pay. So on this side of the House, we say that Thursday could be a great day for small business and the shareholders of Australia, if we can only get on and pass legislation to reform the business taxation system.

answer.para: In addition to that, not only will small businesses get a reduction in their company rate to 34 cents in the dollar and then to 30 cents in the dollar but, if the government's legislation—which comes as part of a simplified small business taxation system—is passed, they will also be able to write off all assets of $1,000 or less and to pool and depreciate all of their assets at standard rates, and up to 75 per cent of small businesses will no longer have to do an annual stocktake, which will be a dramatic simplification for the small businesses of Australia.

There are also two other great benefits that will go through the parliament in this legislation, if the Labor Party can bring itself to support reform. The first benefit is that small business people when selling a business can have 50 per cent of the assets of the business taken out of capital gains tax and then pay the half rate on the remainder, which has the effect of making only 25 per cent of the small business taxable. The second benefit is that those people in small business who have held an asset for 15 years and are approaching 55 years of age can sell that asset capital gains tax free. These are great reforms—this is great simplification and this is a major improvement for the small businesses of this country.

If the opposition can support reform, this is a benefit that we can give small business—along with lower interest rates, improved indirect taxation, improved industrial relations changes, more jobs and the good business conditions that prevail for small businesses at the moment. It is going to take some leadership from the Leader of the Opposition to support reform; it is not something that he is used to. But if he can reach out and support reform, we will commend him for doing so, and I am sure that the business community of Australia would be pleased to see a change from the opposition at all costs to something that is creative for this country.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Do you recall on Monday refusing to reaffirm the National Party's election commitment that, until an independent inquiry certified that Telstra service levels were adequate, there would be no full sale of Telstra? Are you aware that, while you were going soft on full privatisation, the federal president of the National Party's women's section, Pam Stallman, slammed the push by the Minister for Finance and Administration for full privatisation, saying on regional Queensland radio that it was `insane' and that it was time that the National Party stood up to the Liberal Party? If Pam Stallman can stand up to the Liberal Party, why can't you?

—I note with some interest that that question, or a large slab of it, was simply read off a press release issued by the shadow minister on Monday afternoon. I made it quite plain on Monday afternoon that our policy, which I think has been widely circulated and is widely understood on this matter, still stands. I thought it was quite irrelevant to have to restate the proposition that that includes a public inquiry into the adequacy of service levels—the service levels that we have dictated; that you did not dictate—and the obligations that we have put on Telstra being met before a further sale took place. Plainly, I add that that inquiry would involve input from the country people of the sort that I met in Texas last weekend, who had expressed some concern. The member for Maranoa and the member for New England were also there. The people of Texas in Queensland expressed concerns about service levels, which I will be taking up with the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.

answer.para: But I would have thought that it was quite sufficient to point out that our policy position on this matter has not altered. It does mean us meeting the commitments that we have made but, more particularly, I think it is worth stating that this really belongs in the category of useful contributions to the debate about regional services and the needs of rural communities that we get from the opposite side—such as questions asking me to name the regional universities that are facing some financial difficulties. What a useful thing for me to be asked in this place—name them for the benefit of country parents so that these universities will be exposed! This is an absolutely absurd proposition.

It is worth recalling that the opposition's lack of commitment to services in rural telecommunications extended to the deal they did with Vodafone which would have shut down the analog mobile phone network from the end of this year and would have left huge areas of Australia without any mobile telephone coverage at all. I really believe that this question reflects a pathetic attempt on that side—by a group of people who have opposed every worthwhile reform and policy prescription that we have put forward to help rural and regional Australia—to now paint themselves as having discovered some latter-day concern for the wellbeing of country people.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, would you inform the House of the government's commitment to improve the conditions of the workplace for all Australian workers? What obstacles have been placed in the way of the government reforming workplaces to the benefit of all Australians?

—I thank the member for Page for his question. Actions speak louder than words. If you take the ACTU's estimate, real wage increases for Australian workers are up by 9.1 per cent since we have been in office. I am not using our figures but the ACTU figures. Over the 13 years Labor was in office, the real wages of low income people actually fell. Not only have those people enjoyed higher wages; they have had a better chance of getting a job. Over 500,000 jobs have been created since this government has been in office. In respect of basic rights for workers, under this government all workers are guaranteed freedom of association, the right to join a union and, furthermore, the right to not join a union if that is their choice.

answer.para: The honourable member asks: what are the obstacles in the way of further reform? He has only to listen to the interjections from the other side to see the obstacles sitting there giving us their usual response. The loudest one, typical of the frontbench, is a former trade union official. He is a former trade union hack who outlasted his usefulness and so was sent to the federal parliament—former ACTU president, Lord Hotham—

talk.start.para: —Minister!
—Mr Speaker, would you like me to name them all?
—No, Minister.

—I do not believe it is necessary for the Speaker to rise in order to get members in a responsible position on the frontbench simply to listen in silence. The minister has the call. He also has an obligation to generally raise the dignity of the place by making appropriate references to members.

—Talking about members, if you want to go to the statistics, 58 per cent of the frontbench of the Labor Party are ex-union hacks. If you go to the Senate, 69 per cent of the senators on the Labor Party side are former trade union officials. In the House, 40 per cent—nearly half of them—are former trade union officials. It is no surprise that, when the unions have a few problems with declining membership, who do they turn to to help them? They turn to none other than the frontbench and backbench of the Labor Party on the basis that all the members shall use their offices for the purposes of boosting trade union membership. We know now from the TWU that they want their parliamentary offices, paid for by taxpayers, to be used as branch offices of the trade union movement.
—You didn't get this up yesterday, did you?
—Do I have your invitation to continue, Mr Speaker?
—I did not interrupt the minister.
—Thank you. You were obviously paying close attention, Mr Speaker. I do not suppose there is any chance you would ever use your office as a branch office of the Transport Workers Union.

answer.para: Mr Tanner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I warn the member for Melbourne. I have put up with persistent interjections from him.

—It demonstrates how close the two are. The Transport Workers Union, which now wants to use opposition offices as branch offices, is the same union that tipped more than three-quarters of a million dollars into the Labor Party between 1995 and 1998. That does not even include donations to local members. Of course, it has always been a two-way process. When Labor were in office, they were funding the TWU using taxpayers' money and getting it back as a dividend. When you look at the Senate, you have in person Nick Bolkus, formerly of the TWU; Steve Hutchins, a past president of the New South Wales branch of the TWU; and Stephen Conroy. They are not only pulling the strings from outside; they are running the Labor Party from within. How can the public have faith in a political party that basically sold its soul to the trade union movement?

—Mr Speaker, a point of order on relevance: is it relevant for the minister to be bringing into play the fact that a number of us here have represented ordinary working Australians? Minister, perhaps you might like to explain how 19 of your colleagues have family trusts—something that two per cent of Australians have.
—The Leader of the Opposition knows that the chair was extending to him the courtesy it should in that point of order and it was abused.
—My question is to the Minister for Employment Services. I ask the minister whether he agrees with these comments by Minister Reith in his secret employment agenda of 3 December 1998:

question.para: Most long term unemployed will benefit from the assistance received under the Job Network arrange ments and this will continue to be the main vehicle through which public assistance is provided.

Can the minister explain why, if the Job Network is as successful as he says it is, six out of every 10 unemployed people have now been out of work for longer than two years—the highest figure on record?
Mr Griffin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Bruce!
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! The member for Bruce is warned!

—The other day you instructed the House that questions were to be consistent with the standing orders and not be speeches. You have been defied as nearly every question today has breached that, and I believe some action is necessary.
—Mr Speaker, point of order: I draw your attention to page 277 of House of Representatives Practice , in particular to what is referred to as frivolous and dubious points of order.

—I remind the member for Chifley—and the member for Charlton—that, if I were to act on frivolous points of order, very few of them would in fact see the light of day. In the case of the point of order from the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, in 16 years the chair has heard a lot of questions from both sides of this House, and a large number of them have advanced a good deal more argument than that advanced by the member for Dickson. I do not like the tone of some questions, but I have endeavoured to be consistent in my ruling, and I deem hers to be in order.

—I thank the member for Dickson for her question. Naturally, I do support what was said by my friend and senior colleague the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. He made excellent sense in that letter. As for the performance of the Job Network, I have never said that the Job Network was perfect. I have simply said that it is better than the CES and the Working Nation programs that it replaced. I repeat what I have said to the House before: in terms of getting unemployed people into work, the Job Network is at least 50 per cent better than the old CES. I also hope to be in a position very shortly to give the House some more detailed figures on the performance of intensive assistance which show that intensive assistance is comprehensively outperforming the Working Nation programs of the former government. Rather than taking pot shots at members of the Job Network, which comprises some of the greatest organisations this country possesses, the member for Dickson should get out around the country, travel a little bit, get out of Dickson and see some of the other people around the country, and then she will discover just what sort of job the Job Network is doing.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Are there areas of regional Australia that are growing and making a success of building new economic and employment opportunities, despite the challenges they face? Will the regional Australia summit, being convened next week, provide an opportunity for successful regions to share their experiences and help build a better future for all regional Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I must say I like the colour of his tie, and I should add I am looking for an invitation to visit Toowoomba to talk to all those people from my electorate who have retired up there to see what they are doing.

answer.para: Mr Howard interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No, but we might counsel them on this issue, Prime Minister.
—Question time would be facilitated if the minister came to the question.
—I was provoked, Mr Speaker.
—I'm sorry, Mr Speaker, I provoked him.

—All of us are concerned about seeing the best possible future for our rural and regional communities. There is an understandable highlighting of the difficulties that much of the bush faces at the moment. It is important to remember, though, that many communities are finding new and innovative ways forward. Next week we will be having a summit here, and I welcome the opportunity to say to the House that one of the things we will be doing is looking to those communities that really are making a go of it. I could name several, in fact. One that comes to mind is Dubbo, in the member for Parkes's electorate. It is a larger centre with very high growth rates. It is interesting to note that, in part, it is able to attract people there for lifestyle issues. People want to know about things like crime rates, education, restaurants and so forth. There are positive answers to those sorts of questions which help encourage people to go and invest there, and they have been very good at extolling those pluses. Just a little while ago, there were 100 hectares under wine grapes in Mudgee, in my own electorate, and now it is 4,000 hectares. Tourism and a whole range of local activities are seeing that community grow.

answer.para: Leeton, in the member for Riverina's electorate, has a growth rate of around 1½ per cent. I was there recently and they are looking at a new industry based on pectin. That has come about in part because of the Commonwealth government's contribution to research and development. Leeton is a forward-looking community. Longreach, in Queensland, last year generated more money from tourism than it did from agricultural pursuits. Many new jobs are emerging in a very good way in that community. Moree, in northern New South Wales, is turning around a tendency towards quite serious decline in recent times by actively seeking new businesses in a range of ways. They are addressing problems. They have been actively pursuing culturally relevant jobs for the Aboriginal communities. They have created 75 jobs in the cotton industry alone—jobs that did not exist until very recently. There is a serious main street program going on there to make it a more attractive town for people to live in, to come to and to invest in. In the town of Beechworth, in the member for Indi's electorate, we have seen an innovative fellow grow a bakery, in a decade or so, from just two employees to something like 64.

These sorts of success stories need to be highlighted, and we will be doing that next week. It needs to be said that the investment climate that we have created is a very sound one for growth in rural and regional areas in these times of difficulty. The Ralph report, for which we are looking for some leadership and support from the other side—

talk.start.para: —You will never get that.

—We might yet, Treasurer. Do not be too pessimistic; we may yet see some leadership. There is no doubt that the changes to capital gains tax will really make a difference to the attractiveness for small businesses of investing in rural areas. Then there are the huge reductions in transport costs that will come next year with the abolition of wholesale sales tax and there is the slashing of the fuel tax.

answer.para: It is worth making the point that we have seen a transition in the position of the spokesperson for rural and regional issues on that side of the House. The test as to whether the member for Batman is fair dinkum about his commitment to rural and regional Australia might be in a simple repudiation from him of the view of the previous spokesman, the member for Dickson, that our slashing of the diesel costs was nothing more than a $7.8 billion boost to pollution. We might believe he has some credibility when he repudiates that and acknowledges that it is a valuable reform for rural and regional Australia.

There are a range of very valuable tools—whether it is Rural Plan, the Rural Assistance Program, which the minister right behind me runs, the tourism grants, Invest Australia, the TradeStart offices, Networking the Nation and the rural transaction centres—that we are giving rural communities to help them find a way forward. One of the objectives of the summit next week will be to establish the criteria for success by looking at what successful communities have done and then seeking to more widely spread that success across rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Does the minister stand by his proposal for a lower wage rate for the long-term unemployed, outlined in his secret employment agenda? In particular, does he still believe, and I quote:

question.para: Discounting wages would also likely require complementary action on the social security entitlements for this group if adequate work incentives were to be provided.

Minister, isn't this code for the welfare cuts that are contained in Senator Newman's welfare discussion paper that the government is refusing to release? Which payments does the minister think should be cut, and by how much?

talk.start.para: —Well, I would ask the honourable member if she stands by her statement back in—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would be very happy to answer the question, but she was the one who said that a gap had opened up under the leadership of the Prime Minister back whenever it was that she came into the Labor Party. The fact of the matter is, as one of her colleagues said the other day, `Cheryl has become a weight around all of our necks; you never know what she is going to say or do next.'

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order and it goes to relevance. The minister was asked a question about the continuity of his views that low income earners need to be forced onto discounted wages and deprived of social security entitlements. That is what he put in his secret report. We want to know: is this what is in Newman's welfare discussion paper and what does he want to cut?
—The Leader of the House was not responding directly to the question. His introductory remarks were not out of character but I invite him now to come to the question.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker—neither out of character nor out of order in any way.
—I am not sure about that. I will determine the latter.
—I did write to the Prime Minister—in fact, it was not a secret document because I was the one who, in due course, released it.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is a fact. What it demonstrated is that on this side of the House we are genuinely interested in policy. In terms of policy development, since that letter you have seen this government adopt a number of important policy initiatives which have been to the benefit of all Australians. For example, we enhanced the Work for the Dole Program, which was raised in that letter and which provides real benefits.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order and it goes to relevance. It was a specific question: which wages and which payments does he want to see cut?
—I listened to the question. I have already called the minister to respond to the question. I believe he is doing so and I invite him to continue his answer.
—That letter also talked about what we would do for indigenous employment and today I launched another aspect.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The question was about the letter and I am answering the elements in the letter. The Leader of the Opposition asks about wages—

—Mr Speaker, twice the Leader of the Opposition has raised relevance and twice you have asked the minister to return to the substance of the question. This is plainly defiance. He is seeking to avoid answering a question which is plainly relevant to the conduct of this parliament and he should be required to answer it.

—The member for Denison may not have heard my first admonition to the minister, which was to ask him to come to the question. He is now responding to correspondence related to the question, but I expect he will, of course, come to the question asked as well.
—As I was saying, we announced an expansion of the Work for the Dole scheme. That letter also referred to unfair dismissal issues and in that regard—
—What did it say about reducing wages?

—I am happy to get to all of these matters. In respect of unfair dismissals, that is still a problem for the small business community, and flowing out of those discussions there are amendments currently before this chamber which the Labor Party is opposing which would provide benefits for small business and which would mean more jobs.

answer.para: Mr Speaker, the other significant issue—and I will then move on—was the corporations power. That was contained in the letter to the Prime Minister and I have spoken on that publicly since that letter was released. That is an issue which I think we do need to consider more carefully and I am having my department continue to advise me on aspects of that.

In respect of wages and the award system, the government's policy is absolutely clear. That is a matter for the commission. In terms of safety net wage increases through awards, it is my view that—where we can reasonably within the government's general macroeconomic management—we ought to be arguing for higher wages based on higher productivity. That is our approach to wages. The opposition asked me about wages and I will tell them what the policy was when they were in government. They have boasted about reducing people's wages and they did reduce their wages.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order.
—A frivolous point of order.
—It is not a frivolous point of order; it goes to relevance.
—I will determine whether it is frivolous or not, as the Leader of the Opposition knows.
—The precise paragraph said:

interjection.para: Discounting wages would also likely require complementary action on the social security entitlements for this group if adequate work incentives were to be provided.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition has made his point and will resume his seat.
—We want to know what he is doing about it.

—The Leader of the Opposition has been in this House even longer than the chair. He is aware that there is an obligation to have questions framed in a particular way. Ministers are free to answer any question in any way they choose, and the obligation that ministers face is the obligation to be relevant. The Leader of the House has in fact come to the very point of the question asked, and I call him to conclude his answer.

—I certainly will, Mr Speaker.
