I conclude by saying that we are in favour of higher real wages and we are not in favour of discounting wages, and have no such proposal currently or in the future on the books. Our policy is higher wages and, furthermore, we have got the reforms to ensure that our businesses through higher productivity can pay higher wages.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

question.para: Mr Zahra interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for McMillan is a persistent interjector. He was elected, I would have thought, to represent the electors of McMillan. He will shortly face a choice between remaining here and representing them, or leaving the chamber and leaving them unrepresented.

—My question to the minister is: is the minister aware of reports in the media that the costs of early school leaving are as high as $2.6 billion? Would the minister advise the House of government initiatives to improve education and training opportunities for young Australians?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Menzies for his question. I am aware of reports that have appeared in the press on the Dusseldorp Skills Forum study on the cost to Australia of early school leaving. The precise figure of $2.6 billion is dependent upon the particular assumptions made in that report, but it is a report which draws attention to the losses in income and opportunity that are suffered by young people who leave school early. This was a very serious problem when the government came to office, because the 70 per cent of young people who do not go from school to university had been appallingly neglected during the years of the Labor Party's government. Indeed, an earlier report by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum in 1998 based on 1996 data—that is, data referring to the period of the Labor government—said:

answer.para: Young Australians have gained a few substantial benefits from the dollars, words and policy efforts expended on them over the last decade.
Those words amount to the statement that the Labor Party failed young Australians.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is an effort to deny it on the other side of the House now, but it is in fact an admitted failure by the Labor Party itself.
—No-one believes you.
—Peter Baldwin in his Lighthouse discussion paper in 1997 said:

answer.para: Accommodating the needs of those not intending to proceed directly on to university education in the final years of school is something we didn't do enough about in government.
Mr Lee interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Dobell is warned.

—John Dawkins was reported in Neal Blewett's book as referring to Labor's `awful record on the subject of vocational education'. Young people were simply expelled from school onto the unemployment queues. It has fallen to this government to care for the interests of those young Australians, the generation of young Australians, the 70 per cent who do not go on to university. As a result of this government's actions we have greatly increased the opportunities for vocational education in the senior school curriculum.

answer.para: In 1995, under the last year of Labor, there were some 26,000 students doing vocational education in schools. This year, as a result of this government's initiatives and concern for these young people, 130,000 school students will be undertaking vocational education and training in schools. There are now some 90,000 more apprenticeship opportunities for these young people than there were when Labor drove apprenticeships into the ground. Indeed, this year some 5,000 part-time apprenticeships are being undertaken by young people while they are still at school. We would like to see those numbers go up substantially. If every state in Australia were observing the best practice state, that number would be not 5,000 but 13,000; and we want to see those numbers go even higher. This year, the Jobs Pathway program will be assisting some 62,000 young people to make a successful transition from school to work. It has been up to this government to remedy the betrayal of a generation that took place under the Labor Party in office.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, I refer to your answer earlier today. If 16 out of 29 MRI units are accounted for by either backdating or conditional contracts, what accounts for the remaining 13? When you say that these contracts have been cleared or are expected to be cleared, are you saying they have only been cleared of backdating or of being conditional contracts, or have they been cleared for insider knowledge as well?

—I am saying that the Health Insurance Commission believe that there is sufficient reason to refer more than half of the cases to the DPP. Everyone is entitled to the presumption of innocence, but they believe that through their investigations they have uncovered sufficient material to do that. For the ones that they say have been cleared, that means that they will not be sending them to the DPP. It does not mean that there is not still a suspicion that there is a possibility of backdating or that there may have been a non-binding contract that had supposedly been binding. It is not just that they cannot find evidence to do it: they have no evidence whatsoever that there was any leak.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —By any measure, a great deal of tolerance has been exercised during question time today. I now issue, reluctantly, a general warning.
—Of course it is to both sides, the member for Chifley.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Will the minister inform the House of the recent developments in Australia's export performance for cars and components?

—I thank the member for Deakin for his question. Of course, everybody in the House recognises the great job that the member for Deakin does as an advocate for Australia's automotive industry. The member for Deakin has been an active participant in the processes of reform that this government has implemented over the past few years, to the great benefit of Australia's automotive industry. I would like to inform the House, in response to the member's question, that Australia's automotive exports increased to a record $2.77 billion in 1998-99, a nine per cent increase on the previous year. This is in spite of the economic recession that we experienced in the region of South-East Asia, and it is during a period when Australia's exporters have shown that they are quite entrepreneurial in their activities in finding new markets.

answer.para: Those new markets have yielded some unbelievable statistics as far as the automotive industry is concerned. Those new markets, particularly in the Middle East and South America that had not been opened up prior to this, have been opened up in recent years. The Middle East market now accounts for about $560 million worth of Australian automotive exports, especially Toyota Camrys and Holden Commodores. The statistics in a couple of countries in the Middle East are quite compelling. Exports in the past 12 months have seen a 339 per cent increase to Saudi Arabia and a 480 per cent increase to Kuwait.

talk.start.para: —Off what sort of base?

—Those statistics pale into insignificance when you see the increase in South America. In South America, where Holden has commenced shipments of cars to Argentina, we have seen a 2,500 per cent increase in the marketplace. There was an interjection, `Off what sort of base?' Well, the base was fairly low, and we inherited that base from the Australian Labor Party. We have introduced a policy of pragmatic tariff reform that has given consistency and certainty to Australia's automotive industry and has encouraged that automotive industry to invest in what it is doing and to invest in that export effort. It is producing these sorts of export figures in an automotive industry that is being increasingly recognised around the world for its ability and for the R&D that is taking place in that export industry.

answer.para: Mr Cox interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Kingston clearly does not want to represent the car workers in this place, and so for the next hour I will accommodate him. He will excuse himself from the House under standing order 304A.

—I wanted to inform the House that just recently the Prime Minister's special automotive envoy, Mr Ian Grigg, visited the US and, while there, had a meeting with Mr Jac Nasser, the chief executive of Ford. Mr Nasser has offered to host an exhibition to promote Australian auto technology in the Ford Technology Centre in the US. I understand that the automotive industry will take that up, and we will be looking at facilitating that from a government perspective. These export gains flow from our government's efforts in putting in place a market access and development strategy that has been underpinned with funding of $20 million over four years.

answer.para: More importantly, these export efforts have been underpinned by our government's pragmatic approach to tariff reform and our government's sound economic management of the economy, which has provided the industry with a sound economic base in the domestic circumstance from which to launch into the export marketplace. We have now announced and are going to implement taxation reform across Australia that will greatly benefit the export industries, including Australia's automotive exports. As the Treasurer has announced today, we will also be introducing legislation into the parliament later this week to improve the corporate taxation system and the capital gains tax system in Australia. With the support of the Labor Party, that will further underpin the domestic economic circumstance of Australian manufacturers so they can challenge the rest of the world.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, do you recall telling the House yesterday:

question.para: I believe the majority of cases will be shown by being backdated or by being non-binding contracts that were shown to be binding.

Minister, if backdating or non-binding contracts account for the majority of pre-budget MRI contracts, what accounts for the remainder? Of the 13 that you say today have been cleared or are expected to be cleared, have these contracts been investigated for insider knowledge?

talk.start.para: —The Health Insurance Commission have turned up no evidence at all that anyone had any inside information. What they have turned up is what I have been saying all along: that there appears to be evidence in a majority of cases—enough to warrant a reference to the DPP—and a very high degree of suspicion in other cases but not enough, and absolutely no evidence at all that anyone had any inside knowledge.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Will the minister please detail when the temporary protection visas for unlawful arrivals will come into effect?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for the question, because last week I announced a number of decisions the government had taken to deal with the very large number of unauthorised arrivals. Since I spoke on that occasion, two more boats have arrived with 36 passengers from Iraq and Afghanistan. We have been experiencing a huge increase in the level of unauthorised arrivals. They are people who are not local to our region; they have travelled halfway round the world from places like Iraq, Afghanistan and Turkey to seek protection here. In many cases they are relinquishing situations of security they are now in or passing other countries where they can properly make asylum claims in order to come to Australia.

answer.para: Just to give you some idea of the dimension of it, there are 2.5 million Afghans living in countries neighbouring Afghanistan. There are 700,000 Iraqis living in neighbouring countries—many of them people for whom we make arrangements within our special humanitarian program or within our refugee program so they can come to Australia. That is in situations in which they are judged by the UNHCR to be in urgent need of resettlement in a country like Australia. What is happening is that people who are making essentially family reunion commitments are seeking to have their relatives jump the queue over those who are more vulnerable. One person even had the audacity to ring me at my office and to ask whether his relative had yet arrived in Port Hedland. The fact is that the Port Hedland facility is full. There are 300 places at the Curtin air base which have been put in on a temporary basis. That capacity will be expanded to 400 shortly, but we are reaching the point where the numbers of people we have to detain are such that we are under enormous pressure. It is obvious that there are incentives there that are bringing people to Australia rather than their waiting, as they may have in the past, for places within a proper refugee and humanitarian program.

The temporary protection visa that I announced is to be introduced by regulation. The regulations were proclaimed this morning. This is one element of a range of measures we are working on. I welcome the in- principle support we have had from the opposition. I hope it will be maintained. I welcome the support we have had for this measure, because it is important and in the national interest. I hope it will be maintained in the way in which the opposition shadow minister has said it should on a number of occasions—that is, tough action is required and if he were in my place he would be tougher than me.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, do you recall telling the parliament yesterday:

question.para: I was told on 5 May—
that is, 1998—
by the department that we may need a supply measure. That was the first I knew about it.

Isn't it the case that these confidential minutes of the council of the College of Radiologists reveal that, prior to 5 May and as far back as 21 April, the college was actively in negotiation with the government about the need for a supply measure and what form it would take? Don't these minutes prove that you misled the parliament yesterday?

talk.start.para: —They certainly do not suggest what the honourable member says. What I have said is absolutely correct. The first time I was alerted to it was 5 May—the same day that I wrote to the Prime Minister. I have not seen the minutes that the honourable member has, but it would not surprise me at all if the College of Radiologists internally had been speculating on a supply measure. But my department officials tell me—and they were the ones conducting the negotiation—that they had not discussed that with the College of Radiologists. The College of Radiologists may have put some positions to us, but the first I knew of the supply measure was when it was put to me very late in the process, the day before I went to talk to the college itself.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the minutes of the council meetings of the College of Radiologists.

—My question is to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, what is the importance of the new Public Service legislation? In what way will the government's reforms allow Australia to build a high performance into the Public Service?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Mitchell for his question. Today is a historic day for the Australian Public Service, with the passage of the government's Public Service Bill through the Senate this morning. This legislation provides a new modern framework for the Australian Public Service which will take it into the next century. It is the biggest overhaul and reform of Commonwealth Public Service legislation in 75 years. Compared to the 1922 act, it is a short act in plain English underpinned by values and not by rules and prescriptions.

answer.para: The philosophy of this act places the onus for the management of Public Service departments squarely on the shoulders of secretaries and agency heads. The agency heads have gained all of the powers and responsibilities of employers and access to all the flexibilities under the workplace relations legislation. They will exercise similar rights, duties and powers as their counterparts in the private sector. The legislation brings employment in the Australian Public Service into line with employment in the private sector. It nevertheless recognises the special character of the Australian Public Service. The red tape has been stripped away, but parliamentary scrutiny and public accountability of the Australian Public Service has been enhanced.

At the very end of this process members will be aware that the opposition, under pressure from the Commonwealth Public Sector Union, sought to amend the legislation in an unacceptable way. The final amendment that the Labor Party inserted in the Senate would have effectively ruled out temporary employment, except when the Senate agreed to each individual circumstance. That would have made flexibility in the area of temporary and casual employment impossible within the Public Service. The government could not accept this, and I am pleased to say that the Labor Party has backed away from this amendment and we now have a bill which provides a significant new level of flexibility in relation to temporary employment. Temporaries can now be employed for up to three years to meet agency needs and can be employed indefinitely to undertake specific tasks.

Agencies now have a big job ahead of them to get themselves ready for the implementation of the new Public Service Act. I believe that they will be able to use this act to further enhance the quality of the public service offered to the people of Australia. In concluding, I would like to thank the members of the Australian Public Service, who have been waiting a very considerable time for this reform. I am pleased that we can now move into the next century with a new act with new opportunities to continue to build a world-class Public Service in Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, are you aware that at the college council meeting of 21 April Dr Dubois, who chaired the MRI task force negotiating with the government, raised his concern that MRI rebates should not only be available to existing sites? Are you also aware that at the council meeting on 29 April it was minuted:

question.para: . . . this being an election year, the Government has been generous and it would be wise for the College to act quickly to advance this issue.

Minister, is this why you sided with the radiologists against your technological advice? In the light of these extensive minutes, how can you be believed when you say that you knew nothing about the need for a supply control measure until 5 May?

talk.start.para: —I first of all have to refute part of the question. The Leader of the Opposition is suggesting I did something against technical advice. I have already mentioned in the parliament, back in February, the process by which we came to this, and I am prepared to stick by that. In fact, I can probably give you the exact Hansard reference. I was checking it earlier today. In fact, it was 11 February 1999. My answer then— and I will read it to the House, because it is still correct—was:

answer.para: My department said in Senate estimates that I made the decision—
this is the decision about the supply—

That is correct. Let me tell you the process of my making the decision. The department advised my office that there may be a problem. I asked my department for proposals that could address that problem. I discussed them with my department. I asked my department which was their preferred option and I made a decision along the lines of—in fact, identical with—the preferred option put to me by my department. So the notion you are suggesting that I somehow came over the top—
of the department—
and put something in myself is not correct.
That is in fact the advice that was put to me by the department, and I took my department's advice. So somehow suggesting that I have overruled technical advice is simply not correct.

To come back to the College of Radiologists, I am not responsible for the College of Radiologists. I would not be at all surprised if they were speculating as to what was going to happen. It would not surprise me at all that they were speculating on a supply side measure. When I had my meeting with them on 6 May, it was discussed in the most general terms at the end of the meeting, as backed up by the two statutory declarations I have tabled in the parliament and as backed up in my comments back as early as February of this year. They did raise the issue with me, so they had obviously been talking about it amongst themselves. But they did not know the exact detail—I am assured of that by my department—and they certainly did not learn it from me. If they have taken a speculative position, they need to look at that themselves. They need to look at their own internal processes to see how they stack up.

While I am on the College of Radiologists, we had earlier today a suspension of standing orders to get my reference to the Auditor. I would have been happy to give it to you if you had just asked, but I am happy to table it. The Auditor, under section 20—I understand it is under section 20—is able to inquire as widely as he wishes. I will be asking the College of Radiologists to cooperate with the Auditor. If the College of Radiologists does not cooperate with the Auditor, I expect he will comment as such when he gives his report. Finally, on the issue of generosity: yes, it was very generous. It was generous to the 100,000 Australians who were having to pay $400 to $800 each to get a scan.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I remind members of the general warning.
—It was generous to those people who had been neglected by Labor. This was a long overdue reform. It has been excellent for the Australian public.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Young Farm Leaders

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister please inform the House what the federal government is doing to assist the development of young leaders in rural and regional Australia?

—May I thank the honourable member for Longman for raising this question because it draws attention to a gathering of 130 young farm leaders who are currently in Parliament House attending the National Farmers Federation 20th Anniversary Conference of Young Farmers. The interesting thing about this 20th anniversary event is that the National Farmers Federation have chosen not just to recall their achievements over the past 20 years, even though they are considerable, but to use this year to invest in the future of farm leadership. So they have brought together, with sponsorship from the federal government and a number of other agencies, some of the young people who will be the farm leaders of the future.

answer.para: I have to say that I have been very impressed with the calibre of these people, and they give us a great deal of confidence about the capacity of rural Australia to continue to produce in a way which will benefit our nation. These young people are very important in helping to develop the sorts of policies that will be necessary to keep Australian agriculture strong and viable, but they are also important for the role that they can play at a leadership level in country communities. This government is very keen to support rural Australia, and one of the best investments we can make is in its young people, because our rural young people certainly have the capacity to contribute to building strong agriculture in this country to ensure it remains competitive and to ensure that rural Australia remains strong in the decades ahead.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Mr Speaker, I have a question for you. Are you aware that page 8409 was omitted from the proof copy of Hansard on Monday, 11 October 1999? What steps have been taken to rectify this, and how often are members' speeches, especially if they are controversial, omitted from the copies of Hansard ?

—Yes, I am aware of this omission. Such was the nature of the member for Throsby's speech that I looked it up myself. May I be forgiven for observing that I wondered if there had been divine intervention in the absence of a couple of pages. But, all frivolity aside, I should indicate to the member for Throsby that this is an extraordinarily rare occurrence. In fact, what happened on the night in question when the proofs were being printed was that the two Docutech machines that the House uses for printing the proof Hansard were running simultaneously. One of them was producing perfect copies and the other was producing copies in which the page referred to was missing.

interjection.para: As all members will be aware, the proof Hansard is available by about 9 a.m. When the absence of the speech referred to was noted, the printing office then re-ran the Hansards and made, I think, 150 copies of a reprinted edition available to all members and made 180 available around Australia to those various outlets that it was thought may have missed out.

Normally, if an error occurs, an erratum page is inserted or provided the next day. By reason of the fact that this was not merely an error but a page missed altogether, a reprint was determined to be justified. I think it is fair to say that all that could reasonably be done to cover the error was done.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—I claim to have been misrepresented in an article this morning which appeared in the Age , in remarks in a press release put out by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and then in question time by the Minister for Finance and Administration. In the article, in that press release and in the question time intervention it was alleged that I was a government official or in a meeting with government officials in which Frank Blount, prior to his taking up his appointment as CEO of Telstra, received advice that the government intended a privatisation of Telstra or that official policy tended in that direction.

speech.para: I have already denied that once in parliament, and when I denied it on that occasion it was following a conversation that I had had with Mr Blount because that rumour had been out there circulating at that point in time. I now say that I deny those allegations again, and I quote from Mr Blount supporting my position.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order—
—The finance minister is telling lies in the parliament. Let him get it straight. The finance minister is telling lies in the parliament.
—The member for Burke will withdraw the statement he just made—unconditionally.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.
—I just wish to take a point of order relating to personal explanations. The Leader of the Opposition is now debating the point and seeking to quote something to support that debate.

—I would remind members of the general warning. The Minister for Forestry and Conservation, it has been the practice of the chair to be even-handed with personal explanations, and a good deal of liberty was extended to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation yesterday. I did it in a way that I thought no-one could take offence at. No-one knows better than the Leader of the Opposition the standing orders in this place. I will hear his quote. If he advances an argument, obviously I will be obliged to sit him down.
—This is a quote taken from an interview by Phillip Satchell of Mr Frank Blount at 11.25 this morning on Adelaide 5DN:

speech.para: SATCHELL:
Was he amongst those who was saying it should?
BLOUNT:
I'm going to say that the answer to that in those meetings that you referred to, the meeting before I came, is no. I've had subsequent discussions with him—
that is me—
but that subject was not one that we brought up at the time. But . . . the answer to that is no.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The member for Jagajaga may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The Minister for Health and Aged Care misrepresented me in question time today when he said that he would have provided me with the terms of reference to the Auditor-General if I had asked. In fact, my office did ask his office for the terms of reference, and they were not provided.
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings .

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the following papers:
Employment Advocate—Annual Report 1998-99
Affirmative Action Agency—Annual Report 1998-99
Australian Industrial Relations Commission and Australian Industrial Registry—Annual Report 1998-99
Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs—Annual Report 1998-99
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation—Annual Report 1998-99
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Jagajaga proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The failure of the Minister for Health and Aged Care to follow prudent policy advice and correct procedure in making the 1998 Budget decision to extend Medicare rebates to Magnetic Resonance Imaging services.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —What we have here is a cover-up of massive proportions, and we saw the Minister for Health and Aged Care continue this cover-up today in question time, slip-sliding away, not answering the questions at every turn. This minister for health started negotiations with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists in February 1998 to extend Medicare rebates to MRI machines. The Australian Health Technology Advisory Council had recommended—and this was the point the Leader of the Opposition was making in question time—that the number of machines that existed in Australia back in 1998 in public and private locations was sufficient to meet Australia's needs. So the number of machines that we had back in February 1998 already operating in public hospitals and in the private sector were adequate to meet Australia's needs. This is a very important point in the policy debacle that is now before us. There was no need for any more machines to be brought into this country.

speech.para: Some relocation of machines was needed and it is correct that there were some problems in regional Australia. AHTAC had recognised that. In fact, the government had recognised that some of these machines needed to be moved so that access would be improved for people in the country. But we now know today that this advice, originally provided by an independent body, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee—an independent committee of the government—has been completely ignored.

The minister, in answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question today, once again tried to ignore that fact so that he is not hoist on this extraordinarily bad policy judgment. He tried to wriggle around and say that he did not ignore his department's advice, he did not ignore technical advice; that in fact he accepted the department's advice about a budget night cut-off for new contracts. But what he forgot to mention in his answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is that the department's original advice, the department's original position, was to have geographic planned control over the numbers of MRI machines. The minister now is deliberately blurring these two pieces of departmental advice. The original advice was not appreciated by the College of Radiologists. They did not want to see the extension of Medicare rebates limited only to those machines currently in operation.

If I go to the minutes of the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists of 21 April 1998 that I tabled today, those minutes say that the doctor in question commented on the `negotiations'. Remember that was the other word we had a bit of stumbling over in question time—`negotiations'. Who do we think they were negotiating with? Each other? They were negotiating with the government. He commented on the `negotiations leading to the consideration of a possible 18-month freeze on new sites' and `concerns which had been raised if MRI rebates were to be available initially only to existing sites'. So it is quite clear that the College of Radiologists had made it plain to the government that they did not like the department's preferred option, that they did not like AHTAC's original recommendation. The college go on to say that the task force—that is, the task force of the college—believes that `it is essential to get MRI onto the MBS schedule initially and then to make modifications over time'. What sort of health minister do we have who does not have any idea that these negotiations are going on?

The minutes of 29 April of the College of Radiologists talk about `being scheduled to meet with the minister next week'. This is extraordinary, given the minister apparently did not let on about anything. Of course, he made the decision; it did not come from the College of Radiologists. It says:
. . . he was scheduled—
that is, the radiologist in question—
was scheduled to meet with the Minister next week if Council—
that is, the council of radiologists—
supported the MRI proposal developed by the MRI Task Force.

What the government was negotiating about was not AHTAC's original policy proposition, not the department's original policy proposition, but the policy proposition developed by the College of Radiologists. That is what was going to be discussed at the meeting held between the minister and the College of Radiologists.

I agree about one issue with the minister and the College of Radiologists which goes along with the original recommendation of AHTAC: there was a need for better access for all patients but, of course, there was no need for extra machines. The College of Radiologists say that the objectives of the task force were to increase funding for MRI, both public and private, and that they wanted that done in a mainstream way by having a Medical Benefits Schedule item for private providers and an increase in grants for the public.
Then over on page 3 of the minutes of 29 April—this really goes to the point made by the Leader of the Opposition in question time—it says this:
Particular concerns were expressed about the Government's control of MRI supply.
So at this point we are still having concerns raised by the College of Radiologists about what the government's control measure might be. However, it goes on:
It was mentioned that, this being an election year, the Government has been generous—
past tense—
and it would be wise for the College to act quickly to advance this issue.

Of course it was not the case that the college had anything other than the MRI rebate in mind when they were talking about generosity. The minutes then said the college supported the MRI proposal and went on to say:
. . . the College cannot walk away as we will not have this opportunity again for some years.
Of course the `next years' not necessarily being election years. It then goes on—and this is very serious indeed:

. . . Council . . . empowers the President and Chairman . . . to proceed with direct negotiations, with the understanding that Council would have input into the matter of supply control. In particular, Council has reservations about any proposal that control should be by site restriction.

These are very serious matters indeed. This was reiterated in their minutes of 4 May where they again raise concerns about a possible site freeze. So here we are just before the critical meeting, and the College of Radiologists are still raising their primary concern about a possible site freeze. The minutes state again:
. the time for negotiation is over, it is the best position the College will be able to achieve in the short to medium term.

These are very serious matters which show that in fact the government was negotiating for weeks ahead of the meeting that the minister has referred to in question time about this critical issue of supply control.

It is interesting to also look at the important message that was put out by the College of Radiologists the day after the budget. Once again we have reference to that critical report that was written by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Council. It says:
The AHTAC report has formed the basis for the college proposal and fellows—
that is, fellows of the college—
should note relevant aspects of the record of interview, including the current oversupply.

This is their recognising back in May the current oversupply that existed back then and the maldistribution of MRI capacity in the community. This is the piece of advice that radiologists did not take, because the president of the college went on to say:
I would strongly urge fellows to exercise caution with regard to their proposed involvement in any new MRI ventures.
Some obviously did not take the sensible advice that was put forward to them by the president of the college at the time.

These are very serious matters indeed that the minister refers to the Auditor-General today. Of course we had a bit of trouble getting the letter to the Auditor-General that set out the nature of the inquiry that this minister has instigated not at the earliest opportunity—not the first time that problems were raised with him. That is not when we had the first Auditor-General's report. But, of course, what else could we expect from this minister.

What is interesting is the nature of the letter that the minister has written to the Auditor-General, the nature of the reference. What you would expect in the nature of a reference to the Auditor-General is an outline of the problem that the minister is asking the Auditor-General to report on. Given that the minister will be one of the people that the Auditor-General will have to call to examine his involvement in this very messy and sordid affair, what do we see in this letter to the Auditor-General? We see the argument put forward by the minister to support his side of the case. He says:

While the negotiations were of a confidential nature, it was recognised that formal confidentiality agreements for the college's negotiators would be inappropriate because of their need to consult the college membership more widely on aspects of the agreement.

That is a matter for the Auditor-General to investigate, not for the minister to put in argument in his first letter setting out the terms of reference for this essential inquiry. He goes on at the end of the first page to further justify his case:
This measure—
that is, the supply control measure—
was not discussed in the negotiations.
Once again, Minister, this is a matter for the Auditor-General to inquire into, not for you to put argument about when you are giving the Auditor-General a reference.
The piece de resistance comes at the end of the letter. He says to the Auditor-General:

As you would appreciate, there is a significant dilemma facing governments negotiating agreements such as the diagnostic imaging agreement with professional organisations. It is difficult to negotiate agreements around potentially commercially sensitive issues without revealing information that could be advantageous to some members of the group.

I read that as a confession. That confesses that what we have been putting to this minister for eight months is exactly what happened—that the information got out, people took advantage of it and they have taken this government and the taxpayers of Australia to the cleaners. Of course they had inside information. Otherwise why would they have gone out and invested $150 million of their own money? They put their own money up. Why did they put it up? Because they knew that, from the minister's own letter to the Auditor-General, the information they had received could be advantageous.

It was advantageous all right. It was extremely advantageous to a very large number of radiologists who have benefited to a very large degree as a result of this minister letting the cat out of the bag, making sure that the proper processes were not followed—the processes to make sure that the budget and the taxpayers were protected and that we did not have the outrageous scan scam that we are confronted with today.

This Auditor-General's report will be very useful when it is done, but we are still calling for a royal commission. That is the only way we are going to get to the bottom of this minister's involvement. It is the only way we can make sure that the public purse is protected because, for the last 15 months, he has been trying to cover up, to not answer questions and to make sure that this issue just goes away. It will not. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for the option to participate in this debate. The opposition makes a number of allegations, most of which we have gone over before and none of which have any substance, but I am happy to repeat and refute the allegations. I am pleased that the honourable member for Jagajaga is prepared to concede that the Auditor-General's report will be useful. I believe it will be. I have said that I am happy to cooperate in all ways with the Auditor-General.

speech.para: I assume that, were I not to do that, he would comment unfavourably on that in his report. My department can be compelled to cooperate. I cannot be compelled, but I am more than willing to give an undertaking that I, my current staff and my former staff will give him all available assistance. I will also seek similar assistance from the College of Radiologists. The reason I am prepared to do that is very simple: the procedure that we followed on this was meticulously careful because we knew it was of a commercially sensitive nature.

Speaking generally, I am pleased the opposition has decided to move back from making allegations about people not in this House who are known to me. As one gets on in this job, one sees things repeat themselves. In the past, I have not found those sorts of allegations to ever benefit anyone. I think everybody loses from them. Because the two people involved are not able to defend themselves, I feel I should defend them.

Dr Best was mentioned yesterday as arranging dinners for me. It was implied that this had something to do with him being appointed to the National Health and Medical Re search Council. It is true I appointed him to a subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, but so did the Labor Party. When Graham Richardson was health minister he did exactly the same thing. Graham Richardson appointed Dr Best to a subcommittee in 1994 for a period of three years, Dr Best carried out that job in a distinguished manner, and I reappointed him to the Strategic Research Development Committee.

Dr Best is not a radiologist. He does not have anything to do with MRI. He is a public health physician, which is about as far away from MRI as you can get. He did tell me that at one stage he did have something to do with MRI, and that was in negotiations with Neal Blewett, a former Labor Party minister. He has worked for state and federal Labor governments as well as working for state and federal Liberal governments. He is a past president of the Faculty of Public Health Physicians. He is a distinguished member of the medical profession. Before question time, Dr Best provided me with a letter that he has written to the Manager of Opposition Business. It says:
Dear Bob

I read with some surprise, bordering on disappointment, the question you directed to the Minister today concerning fundraising functions I am supposed to have organised. Let us get the record straight.
Over the past 15 years as a consultant I have worked for both Liberal and Labor Governments. I have never organised a fundraising function for Michael Wooldridge, whom I value as a friend.
Therefore the rest of your impugning my reputation behind the cloak of parliamentary privilege is irrelevant. If you were worth your salt you would at least have checked your facts.
I would therefore seek your public apology.

I table the letter. By way of explanation, I did say that I thought Dr Best had organised a dinner for me. Like most members of this place, I attend a very large number of dinners. They are a chore from time to time, but they are a part of parliamentary life. Over the last 6½ years, since I was Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I have attended literally hundreds of dinners with hundreds of people. I thought it was safe not to deny the allegation when I could not prove my position without any warning but, on checking, Dr Best has never arranged a dinner for me.

The second person whose reputation was impugned was Dr Meikle. Dr Meikle is overseas, but he was previously in the Victorian Imaging Group. I had a letter today from the Victorian Imaging Group, which states:
Dr Meikle notes some matters of fact that may be relevant to the Minister's situation:
. Dr Ron Meikle ceased work practising as a Radiologist for the Victorian Imaging Group at the end of March 1998;
. Dr Ron Meikle has not acted on a Royal Australasian College of Radiologists Committee;

. The association with Dr Jack Best and Dr Ron Meikle in relation to a fund raising dinner may be related to Dr Best's involvement with the Howard Florey Foundation and a donation of $20,000 made by Medical Imaging Australasia/Victorian Imaging Group to the Howard Florey Foundation to assist in its promotion of medical science. Dr Best and Dr Meikle attended a fund raising dinner in Adelaide at which the Minister spoke.
That was a fundraising dinner for the Howard Florey Foundation, not for the Liberal Party. There were several hundred people in the audience. The letter continues:
Dr Meikle has no record of organising any fund raising dinners for the Minister.

That is true, because he has not. He has attended a dinner, he tells me. It was a Melbourne Cup Calcutta in 1995. I think I stung him for $100. So to impugn a person's reputation with no basis in fact at all is a very serious thing. I table that letter as well.

The shadow minister went on to talk about the Victorian Imaging Group. She seems to like talking about this group because I notice that she talked about it in a debate in parliament last week. Radiology is an area where there are a lot of intraprofessional rivalries. It is a rapidly changing profession and it contains a lot of very decent and honourable people, but it is also a profession where there is much jealousy. I suggest that whoever is feeding the shadow minister information she should ignore them in the future because the information that she is getting is simply not correct. She talked yesterday about the Victorian Imaging Group having an MRI at the Monash Medical Centre. The MRI at the Monash Medical Centre is owned by the Monash Medical Centre itself. It is in a public hospital. It is not the Victorian Imaging Group's machine. The shadow minister chose to mention the Victorian Imaging Group in Hansard on 14 October 1999, saying:

I recently had cause to look at the web site of one of Victoria's larger radiology practices—the Victorian Imaging Group. The VIG boasts no fewer than 28 sites run by 250 staff under the supervision of 12 radiologists. How can the department honestly believe that, with its professional supervision rules, these are being met when 12 radiologists are split between 28 sites?

I agree that that would be pretty difficult. I checked today with the Victorian Imaging Group and, in fact, they have 23 radiologists—not 12, as she suggested—and this number has been stable over a long period of time, and they have only 18 sites at which they undertake ultrasound. So 23 radiologists are quite capable of providing supervision to 18 ultrasound sites.

I mention this not out of any point scoring but to make the point that at the moment lots of people in the radiology profession are running around with claims and counterclaims, some of them quite scurrilous and almost every one of them wrong. They are doing it because the profession has to come to grips with the fact that there is a significant minority within their profession that appear to have done the wrong thing. I am receiving letters from radiologists actually congratulating me for finally clamping down on some of the cowboys. The behaviour of some people in the profession has been quite unacceptable.

To answer the points of substance in the matter of public importance, the opposition makes much of the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee's report. I have a copy here dated October 1997. I am somehow supposed not to have followed their advice. I am puzzled by this because, for a start, on page 58 it mentions location of units and gives three general principles about location of units. The first principle `requires a sufficient population base'. This is correct. The second principle is:

. . . as MRI is only a portion of the specialist consultation and subsequent treatment, locating MRI services in settings which ensure that there is a cluster of these key specialties is appropriate for both quality and efficiency reasons.
That we have done. It continues:

Thirdly, an MRI service should be located in radiological departments or practices which offer a comprehensive range of alternative imaging modalities and procedures, such as CT scanning, ultrasound, angiography and myelography.

We have done that too. So it is hard to see where we have not taken their advice. If we go to the final recommendations on page 69, they talk very little about location of machines and are very fuzzy, so there is no advice there that we could not have particularly taken.

The recommendations on the second dot point talk about the number of units, and again the shadow minister makes much of our oversupply. But that misses the point. We have not tried to reach a desired number of scans by limiting the machines; we have done it by limiting the scans themselves. If you have a look at our tax calculations, you will see around that time public hospitals were doing about 50,000 to 60,000 scans a year. They said that we needed another 40,000 to 48,000 scans a year—this is 1997—and then over the next five years we would need another 16,000 to 24,000 scans. In other words, we needed about 124,000 scans a year. In fact, that is just about spot-on what we have funded, with 408,000 scans over a three-year period, starting low and increasing because in the last few years the types of investigations where MRI has been proved to be useful have expanded. So, far from somehow taking or not taking the advice, what we ended up doing was completely consistent with the AHTAC report, a report that we have found very useful.

There is much about us apparently not following correct procedure here. That simply could not be further from the truth. One needs to understand the nature of this investigation. It is not what you might do, say, when you are reforming the tax policy—when you bring in some outside experts to have a look at what you have done to give you some practical advice on whether or not it will work. Both sides of the House when in government have done that. This was a formal negotiation with a professional group. I remind honourable members that the government and the cabinet were aware of this. I was specifically authorised to carry out this negotiation with the College of Radiologists. This is something that is minuted in the cabinet minutes.

We were negotiating with them as a representative group. We expected them to consult their members and to tell us the views of their members. MRI was one small component of what we were doing. Essentially, we were negotiating a price and volume arrangement with radiology, and that needed the cooperation of the profession. It could not be done without the cooperation of the profession. A similar agreement had been negotiated with the Royal Australian College of Pathologists in 1996. It has contained the growth in pathology and enhanced the professional nature of the profession of pathology. It has worked so well that the college signed a second agreement earlier this year with the government.

Much has been made of this being a scam. I was actually the first to use the word, and I believe it is. If you look back in history, the last time this happened was under the Labor Party with pathology in the mid-1980s. Report 236 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into pathology was the thing that prompted pathology to change. Today pathology is a highly professional group, able to interact with government and run a proper three-year agreement. I hope that what has happened with MRI will prompt radiology to become equally professional and perhaps be the thing that makes people in that profession realise that negotiating with government can be done but needs to be done in good faith with certain probity around it.

There was nothing unexpected about us funding MRI. I have said in this House numerous times since February that there was a heavy lobbying campaign, and I had openly stated that I wanted to fund MRI. What was not known—and what was the market sensitive piece of information—was the nature of the supply control. The honourable member has provided minutes from the College of Radiologists. Again, given the internal turmoil in that body, I am not at all surprised that minutes have come out. I am happy to look at them. If I have anything to add to an answer, I will. However, I point out that I have repeatedly been given the advice from my department as late as yesterday that the first time anything came to me about a supply-side measure was 5 May.

I believe the investigations we have launched will be completely thorough. The Health Insurance Commission has powers to compel, and I have tabled information from it today that suggests that it is likely to be sending 16 cases initially to the Director of Public Prosecutions—the result of a very thorough investigation. I am happy to look back and have the auditor look at what has happened. I have no reason to believe that there will be any difficulty there whatsoever. I am looking forward because we have to decide what to do with the supply controls at the end of 18 months. I have said that we will have a further investigation to get advice from experts there. I am happy to inform the House that Professor John Blandford, the head of the Health Services Management Development Unit at Adelaide's Flinders University, is going to chair this review. I have asked him to do this as quickly as possible. Professor Blandford was formerly a commissioner of the South Australian Health Commission. I am happy to table that information for honourable members. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In his ministerial statement to the House on Monday, the Minister for Health and Aged Care finally came clean and admitted that there was indeed a scan scam. This happened after months of telling the House that there was no sudden rush for MRI contracts, clearly no insider knowledge and no improper negotiations with the minister. This minister is a real life Homer Simpson with hair. He even has the growl right. Every time he goes to the microphone, he comes out and says, `D'oh. I'm sorry. I think I may be wrong.' The minister stated to the House on Monday that, of the 111 machines notified to have been either in place or on order on 12 May 1998, 48 were ordered between 10 February—when negotiations with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists commenced—and the budget cut-off date of 12 May. What is worse is that 13 of these machines were ordered in the last two weeks before the budget.

speech.para: The Labor Party has discovered these facts very slowly. It has taken us eight months to get the minister to reveal that 48 contracts were signed between February and May 1998. Before his speech on Monday, the minister steadfastly refused to reveal any of the dates of the contracts, arguing somewhat curiously that by revealing the dates he was endangering the HIC's investigation. Now, on the HIC's own advice, he has revealed that 48 of these contracts were made during that period.

If the minister were genuinely open and accountable, he would immediately reveal to this House the specific dates and details of the 48 contracts. More importantly, he would reveal whether any of these contracts involved members of the College of Radiologists' negotiating team that were participating in discussions with the minister from February on. We demand and expect nothing less. These simple pieces of information would assist us to answer the question of whether there was insider information. But this minister is not interested in getting to the truth about this incident; he is too busy ignoring the obvious and hoping it will all go away. This is a minister who has delusions of adequacy.

The accumulation of 62 MRI units around the country took 13 years, and yet in three months Australian radiologists suddenly ordered 48 machines at a cost to them of $150 million. They knew that some of that $150 million would come out of the pockets of ordinary taxpayers as a result of the changing policy made at that budget. That was an increase of 77 per cent in three months, yet this minister expects us to believe that there was not a fix on. For eight long months he argued that there was no fix and that the Labor Party simply did not understand health. We have had question after question but no answers—just growling from this minister across the chamber.

On Monday, however, the minister was forced to acknowledge a few facts. He finally admitted to the House that there was a $150 million scam played out on the Australian taxpayer. He was forced to notify the House that the HIC was so suspicious of these contracts he would recommend to the Executive Council that a regulation be introduced to limit access to Medicare benefits to those machines already on order on 10 February, but not those ordered between February and May. The minister then explicitly stated:
This . . . will ensure that an advantage does not accrue to any person who may have taken advantage of backdating of a contract, a non-binding contract or any form of inside knowledge—
These are the minister's own words—
as a result of the negotiation process to order a machine before 12 May 1998.

His own words were `any form of inside knowledge'; that is where he has been got. Blind Freddy can see that there was inside knowledge. You cannot tell me that 52 radiologists around Australia committed contractual fraud and backdated their contracts after 12 May. Perhaps one or two did, but not all 52. That is why we need a royal commission to find out the facts. It is quite clear that the minister's answers are just not credible.

On Monday he admitted there was insider knowledge, but yesterday he backflipped and today again he decided it was all about backdating and non-binding contracts. Let us compare the minister's comments of the last three days with his previous comments on this issue. While we compare these comments, let us not forget that, several days before the budget in May 1998, the minister was warned by his own department that there may be a problem and that `we should address it'—that is, this problem—`ahead of time'.

That certainly has not occurred. Unfortunately for him, hoping major fraud will just disappear and the opposition will not notice is not his job. More unfortunate for him is that our shadow minister does know her job, and she has done it superbly. Let us not also forget that this whole scheme of MRI rebates is one of the minister's own devising. The original advice from both the department and the medical technologists was that the government should identify areas of need on a regional basis. So the minister has only himself to blame for the scam. Compare his confessions of the last three days to what he stated in the months previously. On 11 February, he said:
I have no evidence, and no evidence has been presented to me or provided by the opposition, that there was actually a rush of orders in the weeks before the budget.
It was not a rush, Minister, but a stampede. On 10 February, he said:
. . . there has been no massive blow out in MRI numbers—

That is right, Minister, no massive blow out, just a 100 per cent increase in machines. Perhaps all the radiation from these excess machines is affecting old Homer's capacity to think straight. It is another case of, `D'oh, ordered too many machines, opened my mouth too early, forgot to take notes of important negotiations'—mistake after mistake after mistake.

The minister and his colleague Senator Herron also seem to have a bizarre belief that proper minute taking of meetings and asking for declarations of pecuniary interest is unusual government behaviour. He actually said in the parliament on 28 September, again in response to the shadow minister:
I have never told my department to keep minutes or not to keep minutes, and I didn't in this case.
The next day, he said:
It is not routine or normal to take minutes of every meeting.

It might not be routine in Kennett's Victoria, but it is routine in good government and accountable government. The fact that no minutes were taken but everyone was sworn to secrecy is another example of the minister's complicity in this scam.

If there was no passing of confidential information in that meeting, why were all the participants sworn to secrecy? What would be the point of that? Did the minister say, `Don't tell anyone what we said because I'm organising a surprise birthday party for little Johnny,' or is it more likely that the line was, `Don't tell anyone what we said because I shouldn't have said it'? I think the latter is more likely. Something happened in that room in May that was secret enough that people were sworn not to repeat the discussion, but heaven forbid that the public or the opposition should ever know what happened. That would be counter to the principle of coalition accountability. The minister should learn from Jeff Kennett's mistakes, not try to emulate them.

The minister was forced, yet again, to back down when he realised that not only had his department not taken minutes but also not one of the members of the College of Radiologists had made declarations of interest. There they were negotiating with a professional organisation about Medicare rebates and it did not occur to the minister to maybe think that some of those people had a pecuniary interest, some of them may have had friends who had a pecuniary interest, in making these decisions. They were radiologists. That is their job. It is not surprising that this has occurred. Yet, when asked in the House about why they were not asked to declare any pecuniary interest, his answer then was:
If anything like that was to be declared, it should have been at the beginning of the process and not at the end.

Hear, hear, Minister! That is the whole point that we make. Dr Wooldridge's handling of this entire process demonstrates the problems coalition governments face. They simply do not understand public accountability. Remember the minister's call to Paul Harley-Green about public accountability where he called him `a rude, something else'—I am too demure to say—`nitwit loser'?

They understand about their mates and their mates' business interests, they understand about family trusts, but they do not understand public accountability. They are the handlers and keepers of the public purse. Their decisions have to be above and beyond any allegations of bias or mishandling. In government, they have to keep minutes, they have to ask for declarations of pecuniary interest and they have to stop thinking about money and political donations for one moment and start thinking about ethics. It is often too hard for them. This government is an organised hypocrisy.

talk.start.para: —My intention over the next 10 minutes is to do five things: to examine trends in service delivery and funding of diagnostics generally, to consider the model implemented by the Australian Labor Party for the delivery of these services, to look at the impact of the October 1997 report of the Australian Health Technology Advisory Council, to consider the challenge which that presented to this government and this minister and to examine the allegation of some breach of probity on the part of the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

speech.para: In relation to diagnostics, there is really a great story to tell, and the human story gets lost in the mud which is being slung from that side of the chamber to this. The key diagnostic tools available at the moment are X-ray, ultrasound, nuclear medicine, computerised axial tomography—or CAT—scans and MRI, magnetic resonance imaging. The improvements in diagnostic technologies have delivered absolutely outstanding benefits to Australian citizens and health care users.

We have gone from X-ray, which is just a single two-dimensional image, to nuclear medicine, which allows through the use of radioactive isotopes a much more precise diagnosis of problems, to CAT scanning, which allows us to build up a layered picture of a problem, to finally the Rolls-Royce of diagnostic imaging, the magnetic resonance image, which allows us to produce a three-dimensional, high definition image of a damaged piece of soft tissue. MRI has completely superseded older, more invasive, much more uncomfortable procedures for patients such as the myelogram, which required, for example, an injection of dye into the spinal chord and produced days and sometimes weeks of discomfort. All of that is now in the past, and it is no wonder that that created a huge amount of demand for the availability of the technology and a high pressure on the government to include it in the schedule of medical benefits.

The ALP's response, which was a fairly characteristic socialist response, was that the technology should only be available in public teaching hospitals, should only attract a benefit if you are in a public teaching hospital. The consequence of that for my constituents in Parramatta, whose only available local service was at the teaching hospital of Westmead, was to wait around in queues of up to five months, when many of them had a potentially fatal illness which needed rapid diagnosis. But that was the Labor response. That is Labor's commitment to patient care—only have it available in a public teaching hospital and do not worry if the poor punters, the mums and dads and kids, have to wait in line for five months for a desperately needed piece of medical intelligence which should be more widely available.

It also had damaging consequences for rural and regional citizens in Australia who could not get to those 18 public teaching hospitals overwhelmingly concentrated in the capital cities. The alternative was to spend $400 to $800 to get the procedure available through some 40 private practices. So, again, if you are wealthy, under Labor's policy, you can get access to it, but the poor, the punters and the mums and dads have to wait in line for five months.

In October 1997, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee, which is the technological source of advice to the Medical Health and Research Council, the principal advisory body to the Commonwealth government, produced a report addressing this problem which Labor policy had created. The critical thing here is the suggestion that this report is a secret piece of information which has been somehow secretly disseminated to a privileged few. This is a public document that has been on the public record since October 1997. Let me quote a couple of paragraphs from its contents:

The Commonwealth and state funding arrangements for MRI services have concentrated MRI units in tertiary hospitals. Such a policy inevitably restricts access for both doctors and patients. The resulting delay in diagnosis undoubtedly prolongs patient discomfort and/or uncertainty.
That was of course no great concern to the Australian Labor Party. It continues:

MRI may be a cost effective replacement for some conditions, but in the absence of adequate MRI supply another modality is used. MRI services should be located in settings where these key specialties are clustered. MRI services should be located in radiological departments or practices which offer a comprehensive range of alternative imaging. This would achieve economies of scale in staff and infrastructure, as well as providing the base for promoting cost-effective use of MRI via substitution.

What we have seen the minister do, contrary to the suggestion of the shadow spokesperson, is exactly what the report has recommended. The key recommendation of that report is that there is a shortage of supply of MRI diagnostic services and that the supply needs to be increased. The report also stated that the concentration of MRI services in public teaching hospitals was causing damage to patients, to the quality of care and was leading to a misuse of scarce health resources, by reference to other modalities, because MRI was not widely enough available. The minister then set about coming up with an effective policy response to that set of problems and a process by which it could be implemented that would ensure appropriate health outcomes and observe necessary probity requirements.

We are talking here about a $1 billion industry. The idea that there is some simple solution to that set of policy and process challenges, that you could wake up one morning and just issue instructions, is fanciful and demonstrates the opposition's lack of recent government experience—and long may it remain so. The cost to the Commonwealth of diagnostic imaging generally rose by 330 per cent in 10 years. It rose from $279 million in 1984-85 to $1.06 billion in 1997-98. That 330 per cent increase is reflected in the recommendation by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee that there had to be greater coordination and greater collaboration within the radiology fraternity to achieve better outcomes. Where there had been an instinctive reach for a CAT scan, for example—regardless of whether the treatment required it—in order to achieve certainty of diagnosis, that was causing a massive blow-out in funds. The minister had to ensure that that experience was not repeated with the MRI.

The idea that this could be achieved in isolation from a discussion with the Royal Australian College of Radiologists is, again, fanciful. The only way that a proper, important, necessary policy outcome could be achieved was to have a discussion with the people who were delivering the services. So rightly, properly and completely appropriately, the minister authorised his department in February of last year to enter into what turned out to be a 10-week discussion on how the delivery of services could ensure that Australian people who need to access these services get it at a cost which is affordable to them and at the same time sustainable in terms of ongoing, Commonwealth budget outlays. That was the purpose of that 10-week discussion.

The minister rightly points out that there was an expectation in the market that the government would make a supply measure. That expectation was fuelled by the explicit recommendation of the government's own expert advisory body that, in the absence of adequate MRI supply, other modalities are used. Clearly, there was going to be a move to increase the allocation to MRI. The question was how that should best be achieved in a manner which did not involve some breach of probity requirements.

What then happened was that the minister, on the night of the budget, on 12 May last year, announced that there would be an allocation of funding, that there would be 400,000 images funded over the next three years but that you could only get a medical benefit for that funding if the machine was in service or subject to a binding legal contract on the night of the budget. That was the minister's chosen instrument to ensure there was not abuse and commercial opportunism on the part of the profession. As it turns out, it was an imperfect instrument. That may well be an outcome of the Auditor-General's inquiry.

It may be that we should have said that only machines that were in ships en route to Australia will attract the rebate. In that sense, it was an imperfect response but, nonetheless, it was, I think—and I think any reasonable person looking at it would also think so—a natural and practical response to ensure that there was not abuse of the benefit. Since that time, the government has received 52 claims for access to the benefit on the basis that those 52 machines satisfied the minister's budget night criteria.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The discussion has concluded.
—On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 11th report of the committee for 1999 relating to the refurbishment of 4 Treasury Place, Melbourne.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The report which I have just tabled concerns the proposed refurbishment of 4 Treasury Place in Melbourne. The building at 4 Treasury Place is a Commonwealth owned building located on the corner of Treasury Place and Lansdowne Street, Melbourne. It fronts the historic Treasury Gardens to the south and Fitzroy Gardens to the east. The building is part of Melbourne's Treasury Reserve Heritage Precinct which comprises a group of public buildings dating from 1858 which are of national significance in their own right. It was the first purpose-built federal building and was designed by the Commonwealth architect, John Smith Murdoch, who is publicly best known as the designer of the provisional Parliament House in Canberra.

speech.para: The building at 4 Treasury Place was constructed in two stages between 1911 and 1913. Construction materials used in the building are also significant. It was one of the first reinforced concrete framed buildings constructed in Melbourne. It has brick walls finished with stucco externally and plaster internally. The original pitched rooves are clad with slate. The building is also notable for its association with the offices of the Prime Minister and the Governor-General, who have been occupants of the offices in the building since 1912. Accordingly, both because of its historic role during the early years of Federation and its location in the Treasury precinct, it is considered by heritage authorities to be one of the most significant heritage properties listed on the Register of the National Estate.

The building has been used continuously for ministerial and parliamentary office accommodation since 1913. It currently provides offices and cabinet room accommodation for Victorian based federal parliamentary tenants. At present, there are six ministers and a parliamentary secretary accommodated in the building. There is also accommodation for visiting ministers, including the Prime Minister, the current Governor-General and two former Governors-General and some departmental staff.

The extent of the proposed refurbishment includes repair of the render work and application of new finishes, demolition of the non-original fourth floor additions, restoration of the slate roofs, replacement of all building services and refurbishment of amenities throughout the building. The aim of the refurbishment is to restore and protect this valuable heritage asset while providing the building tenants with an efficient and safe working environment with reduced building operational costs. The level of disruption associated with the proposed building works necessitates the relocation of tenants to alternative accommodation for the duration of the refurbishment works. The proposed refurbishment works are expected to take about 14 months and the official opening of the refurbished building will form an important part of the centenary of Federation celebrations in Melbourne early in the year 2001. When referred to the committee, the estimated cost of the proposed work was $15.8 million. During the committee's inquiry the cost estimate was increased by $2 million. The proposed refurbishment is now estimated to cost $17.8 million.

The committee's report recommends that the refurbishment should proceed and the committee has concluded that, whilst the building appears structurally sound, there is a need to refurbish the interior and exterior. Internally, the building's finishes and services are showing signs of disrepair and have reached the end of their economic life. Externally, the building requires extensive restoration, the removal of extensions, and roof repairs. The proposed internal and external works are extensive and can be justified to preserve the building and to provide office accommodation of a suitable standard. Occupation of the building during the refurbish ment period is impractical, given the extensive nature of the work to be undertaken. Suitable temporary accommodation for existing tenants has been located at Casselden Place on the corner of Lonsdale and Spring streets. The cost of this accommodation is included in the project budget.

The proposal includes refurbishment of the basement, which contains the first Treasury vault. It is planned to lease the basement as a resource or interpretation centre. The committee noted the proposed design of emergency evacuation exits from the basement. The committee has concluded and recommended that the building certifiers have confirmed that emergency egress from the basement will be the subject of a dispensation from the Building Code of Australia. However, the committee believes that the provision for emergency evacuation of basement occupants should be accorded the highest priority and that the suitability of the basement as a public resource or interpretation centre should be investigated further. The views of the Melbourne metropolitan fire brigades should be sought before final plans are developed for the basement.

The internal refurbishment of the building services and systems will be extensive. The committee concluded that the scope and design of the building services and systems are appropriate for the operation of the building, subject to basement emergency evacuation requirements being satisfactorily addressed. The building is listed on the Register of the National Estate administered by the Australian Heritage Commission, which raised a number of concerns with the committee.
