The committee shares these concerns and has therefore requested that it be provided with continuing advice and information about ongoing discussions with the Department of Finance and Administration and the commission to ensure that all options are properly explored to maintain the heritage aspect of the building.

In conclusion, the recommendations in the report have been unanimously endorsed by the committee, except for the removal of a lovely stand of pine trees on the eastern side of the building. It would be my personal preference to try to retain these trees as a very important link to the historical landscape design of the area, but I was a lonely voice on the committee on this. The reason given for the removal of these trees was the birds that nest in there. Of course, they foul the building.

It is a sad indictment on humanity today that we want to sanitise the world. We have kicked the roosters out of the backyard, and I heard the other day that some Queenslanders want to shoot the crows because they make too much noise. Now we want to evacuate the birds out of their nesting place at 4 Treasury Place. My preference would be to retain those trees as an important part of the historical landscape design. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit I present the following committee report entitled Report 371—Aviation security; costing of services; planning of aged care—Review of Auditor-General's reports 1998-99—First half .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Report 371 informs the parliament of the committee's examination of the Auditor-General's reports on aviation security, the costing of services, and the planning of aged care services. The committee held a public hearing in May this year to discuss these issues with the relevant Commonwealth agencies. I will briefly discuss each issue in turn.

speech.para: The audit report on aviation security noted that the department had established a regulatory regime which ensured Australia's compliance with international standards. However, the report also identified areas where Australia's aviation security regime could be strengthened. The JCPAA focused on risk management practices and auditing and compliance procedures. It is vital that security procedures address the danger presented by criminal behaviour at airports. Currently, the focus is on politically motivated violence, but criminal activity is actually more of a prob lem. Our report recommends that security arrangements be reviewed by relevant Commonwealth agencies so as to maximise the effectiveness of police forces and airport authorities in combating crime.

The committee also examined Audit Report No. 19, into the planning of aged care. The quality and availability of aged care services is a very important issue for many Australian families. It is critical that the Commonwealth plan effectively to provide these services where they will be most needed. This is why the JCPAA has recommended that the input of local communities be harnessed when planning is undertaken. Local communities, particularly local councils, are uniquely qualified to advise the Commonwealth of their future needs in this area. Currently, state offices of the Department of Health and Aged Care can choose whether to consult local communities. The JCPAA believes that this approach is inadequate. We have recommended that local council input become an integral component of the planning process.

Audit Report No. 21 reviewed the costing of services in Commonwealth agencies. With the adoption of accrual budgeting and the increasingly contestable environment in which agencies operate, it is vital that Commonwealth services are costed appropriately. The audit report found that there was scope for substantial improvement. Indeed, committee members are concerned that costing systems are not sophisticated enough for the new public sector environment.

The JCPAA has recommended that the Department of Finance and Administration actively facilitate the development of appropriate costing methodologies. We support the contention that each agency should prepare a methodology that is suitable for its business needs. However, in the interests of both quality and consistency, we also encourage the Department of Finance and Administration to provide a suitable level of assistance.

I conclude by thanking on behalf of the committee those people who contributed their time and expertise to the committee's review hearings. I am also indebted to my colleagues on the committee who have dedicated much time and effort to reviewing these Auditor- General's reports. As well, I would like to thank the members of the secretariat who were involved in the inquiry: Dr Margot Kerley, the committee secretary; Ms Rose Verspaandonk; Ms Maureen Chan; Ms Tiana Gray; and Ms Maria Pappas. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The aspect of the JCPAA report that I wish to focus on is aviation security. This is going to be an increasingly important issue over the next couple of years. There is no doubt that considerable resources are being expended in dealing with the possibility of terrorist activity around the Olympics, and other politically motivated violence. By way of more relevant local interest, I am more concerned in the general case about deficiencies in dealing with criminal related activities at Australian airports. There have been some significant changes in jurisdiction over the past few years. The actual airside security at domestic airport terminals is conducted in almost all cases by Australian Protective Services officers and at Canberra airport by the Australian Federal Police. Most criminal activity that takes place at airports is more likely to be of interest to state police forces and there is a significant need for an improvement in the coordination between state police forces in their dealings with Australian Protective Services, in the case of most airports, and with Australian Federal Police with respect to Canberra airport.

speech.para: There are also issues relating to significant issues relating to criminal activity that passes from one jurisdiction into another. There was one notable incident earlier this year that involved the member for Bonython and me where there was a miscommunication between police in South Australia and the Australian Federal Police in Canberra—which resulted in some embarrassment ultimately for both police forces, I think. There was some focus on this in the inquiry to which I am referring. I was very pleased that the committee has seen fit to make a couple of recommendations to the government which I hope will be taken up with some expedition, namely:

2.27 The Committee recommends that the Department of Transport and Regional Services and the Attorney-General's Department review arrangements for cooperation between airport authorities and police forces in dealing with criminal activity at airports.

The Committee recommends the Department of Transport and Regional Services review passenger and hand luggage screening, including: the training, capability and responsibilities of operators; and the effectiveness of response by relevant authorities (Federal Police or Protective Services officers) in the event of contraband being detected, or other critical events occurring during screening procedures.
I hope that the government will take up these matters with a degree of thoroughness which it has not heretofore employed.

para.inline: Person becoming 85% holder to give notice to company

para.inline: Person continuing to be 85% holder to give notice to company

subdebate.1.para: (4) A person who:

para.inline: 665E Notice by company to other members

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 is part of the government's corporate law economic reform program. The objective of the program is to provide efficiency in the Australian economy, while facilitating market integrity and providing appropriate investor protection mechanisms.

The reforms contained in the bill mark a significant change in the regulation of fundraising, takeovers, accounting standards and directors' duties under the Corporations Law. The reforms modernise the regulation of business in Australia and will ensure that Australia's corporate laws meet the challenges of the present and future market in a forward thinking, responsible and innovative way. In addition, the reforms contained in the bill are integral to the government's broader objective of boosting Australia's international competitiveness and building Australia as a centre for global financial services. The reforms send a clear message to the business community that this government is serious about reform and serious about making Australia a leading financial centre.

I am very pleased that the bill is now in its final stages of passing through this parliament. A number of amendments were made to the bill in the Senate. The government is a little disappointed that some of these amendments have been made, particularly in light of the extensive program of public consultation and discussion which was a hallmark of the development of these reforms. Nevertheless, the central reforms proposed by the bill are largely intact. Whilst the government would have preferred that the bill not be amended, it believes it is preferable to pass the bill as amended by the Senate rather than delay the implementation of these valuable reforms any further.

I will now turn to the details of the amendments. The Senate amendments include a number of amendments which address the recommendations of the report into the bill by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. These amendments will include the implementation of almost all of the recommendations of the majority report and a number of the recommendations contained in the supplementary report. The committee's recommendation that rollover relief from capital gains tax be provided in relation to turnovers and compulsory acquisition was not implemented. Instead, that recommendation is being dealt with in the context of the review of business taxation where it has been recommended that, subject to certain conditions, capital gains tax rollover relief should be allowed for scrip for scrip transactions allowing takeovers. The government has accepted that recommendation.

The government also took the opportunity to make additional amendments to the CLERP Bill in the Senate which will facilitate the effective operation of the Corporations and Securities Panel. The amendments are in keeping with the government's previously stated policy objectives of making the panel the primary forum for the speedy resolution of takeover disputes during the takeover bid period. For example, the amendments will introduce an internal appeal process within the panel. As the panel is to become the sole forum for resolving takeover disputes, it is appropriate that an appeal process is available to any party who is not satisfied with a panel decision.

The amendments will also give the panel a rule making power, enabling it to make rules which would apply in addition to the takeover provisions. The rules will be subject to ministerial disallowance. The rules must not be inconsistent, obviously, with the Corporations Law or its regulations. The government also took the opportunity to make a number of minor technical amendments to the CLERP Bill in the Senate.

The bill was subject to a number of amendments by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I must say that I am disappointed at the Labor Party's continued opposition to the CLERP reforms which have, by and large, been very well received with almost unqualified support from the business and investor communities. On the other hand, the Democrats were very constructive in the discussions and in the debate. I reiterate my thanks to Senator Murray for his constructive role in this process.

The government's position has always been that the bill represented a balanced package of reforms. We were therefore very reluctant to see amendments to the bill without the benefit of consultation. However, we considered that the bill contains reforms which both the business and investor communities have been waiting for since the plan was first flagged in 1996. (Extension of time granted) Therefore, we accepted that it would be better to accept the bill in its amended fashion rather than pulling the bill totally.

The Democrats' reforms to the compulsory acquisition provisions will require the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to nominate experts to be used in valuing securities and will require a company to notify its shareholders when a person is reaching a position where they may become a 90 per cent holder capable of compulsorily acquiring the remaining securities. Whilst the government considers that these changes are unnecessary, it is pleased to see that compulsory acquisition reforms come to fruition, particularly in light of the very extensive consulta tion process which accompanied the development of these provisions. Similarly, Democrat amendments to the sophisticated investor exemption in the fundraising provisions and to the accounting standards provisions while considered unnecessary by the government will not significantly alter the basic thrust of the reforms in these areas.

One final point I would emphasise is that the removal of the mandatory bid rule from the takeover provisions of the bill by the Democrats and the Labor Party is deeply disappointing. Neither the Democrats nor the Labor Party has been able to convince the government that the mandatory bid rule does not deliver significant benefits to investors and to the market as a whole. The mandatory bid rule would have provided an additional avenue for takeover activity in Australia. It was subject to a number of safeguards designed to ensure that all target companies shareholders had an opportunity to sell their shares at a fair price and to benefit from the control premium that a bidder places on the securities. The mandatory bid was to be an additional means of ensuring that Australia has a competitive market for corporate control. A competitive market for corporate control places pressure on managers of all corporations to perform at the highest standards, thus benefiting all shareholders. The government will be pursuing the implementation of the mandatory bid proposal, and I will be referring it to the parliamentary joint committee for further consideration.

Finally, this bill was the result of an extended period of consultation, and there are a number of people I would like to thank. Firstly, I would like to thank the Treasurer, Peter Costello, who set down in 1996 the guidelines for the development of the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program and who as shadow minister for corporate law had a significant hand in a lot of the policy issues and developments that are the background to this bill. This is as much his bill as anyone else's, and I commend him for it. Similarly, I commend Senator Ian Campbell in the other place for his vast amount of work in developing this bill. He conducted the consultations right around Australia. I congratulate him for all his efforts and thank him for guiding this bill through the other place.

I would also like to thank the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities and, in particular, Senator Grant Chapman, the chair of that committee. The committee took a very constructive approach to this bill. I would also like to thank the members of the Business Regulation Advisory Group, which is chaired by Catherine Walter and includes Peter Barnett, Leigh Hall, Rohan Jeffs, Jeffrey Lucy, John Murray, Robert Nottle, Malcolm Starr and my friend Les Taylor.

Similarly, I would like to thank the Treasury officers who have put in an extended amount of work in this area. Jim Murphy, with Senator Ian Campbell, travelled Australia on the consultations and, whilst no longer in Treasury, made a substantial contribution, as did Jennifer Wells, who has gone on to greener pastures after being my DLO for some period of time. I would like to thank the current unit—Michael Willcock, Veronique Ingram, Phillip Lynch, Emma Armson, Sandra Patch, Les Pascoe—and the other members of the Financial Markets Division and the Corporate Governance and Accounting Policy Division in Treasury. Finally, I would like to particularly thank Kersten Wijeywardena from my office, who has done an absolutely outstanding job during this very extensive and very draining debate. It gives me enormous pleasure to commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, both yesterday in question time and again in introducing these amendments, accused the opposition of opposing the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 . Yesterday in question time he said:

speech.para: It defies logic that the Labor Party would choose to oppose this bill and the principles behind it at every point. Every political bone in your body would make you wonder why the Labor Party would oppose it.

Frankly, he was misleading the House because the facts are that we did not oppose the second reading or the third reading here, we did not oppose the second reading or the third reading in the Senate and we will not be opposing the bill going through now. So the minister has been regrettably misleading the parliament in relation to this.

We have moved amendments to this bill because it needs fixing. The bill does little for shareholders—in fact, it subverts the rights of shareholders, particularly minority and mum and dad shareholders. The opposition assessed this bill critically because that is our job. We moved amendments to it because it is skewed too much in favour of certain vested interests at the cost of many other people in this community. When we considered the bill, we considered a number of very important and critical questions: do the propositions encourage managers to be accountable to shareholders through consultation and disclosure in a timely manner? Do the propositions help define the role of the board of directors as active participants in the governance of the corporation? Do the propositions help define shareholders' rights and treat all shareholders of the same class equally?

Unfortunately, this bill fails to satisfy these questions. Yesterday in question time the minister wanted to quote the Australian Financial Review as saying that this was good stuff and that, if the government were serious about making Australia a global financial markets player, some of these things needed to happen. The minister was keen to quote the Australian Financial Review in relation to that; I do not know whether he was so keen to quote the Australian Financial Review when it reported how the minister was going with his idea of Australia becoming the region's chief financial centre. Hans van Leeuwen from the Australian Financial Review reported back on Friday, 8 October that the minister's strategy essentially involves Mr Hockey sitting down to a lot of lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers. No-one denies, Minister, that you have been having the lunches, but we think spending money on lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers is perhaps not the best way to spend the $7 million allocated in last May's federal budget.

This government has said that it wants to make Australia the biggest shareholder nation on earth, but it is not prepared to secure or protect the rights of mum and dad shareholders. Indeed, Telstra shareholders ought to be watchful of their company directors. This bill will make them immune from negligence liability. Telstra shareholders and other shareholders will have little recourse should company directors lose or mismanage their money.

The opposition at least succeeded in the Senate in correcting some aspects of this bill to allow some measure of accountability. But the issue of the directors' duties business judgment rule—about which we are very concerned—is nevertheless only one of a number of faults in this bill. Other issues of concern that the opposition has raised here and in the Senate concern the mandatory bid rule, compulsory acquisition and accounting standards.

So, yes, we have moved amendments to this bill. We do not apologise in the slightest for doing that. Our amendments have improved the overall balance of the bill, and the minister ought to be grateful instead of complaining about this. Despite what the government might have said about the opposition simply being contrary in relation to the bill, it should look again at how much of this bill we did support. We supported all of the fundraising provision, except for a one-line provision, we supported the whole proposal on the takeover panel, and there are many other provisions which we did not touch.

I turn specifically to the directors' duties business judgment rule. The bill includes a provision called the business judgment rule which would give company directors what is described as a safe harbour from negligence liability. This so-called initiative from the government is supposed to encourage directors to take more risks in their activities. (Extension of time granted) It will encourage directors to take more risks in their activities because external scrutiny will be restricted. It will encourage directors to be careless, reckless and deceitful, to the detriment of the company and its shareholders.

The government argues that there is currently a level of uncertainty in case law about directors' liability and responsibility, particularly in terms of their duty of care and diligence, that has constrained them from working to the best of their abilities. The opposition strongly disagrees. I think few could dispute the fact that court judgments have been fair and consistent. The courts have, in the main, exercised restraint. They have avoided second-guessing directors' decisions. I therefore believe the government's attempts in this regard will not add value and will not deliver clarity but rather will add complexity to the current arrangement. Moreover, far from clarifying matters, these proposals on directors' duties represent a Trojan Horse for watering down directors' standards of responsibility.

These proposals encourage directors to be careless, reckless and deceitful to the detriment of the company and its shareholders. They are totally irresponsible proposals designed purely to placate vested interests. The majority of Australian company directors would not benefit from these proposals. On the contrary, they will suffer. Those who would benefit are the directors who lack skills, are irresponsible or are dishonest. The government is sending the wrong message to directors and to the market. Shareholder interests and good corporate governance have been forgotten in the process.

The opposition is generally supportive of the principle of statutory derivative action, but the process put forward by the government is unclear and we expect that exercising statutory derivative action will remain confusing. We therefore believe that this provision should also be open to the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, ASIC, to take action on behalf of shareholders. Labor has moved such an amendment, but the government has not been prepared to accept it. Consequently, the statutory derivative action rule proposed by the government is likely to remain onerous for individual investors to utilise. It is doubtful whether many shareholders will be able to meet the onerous requirement of applying for leave from the court to take action.

I think it will be interesting to see, in the months and years ahead, whether shareholders or investors really do take advantage of the statutory derivative action in the way in which the government has put it forward or whether it becomes something of a dead letter. The ineligibility of ASIC from being able to apply for leave from the court is difficult for us to understand or support. As the government-created consumer protector, ASIC should surely have the power to act under these provisions. Labor accepts that it would be appropriate for the right to take a statutory derivative action to be extended to ASIC because small shareholders may not have the resources to take such action. The opposition's amendments are designed to ensure that this can occur.

While the government claims that its proposal to allow shareholders to take a statutory derivative action will balance the so-called safe harbour provisions, it is clear that its proposal does not balance the ledger at all. Labor's amendment will go some way towards achieving appropriate rights for shareholders. With the government trumpeting its support for Australia as a shareholding nation, I would have thought that it would have supported a regime that provides an appropriate level of protection for thousands of new and mostly, by definition, inexperienced shareholders who have entered the market. I think it is regrettable that the flip side of saying that you want to have a shareholding democracy—and the Prime Minister talks about us being the world's greatest share owning democracy—is that you need proper consumer protection measures. We are concerned that the government's proposals do not provide this and do not balance the ledger.

On the mandatory bid rule, which the minister made some reference to in his introduction, the provision to allow for easier takeovers by veiling the process from the wider market should not be there. We are pleased that the Senate has accepted Labor's amendments and that the government is now doing this as well. The tax concession on scrip for scrip takeovers is the solution that the government is really looking for, and we will have that. There is no need for the mandatory bid rule as the cost to market transparency and integrity are too great. The opposition understands the arguments for the mandatory bid proposal, but we believe that the arguments against it clearly outweigh the arguments for it. We acknowledge that there are economic efficiency considerations or arguments for increasing takeover activity—or at least the threat or prospect of it—but it comes at a cost that is potentially more than the opposition is willing to risk. (Extension of time granted) Those costs will come from the subversion of good corporate governance principles such as transparency, accountability and equity.

No longer will there be an appropriate competitive regime for corporate control and, despite the proposed safeguards, shareholders will not get a better price than that obtained from an auction process. We move to omit the mandatory bid rule so as to ensure that transparency in the market is maintained. We moved our amendments because we strongly questioned the need for such a new rule. We believe that it would have led to significant disadvantages and few benefits. On the other hand, the government's position was one which would have given takeover bidders control of a target company before the market had been advised of the takeover bid. The government wished to encourage bidders to try to lock up key blocks of shares before launching their takeover bid. The result of such a proposal was that it could grant the bidder effective control of a target company before they had to reveal their intentions. That would give some takeover bidders a mechanism to discourage competitors emerging in the takeover process. Under such an arrangement, competitive bidders and directors of target companies would have less time to appropriately respond to takeover bids. Discovery of fair prices would also be restricted as there would no longer be an auction process.

The mandatory bid rule would go against the Eggleston principles—the principles on which the proposed takeover panel would consider and make judgment on takeover disputes. The Eggleston principles require that, first, shareholders of a takeover target company know the identity of any person who proposes to acquire a substantial interest in the company; second, the target shareholders and directors have sufficient time to consider the offer; third, sufficient material is provided to them to make proper assessment of the offer; and, fourth, all shareholders have equal opportunity to participate in the benefits of the takeover offer. The mandatory bid rule breaks these principles.

The government is effectively sacrificing a great deal in terms of good corporate governance practices for potentially little gain in takeover activity. As I said before, the opposition is willing to support the capital gains tax concession on scrip for scrip takeovers. This, more than the mandatory bid rule, will raise takeover levels. If the new tax arrangement does not deliver, then we could reconsider our position on the mandatory bid rule. But the arguments being put forward on the mandatory bid rule simply do not wash with the opposition. We remain concerned that such a rule would lower the share price of takeover targets and simply allow takeover bidders to pay a lower price.

The government is proposing to extend the compulsory acquisition provisions to allow a 90 per cent majority shareholder in a company to compulsorily acquire the remaining 10 per cent share at any time. All that would be required is a notice of acquisition accompanied by an independent expert's report qualifying the value of the remaining securities. The government claims that the proposition is designed to remove so-called greenmailers, but this concern over greenmailers is dubious. Simply, this proposal is something that is about scrapping the rights of minority shareholders. Some people have even described it as allowing a legal means to expropriate another person's property. It is fascinating that the conservative side of politics are interested in this and are into expropriating property.
Mr Ted Rofe from the Australian Shareholders Association stated as much in a submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities. He stated:

Compulsory acquisition involves the expropriation of the property of the shareholders whose shares are to be acquired. Minority shareholders in a partly-owned group of companies are in a particularly vulnerable position. It is therefore essential that any compulsory acquisition of their shares can be seen to be fair to both the majority and minority shareholders. As the courts have pointed out on a number of occasions, fairness in this context involves both fair dealing and a fair price. The proposed new compulsory acquisition power in its present form tips the scales too much in favour of the majority shareholders.

Since the government has been encouraging more and more mum and dad shareholders, it is indeed surprising that it is not making the appropriate efforts to ensure that the rights of shareholders, particularly minority shareholders, are protected. As more and more Australians become shareholders, change to compulsory acquisition becomes a significant concern.

A survey by the Australian Stock Exchange earlier this year estimated that 4.4 million Australians now hold shares directly. That is about 32 per cent of the population. The majority are likely to be inexperienced first-time shareholders who may not be able to best represent their own interests. (Extension of time granted) The government says that it wants to make Australia a nation of shareholders, but if mum and dad investors get in the way of the interests of big business then the government wants those mum and dad shareholders to move aside or be done over.

talk.start.para: —Yes.
—Indeed. It is simply not good enough.

speech.para: Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is true. With little doubt, the extension of the compulsory acquisition rule was conceived and designed to placate vested interests. There is absolutely no need for it. I understand that the ASA is already receiving reports of shareholders being threatened that their shares will be expropriated as soon as this bill becomes law.

speech.para: The CLERP Bill also seeks to revamp the takeover panel based on the UK model. While we are supportive of the principle that a body could act in arbitration to settle takeover disputes as an alternative to the courts, we have some doubts about our ability to emulate the success of the UK's panel. Australia has a somewhat different business culture from that of Britain. Based on evidence provided to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, British corporations are less adversarial and less inclined to pursue litigation compared with their Australian counterparts. Because of these concerns, the opposition is supporting the government's amendments to its own bill on the takeover panel. We hope that these changes will boost the relevance and authority of the takeover panel in considering debates arising during a takeover process.

I turn now to fundraising. Fundraising provisions are among the more positive aspects of this bill and are primarily designed to reduce the costs involved with capital raising, especially by small and medium sized enterprises. To reduce the costs of capital raising, the government has targeted costs tied up with the preparation and lodging of prospectuses. The opposition is supportive of all but one of the proposals.

We agree, for instance, with a proposal that a disclosure document would not be required if a person made an unlimited number of personal offers of securities that resulted in securities being issued to 20 or fewer persons in a rolling one-year period with no more than $2 million being raised. However, it would be irresponsible for us to agree with a proposal which would allow licensed securities dealers to judge who would be defined as `sophisticated investors'—that is to say, investors not requiring access to prospectus or disclosure documents—and allow such investors to invest less than $500,000.

This provision is inconsistent with other criteria which define a sophisticated investor as having the appropriate resources to undertake their own investigation of a venture. We are opposed to the authority to be granted to licensed securities dealers because it may be abused, brought on by commission pressures. The Democrats and the government have allowed licensed securities dealers to declare a person a sophisticated investor and get them to sign a piece of paper to this effect. In those circumstances, there would be no need to provide a prospectus.

If the licensed securities dealers define mum and dad investors as `sophisticated', they give up their rights to receive appropriate disclosure documents. People are arguing that sanctions would exist to deter licensed securities dealers from misbehaving. Such measures tend to address events after the fact. Once mum and dad investors lose their money, they usually lose it for good. We hope that the government sees merit in this argument and in the fact that there is a potential behavioural shift involved with the proposal. Entrepreneurs can now raise as much money as they wish through a licensed securities dealer, without having to issue a prospectus; therefore, expect an increase in capital raising through this process and an increase in the number of licensed securities dealers. This proposal completely undermines the current regime, which requires investors to be fully informed of any venture which they put money into.

Regarding accounting standards, the opposition is extremely disappointed that the government cannot comprehend the dangers of having the proposed Financial Reporting Council control the agenda of the Australian Accounting Standards Board. The bill gives powers to the Financial Reporting Council, FRC, to appoint the members of the Australian Accounting Standards Board and to approve its priorities, business plan, budget and staffing arrangements. These powers are about more than just oversighting the AASB activities. The FRC will effectively be running AASB.

With this bill the government demonstrates a lack of appreciation for the role that the AASB has played to date in ensuring that Australia has high standards of financial reporting and corporate disclosure which have engendered investor confidence and market integrity. (Extension of time granted) The opposition has endeavoured to move amendments to the bill to ensure that the AASB's independence is not compromised and that the FRC does not become just another layer of bureaucracy in the development of accounting standards. Unfortunately, the government failed to accept the amendments.

We are concerned by the proposal to introduce formal cost benefit analysis by the AASB for every accounting standard proposed. There are difficulties involved with such a proposition for the standard setter in terms of the compliance costs as well as the technical aspects of determining the indirect costs and benefits to the wider community or economy of a proposed standard.

Furthermore, it does not give appropriate regard to the potential conflict that may arise from the fact that, while most of the costs involved with meeting accounting standards are shouldered by the preparers, significant benefits accrue to users and to the wider community. There is also a risk that this proposition would simply give businesses with purely short-term perspective some form of ammunition to discredit a standard when the longer term benefits may be quite significant. It is astounding that the government cannot acknowledge the dangers of this proposal and could not accept the opposition's amendment in this regard.
Tom Ravlic in the Age today addresses this very problem and quotes Mr Wayne Lonergan, the President of the Securities Institute of Australia. The article states:
. . . the failure to clarify the FRC's powers had the potential to jeopardise the integrity of Australia's capital market.

He said a proposed amendment pushed by the Federal Opposition would have ensured the board remained independent and the role of the FRC would have been to advise and monitor, rather than approve the AASB's agenda.
"The amendments proposed in particular by the Labor Party were in accordance with submissions made by leading industry bodies," Mr Lonergan said.

In conclusion, I am glad that the government saw value in Labor's redrafting of part of the accounting standards provisions, particularly that relating to international harmonisation. Australia should adopt only those accounting standards which have been extensively debated both domestically and internationally and which have demonstrated integrity. Australia should also play an active role in the development of accounting standards for worldwide use. Labor has previously been—we have managed investments and other pieces of legislation—and continues to be supportive of sensible corporate law reform, and we will be continuing to support this legislation.

talk.start.para: —I do want to respond to some of the comments made by the shadow Assistant Treasurer. Firstly, he said that I had misled the House about the Labor Party's opposition to the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 . I did nothing of the sort. The fundamental point is that the Labor Party, in their true tradition and true to form, moved a raft of amendments which would have absolutely gutted the corporate law reform bill before the House.

speech.para: It is an old trick of the Labor Party's. They opposed the GST package at the last election but, when the personal income tax cuts dealing with the GST came through the House, they did not vote against it, even though it was a package and it was being paid for out of the restructuring process associated with the GST. I do not accept the proposition put forward by the shadow Assistant Treasurer in relation to this matter.

Secondly, the shadow Assistant Treasurer made some comments to me about Australia as a global financial centre and said that it involved lots of lunches, dinners and various other things as part of the marketing. That was reported in an article written by Hans van Leeuwen in the Australian Financial Review on 8 October. I so happen to have a copy of a letter sent by a member of the parliamentary Labor Party to the Editor of the Australian Financial Review, who refused to print the letter. I propose to read out parts of the letter so as not to disclose who wrote it and then seek leave to table the letter, and I wonder how the shadow Assistant Treasurer will react. The letter begins:
Dear Sir

The only sensible points in Hans van Leeuwen's article . . . on the Australian and New South Wales bid to become a global financial centre were the remarks made by the Minister for Financial Services, Joe Hockey.
Hans van Leeuwen's own comments were facile and stupid and in keeping with the undergraduate cynicism that mars much of what passes for journalism in this country.
Australia's bid to be a major financial centre is based on a good and improving set of fundamentals.

But there is little point in having a good product unless you get out and sell it, even if that does involve people like the Prime Minister, . . . Joe Hockey . . . "sitting down to a lot of lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers".
He goes on to say:
Incidentally, where is this "continuing questioning of the Federal Government's regional financial centre strategy" that Mr van Leeuwen talks about. As far as I can see it's only coming from him.

It is no wonder that the Editor of the Australian Financial Review did not want to print the letter. I remind the House that this letter was drafted by a member of the parliamentary Labor Party. I now seek leave to table the letter.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. If the minister wishes to be malevolent and malicious, be it on his own head. He does not require leave.

—My understanding of the standing orders is that, apart from question time and when a ministerial statement is being made, leave in fact is required by a minister. So I repeat the question: is leave granted?
—If the minister seeks to pursue a malevolent course, we have means to prevent it. Of course we do not grant leave.
—Leave is not granted.

—I wait for the day when the Labor Party lets me table this letter and a few other letters that have fallen off the back of a truck in support of our ambitions to become a global financial centre. Isn't it funny that the Labor Party would not give me leave to table a letter from a member of the parliamentary Labor Party in support of what we are doing!

—The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation knows that he can table that document if he wants to. That is fine. That is his prerogative. The more interesting issue arising from the minister's response to the Financial Review article of 8 October, the very paper he was quoting from in question time yesterday, is: has the minister run-up the white flag on Australia's bid to be a regional financial centre? Clearly, suggesting that he wants to now share with Singapore seems to ordinary readers of the article to be an acceptance of defeat or some kind of surrender on the minister's part. We are entitled to find out from the minister what his real attitude is on this.

speech.para: We are also very curious to know just how long it will be before we start seeing some return on the $7 million outlaid towards Australia's bid in this area and the minister justifying some of the expenditure that has been going on in this area. I also want to provide some support for the minister and, indeed, congratulate him on getting the bill this far. I feel I need to do this because no-one else in the parliament has. Senator Campbell, in summing up after the long and quite tortuous process of this legislation through the Senate, thanked the senators for their contribution and went on to say:
I did miss one person, however, that is Australia's Treasurer, Peter Costello . . . It was one of the great privileges of my life to work so closely with him during that two-year period.

We can see quite clearly the intent of Senator Campbell's congratulations for Treasurer Costello—that is, that one day, in a Costello government, he hopes Treasurer Costello will throw out that evil usurper, the present Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, and install Senator Campbell in his place. Then Senator Chapman, talking about the same thing—the CLERP program—places on record his appreciation for the work of Senator Gibson and Senator Campbell on this legislation. So we can see that everybody on the government side, but the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, has had a pat on the back. I do not want him to feel that he has been left out in relation to this matter so, on behalf of the opposition, I note his efforts in getting this legislation through the parliament.

talk.start.para: —I thank the shadow assistant Treasurer for his magnanimous good wishes. In some cases, it is in keeping with his demeanour. He asked a little earlier to see some dividends of what we are doing. The dividends are clear. The Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank announced just a few days ago that it is going to increase its operations in Australia by 300 people. Deutsche Asset Management has announced that it is relocating all of its asset management activities for the Asia-Pacific region from the headquarters in Tokyo to Sydney, and, obviously, I declare an interest in that.

speech.para: A number of others—including Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley—have also indicated that they are significantly expanding operations in Australia. The global links between our exchanges and the exchanges of other nations, including the MOU that I witnessed the signing of in Thailand between the Thai stock exchange and the Australian stock exchange, are part of the partnership arrangement that will deliver us better opportunities in the region.

The non-Japan Asia part of the world economy has enormous potential; probably half the people in the world live in non-Japan Asia. However, it represents only a small fraction, about 12 per cent, of the global economy and global market. It has tremendous growth potential. That is why we talk about partnerships in the region. There will effectively be four time zone centres in the world—the Americas, Europe, Japan and non-Japan Asia. We aim to be a major financial centre for the globe in non-Japan Asia. That is our window of opportunity.

We have skills that others cannot provide, particularly in back office operations. We can provide, from Australia, the IT support, the accounting support and the telecommunications for the entire Asia-Pacific region. We have excellent people, and that is reflected in the example of Merrill Lynch. They have 1,000 employees in Australia, of which only 18 are ex-pats. They have a further 250 Australians in significant management positions around the world. It is of great credit to Australia and its people that we have this enormous talent. That is having a global impact but we do not appreciate it here. What we want is for them to get into leadership positions around the world and to bring some of that wealth back home to Australia. That is what this push is about. Each step of the way delivers jobs and investment for everyday Australians. We have the opportunity to be a very wealthy nation. We want the regional pie to grow, and that is very important.

On that basis, I have no qualms about advising the House of the success. In fact, if the shadow assistant Treasurer has a look at yesterday's Hansard from the New South Wales parliament he will see that it was the Treasurer of New South Wales who was congratulating me on my performance. But I am humble and I will not go into the details of that. I will leave that up to the shadow assistant Treasurer. Given that he is prepared to blow my bugle, I will give him the opportunity to continue to do that.

Obviously the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 is a key part of our development as a global financial centre. It is world-class regulatory reform. In fact, in my discussions with the monetary authority of Singapore, the program was referred to as `leading'. They anxiously await CLERP 6. We are going to give it. The best form of flattery for us is the fact that others are copying what we are doing. Unfortunately, the Labor Party is taking a different approach.

talk.start.para: —The last few years in the Asia-Pacific region have indicated one thing about Australia's comparative strengths with the region, and that has been the comparative integrity and transparency of our markets. In terms of achieving the objective that the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation is on about relating to Australia's developing its capacities in financial services, one of the crucial things that has underpinned the Labor Party's approach on these issues before the parliament under the badge of CLERP—it is a rebadging of the former government's corporate law simplification program—is in fact that question of market integrity and transparency. That is what has principally motivated the sorts of concerns that the Corporations and Securities Committee have put before the parliament.

speech.para: For the minister to suggest that in some way we have been dragging the chain is playing pretty fast and loose with the facts. This minister is particularly sensitive about a few things. Long lunches is obviously one of them. The facts are that if the minister had not been on so many long lunches this legislation may well have passed through the parliament somewhat quicker than has been the case. This has dragged along for three years now under this government. That is not satisfactory.

The other area where the minister has been playing pretty fast and loose is the view he expressed earlier, that is, that in some way there is almost unanimous support for the government's position on a number of these measures from the business and investor community. I once again quote the very well respected chairman of the Australian Shareholders Association, Ted Rofe, in respect of compulsory acquisition. He says that compulsory acquisition involves the expropriation of property. This was quoted extensively by the shadow Assistant Treasurer, but to suggest that there is a unanimous view in the business community on the approach the government has taken is factually incorrect. There are a range of areas where there has been very serious concern in the business and investment community about that approach. Some of the aspects have been tidied up in the Senate but not all, and I do not intend to go through all of them. But for the minister to make these suggestions is misinforming the House.

The government, with respect to its approach to takeovers, seems to have the view that takeovers are always good. I would suggest that there are an awful lot of shareholders in a number of companies, most notably in recent times the AMP-GIO fiasco, who would dispute that view. What is required is a balanced set of corporate law measures that attempt to balance the interests and protect all sorts of interests, not just the big end of town.

If one looks at the rhetoric of the minister when he expresses great disappointment about some of the matters he has before the House at the moment, it is somewhat disappointing that the government still has not learnt the lessons that these balances are necessary. That, I think, bodes ill for the future of some areas of corporate law, which, to come back to my starting point, is absolutely critical in maintaining the strengths and integrity of the Australian financial markets given the sorts of objectives the government has set for this country in terms of international finance. I was inspired to rise to my feet by the minister's misleading the House in relation to the attitudes of both the opposition and also of the business and investment community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Dr Stone:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —At the conclusion of this address on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , the opposition will be moving a second reading amendment which will foreshadow certain areas of concern which we had hoped would be taken up in this House through reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, but we understand that, in relation to the government's position, they are disinclined to that course. We will subsequently be pursuing the issues we raise by way of specific concern in the second reading amendment by seeking the cooperation of non-government parties in the Senate to have an examination of those issues in that place.

speech.para: The government has stated two main aims in introducing this bill: to provide flexibility in Australian Federal Police employment consistent with the AFP reform program and to recast and to clarify the commissioner's power of command. The bill alters the statutory employment framework so that there can be a greater reliance on industrial agreements—that is, it facilitates the removal of statutory fixed term appointments. The government has also attempted to introduce a regime which separates the commissioner's general employment and disciplinary powers. The commissioner will have a general power of employment, with most employment conditions being determined under the Workplace Relations Act. The commissioner will, however, also retain command powers as set out by the Federal Court in Anderson and Sullivan which will be excluded from the Workplace Relations Act. In addition to arrangements which currently operate by way of agreement with the Australian Federal Police Association on a voluntary basis, the bill includes provision for compulsory drug testing. The bill also removes the statutory entitlement to the Australian Federal Police Adjustment Scheme, which is commonly called AFPAS.

I should make a couple of general introductory remarks. Firstly, it was the Australian Labor Party which started a significant reform process within the Australian Federal Police. That reform program has not proceeded smoothly and has been the subject of significant difficulties with respect to the way in which this government has managed its relationship with the Australian Federal Police. The government in the past has decimated the Australian Federal Police regarding funding and support, and it is only now vainly beginning to try to fix the damage it has done.

If I might be specific in relation to recent events, the $155 million funding package for the Australian Federal Police announced by Senator Vanstone on 20 September was an example of the government's fudging of figures to hide the fact that they have not been, and still are not now, adequately funding the Australian Federal Police. I will examine the rationale for that statement, but I make the statement now that, of the $155 million referred to, only $5 million will, in practice, be new money to be spent by the AFP in an attempt to redress problems with resourcing, funding and carrying out their core functions. Those are problems which have been caused by the government's fierce slashing of the AFP's budget in the past.

The reason I say the $155 million funding package really reduces, on analysis, to $5 million is that there is approximately $100 million that the Australian Federal Police's AFPAS scheme—which is being terminated by this legislation—has in liabilities that will now have to be paid out, most of them within the next 12 months, to officers whose 10-year contracts expire and, in some circumstances, to officers who stay in the force under the new certified agreements provisions and the provisions of this bill.

Last year, the government also announced $115 million of funding following the Ayers report, but $50 million of that was to come from savings within the Australian Federal Police. The government has not given any guarantees that these savings were found. In fact, information which has been provided to me from within the organisation and the AFPA suggests that those savings were not achieved—which means that in fact $50 million of this year's $155 million will have to be siphoned off to cover that shortfall.

There may have already been some minor savings; but broadly, if you take the $155 million—of which much was made in terms of an assertion that there was increased resourcing for the Australian Federal Police—you have to subtract from that about $100 million for the AFPAS liabilities and about $50 million for the savings which were foreshadowed in the Ayers report but which were not achieved and which will need to be backfilled by that measure. So you actually come up with a very slight amount: in the order of $5 million of new money.

The government is continuing to fund the Australian Federal Police in an ad hoc, ineffective and inefficient way. I regret that the government has not yet released—and appears absolutely determined not to release—the Ayers report, so that there can be public debate about our prime enforcement agency.

One of the issues which we will take up subsequently and which we will be addressing in the amendments in detail is the advantage that would accrue were this parliament to have greater oversight of the whole area of law enforcement. Currently, this parliament only examines the operations and workings of the National Crime Authority. We conceive that there would be great advantage in having a parliamentary committee charged with much larger responsibilities of looking at law enforcement in general, which would bring within its remit the Australian Federal Police and would also go to long-term strategic planning issues; the proper resourcing of the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority and other associated agencies; the way they work together; and the challenges and threats they face in the future. This government is operating in a piecemeal and quite covert manner in relation to a whole range of issues that really need to have proper public examination and the proper scrutiny of this parliament.

Today, in the Senate, the minister for justice made much of some remarks—at which I am sure the Commissioner now squirms when he hears them repeated—of the Commissioner when he unfortunately was taped in a radio interview. I attended the 20th birthday party for the Australian Federal Police, and was delighted to be there; and I do have enormous respect for those who occupy high office in the Australian Federal Police—the Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner and those who serve right throughout the ranks—because I believe it is an organisation which, under very trying circumstances, has offered a high level of proficiency, admittedly with some difficulties and, I am certain, with a number of errors from time to time. Nonetheless I say that the Commissioner must squirm now, because I thought that the Commissioner suffered from an outburst of enthusiasm of a most uncharacteristic kind when he said in the radio interview that the current government had provided the greatest resources and the best support of any government in relation to the workings of the AFP.

I am sure that the Commissioner expressed this hyperbole in response to being pressed in relation to issues that were being put to him at that time, suggesting that the AFP's morale was running down and that it was subject to considerable difficulties. Also probably at the back of his mind was the then pending motion of no confidence that was being brought against him by the Australian Federal Police Association, which went to the then negotiations about the workplace relations agreement that was being proposed and, of course, to the larger issue of the resources of the Australian Federal Police.

talk.start.para: —Some of whom are in East Timor.

—The former Deputy Prime Minister makes that point. Might I say that I have indicated that the opposition, through me as spokesperson for justice, has continually honoured the service of the Australian Federal Police, and nothing that I say is intended to dishonour that. The record of service that has been given overseas in places like Cambodia and Haiti, and that is still being given in the Republic of Cyprus and most recently in East Timor is a distinguished one and will continue to be so.

speech.para: I was trying to put the Commissioner's remarks, which I regard as hyperbole, into some context and to indicate why I am sure when he looks at himself in the mirror he must say, `How did I get myself to say those things?' If you go to the actual formal reports of the Commissioner, as presented to this parliament in the Australian Federal Police's annual reports, a very different story emerges. I might take the parliament first to the annual report of 1997-98, where the Commissioner referred to the previous report of 1996-97, in which he indicated he had identified a number of factors which had hindered the Australian Federal Police's capacity to perform its core functions. He indicated that those factors included resource constraints, high attrition rates and a declining capacity to accept referrals for investigations from other agencies.

He indicated that in that year—1997-98—these factors continued to exert pressure on the Australian Federal Police along with the continuation of savings measures introduced in 1996-97. These measures included restricted recruitment, across-the-board application of internal budget cuts, targeted reduction of travel expenditure, limited filling of vacant positions and limited assessment of service levels to client departments. The number of fraud investigations initiated by the AFP continued to decline during the year and the gross attrition rate of staffing levels remained high at 7.41 per cent. He pointed out that the AFP experienced a significant reduction in base funding in 1997-98 as a result of the continued application of the efficiency dividend and a four per cent portfolio base cut and reductions for whole of government telecommunications savings. He indicated that the impact of reductions in base funding was exacerbated by a need to repay significant forward borrowings which had accumulated over a number of years. He mentioned a number of specific purpose allocations which had been given but indicated that they did nothing to address or relieve the underlying structural budgetary problem which threatened continued operational effectiveness and viability. That is an extraordinary thing for the commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to say in a report to this parliament. The nation's premier law enforcement agency in 1997-98 is reporting that its continued operational effectiveness and viability have been threatened by this government.

Then we turn to the current annual report. It noted that gross attrition rates to June 1999 were 6.58 per cent, down from 7.4 per cent in the last financial year, but it pointed out that this represented a loss of 173 personnel—112 police members and 61 staff members—while the reprofiling program accounted for the loss of another 57 personnel—49 police members and eight staff members. The report pointed out the difficulties in the rate of progress of some aspects of the AFP's reform program, particularly the implementation of certain human resource reforms, which are always going to be difficult. The report indicated that there remained problems—that, although there were some issues which had been relieved to some extent by funding that had addressed some of those specifics, there were still ongoing difficulties with the management and funding in relation to the organisation.

We have just tabled—I think today, but I am not certain; I would not be held to that— the Commonwealth Ombudsman annual report, which points to significant problems in the internal operation of the recruitment program of the Australian Federal Police. The Ombudsman's investigation had found that AFP recruitment processes in the term of this government had lacked professionalism and raised serious questions as to whether there was a conflict of interest and/or undue favouritism in the process.

So I am certain that there is not much support in the Australian Federal Police or in the Australian Federal Police Association for the extraordinary comments of the commissioner. I am certain the commissioner looks back on them with some regret as he finds that they are being used and touted by the Minister for Justice and Customs—saying that all is well in the best of all possible worlds in relation to the funding arrangements that this government has put in place and the management regime that currently exists. Frankly, we do not believe it. The Australian Federal Police who are serving do not believe it. The Australian Federal Police Association is actively committed to the contrary proposition. And we are advised—although the details are difficult to nail down—that there continues to be a reduction in the number of referrals that can be accepted by the Australian Federal Police for investigation, whilst at the same time the number of referrals coming forward that require investigation is actually increasing.

This is not to denigrate the work of the Australian Federal Police but rather to put this debate and these reforms in a practical context and to get away from the braying self-congratulation that the minister for justice substitutes for analysis. In general, both the Australian Federal Police Association and the opposition support the general direction of this bill. We have consulted with the AFPA. The bill substantially redefines AFP industrial relations arrangements, but there are a number of questions that remain to be settled. It is not immediately clear how the new scheme will operate in practice—and the association and the opposition have concerns about several aspects of the bill, which are iterated in the second reading amendment. For example, the wholesale repeal of the existing part 5 of the act which contains provisions relating to maternity leave, promotions, the operation of the Merit Protection Act and standards and rights with respect to employees seconded as officials of the union are all issues that overlap with the government's approach to industrial relations and employment security.

Some of those concerns are not just restricted to the Australian Federal Police, but we are anxious—in this environment where we expect quite a deal of those wearing the uniform or not wearing the uniform but who are agents of the Commonwealth in this important area of Commonwealth responsibility—about the trend of leaving crucial employment provisions and guarantees to the enterprise bargaining process. The removal of legislative provisions relating to maternity leave is particularly concerning for women and particularly concerning for those who, over recent years, have been making a significant contribution to the service and workings of the Australian Federal Police. It is not so long ago that it was a rarity to find a woman entering the Australian Federal Police, and we are concerned that the government has steadily eroded many of the legislative and social safeguards for working women which should be a fundamental part of our society.

Having had discussions with the Australian Federal Police Association, we expressed concern about what is believed to be lack of accountability and transparent promotional and advancement systems dealt with under regulations and industrial agreements which relate to existing provisions in part V of the act which are not provided for in this bill; the provisions which allow for dismissal following conviction for an offence which only receives a section 19B Crimes Act bond. The provisions in this bill anticipate that anybody so convicted of an indictable offence will automatically be dismissed from the force, but section 19B provisions apply only to convictions where a bond has been given, and that can only occur where an offence has been held by a judge to be of a trivial nature.

Notwithstanding the fact that the offence notionally is one of some seriousness and we would normally expect dismissal to follow, section 19B can only come into effect where the judicial determination is that in fact what has occurred, whilst notionally falling within the terms of indictable offence, is in fact trivial. It may well be that that matter needs examination. It is one of the issues that we will be asking to be looked at whenever this matter does have a committee examination.

We also think there needs to be some examination of the process that the merits review of decisions of the commissioners will operate. I think that there does need to be some clarity about the relationship between the command and employment powers of the commissioner and the application of the Workplace Relations Act. It is clear that those two streams will overlap from time to time, and the working through of those issues and exactly how they will work in practice does need clarification. Perhaps some undertakings from the minister in the consideration in detail stage may assist.

The opposition is content for the measures in relation to compulsory drug testing to proceed, but we understand from the minister's office that she is content to give assurances that the process will continue in practice as it has under the voluntary scheme—in other words, that the arrangements which operate when somebody is discerned to have at some stage taken an illicit drug will remain as they currently stand. I think that is a matter that can be dealt with simply by the minister giving the undertaking that her officers have indicated that she is content to give.

Closer scrutiny of this bill is warranted. I might say that a lot of the concern that is being expressed in the second reading amendment and by the association might not have had to have come before this place had the government been more open in the way it went about the development of this legislation. When Labor was in office, we always regarded significant change to the legislation governing the Australian Federal Police as requiring at a very early stage the engagement of representatives of those who were employed within the Australian Federal Police and their association. That has not occurred in the development of this legislation.

Notwithstanding that, broadly, both the opposition and the AFPA are not inclined to throw the baby out with the bathwater; we think that they are, in the main, quite reasonable provisions. But, when you get down to these matters of detail, many of them—which perhaps could have been worked through and concerns alleviated by up-front and transparent discussion at an early stage—which do now need to be the subject of an examination in committee, could have been avoided had the government been minded to follow a less closed process.

The issues regarding accountability of the organisation are also important. The restructuring of the Australian Federal Police which is proposed by the bill raises issues of organisational accountability. Commonwealth law enforcement generally needs improved provisions to ensure that the community has a clear understanding of law enforcement's role. We need to be satisfied that there are properly developed and integrated strategic and tactical directions being adopted. After all, the Australian Federal Police, by a very significant order of magnitude, is the largest law enforcement body of the Commonwealth. There are a number of other agencies which have functions in the law enforcement area, but none have the significance and importance for the whole of government that the Australian Federal Police has. The organisation has always been regarded as the pre-eminent law enforcement agency of the national government.

It is odd, therefore, in that context, that the parliament has a scrutiny and oversight committee which examines the National Crime Authority and a scrutiny and oversight committee which examines the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation but none which examines the whole issue of law enforcement. Of course, it is not appropriate to bundle ASIO in with law enforcement generally; I am not proposing that.

However, the measures that we are proposing, and which we will be moving in the consideration in detail stage of this legislation, are directed towards giving this parliament the capacity to have a continuing relationship with the direction and the objectives of law enforcement, so that we do not address these issues in a piecemeal way, so we can look at the whole range of strategic threats that we face as a community in the future—from organised crime and new technologies as they emerge, which open up new vulnerabilities, to all of those issues that come before this parliament—and so we can look at the organisational structures to best deal with them.

We can look at the coordination that needs to exist between the different agencies which have some carriage of different parts of the Commonwealth law enforcement brief—of course, they include a whole range of different agencies including, for example, the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, AUSTRAC and a number of other agencies which do have specific responsibilities—to make sure that the whole package fits together and works well. It is something that this parliament would be very much empowered by. It would give this parliament a significantly greater capacity to be able to look at strategic and non-operational issues which go into the whole law enforcement agenda.

In that regard I think there are very few who have served on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority who have not welcomed the insights that that has provided in relation to that organisation. I see it as being very positive for the Australian Federal Police were the government to adopt these provisions. I might also say that I have had discussions with the Australian Federal Police Association about these proposals. They welcome them. They think it is very important for this parliament to have a proper committee in which the larger issues relating to law enforcement can be discussed, often in private, often outside the partisan debate that currently passes for analysis and serious discussion of law enforcement, and away from some of the rhetoric that clouds the air. This is one of the particular measures which we will be commending to the government.

When this matter comes before the Senate we will be asking the Democrats and the other non-government parties—the Greens and Independent Senator Harradine—to support reference of the matters on which we have expressed concern. These are concerns which have been raised by members of the Australian Federal Police. It may be that on some of these issues we need not proceed with specific amendments; undertakings that satisfy those concerns perhaps can be given. Other particulars may require specific amendments to be moved after consideration of those concerns to ensure they are legitimate and, if they are legitimate, you would expect the opposition—and, indeed, perhaps the government—to take the initiative on those particular matters. I conclude this overview of our approach to this legislation.

I was pleased with the briefing I received from the minister's office on this. Certainly since the bill has been published I can but commend the cooperation. I only regret that, in common with much of the way in which this government deals with law enforcement, there is often—as with the duck—tranquillity on the surface and much action underneath which the government does not disclose. That does not lead to good decision making in the end because there are interested parties who need to have their concerns addressed, not least the opposition. At some stage we will be back in government and there are important and longstanding issues of common concern that go to having a good framework for law enforcement. The Australian Federal Police Association, civil liberties groups and others want to see greater oversight of these arrangements to make sure that those processes are transparent and proper. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:
(1) expresses its concern about:
(a) the level of accountability and transparency of decisions made under the command and employment powers of the Commissioner of Police under the provisions of the Bill;
(b) the lack of mechanisms in the Bill for scrutiny and review of dismissal and promotion decisions;
(c) the possible unfair operation of the Bill in relation to termination of employment;
(d) the repeal of provisions relating to promotional and advancement systems, and to maternity leave;
(e) the relationship between the command and employment powers of the Commissioner of Police under the Bill;
(f) the operation of the Bill in relation to entitlement to continuous employment;
(g) clarification of the application of the Workplace Relations Act to the employment regime as established by the Bill; and

(h) the failure of the Government to support the establishment of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on Commonwealth law enforcement to provide a strategic view in respect of all Commonwealth law enforcement agencies; and

(2) is of the opinion that the Bill should be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and advisory report, given the detailed matters raised in the Bill.

talk.start.para: —It is important that law enforcement be provided with the resources and the capacity it needs. In a nation which believes in the rule of law it is vital. Also, in a nation which prides itself on the doctrine of the separation of powers, it is important that those of us in this place provide law enforcement officials with the capacity, the resources and the understanding of issues which are important in the enforcement of laws. We wish them well in their endeavours. We look forward to seeing the AFP continuing their tremendous job.

speech.para: It is 20 years since the inception of the current incarnation of the Australian Federal Police, but the idea of a national policing body had its roots back in the very earliest of days of this parliament. It was as early as 1903 when some of the ideas were floated. But it was at the time of the celebrated egg throwing incident in Warwick, in my state of Queensland, when Senior Sergeant Kenny, a good Irishman, told Prime Minister Hughes at the time of the great conscription debate he would not intervene to protect the Prime Minister of the day because he worked for another great Irishman in T.J. Ryan, the Labor Premier at the time, that Hughes thought there needed to be some sort of protective mechanism for the Commonwealth. Out of this sketchy tradition came what we have today.

The Australian Federal Police has had, ever since 29 November 1917—it is worth remind ing the House of this particular date; the date of the famous egg throwing incident at Warwick railway station—various incarnations. We had the Commonwealth Investigation Branch from 1919 to 1945. We had the Commonwealth Police Force at one stage, as well. We had the Commonwealth Investigation Service.
