Since 1979 we have had the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Federal Police do a number of things. One of them is providing police services to the Australian Capital Territory. But it is the provision of police services to enforce the laws of the Commonwealth, to protect the property of the Commonwealth and to safeguard Commonwealth interests in which we in this place are particularly interested.

In my contribution today I want to pay tribute to the efforts of the contemporary members of the Australian Federal Police. I also want to acknowledge that this government is providing them with—as has even been noted by the opposition spokesman the member for Denison—in the words of the Commissioner, Mick Palmer, `resources and capacity far greater, far better, than have ever been provided before'. We do so for a number of reasons. There are great pressures on modern society because criminals seem to be, to use the hackneyed phrase, `one step ahead of the law' because of their capacity to use technology. It is always we legislators who have to react to some new idea of breaking the law, therefore criminals tend to get away with things for a while.

The influx of drugs into this nation has rightly been met with a solid response from the Howard government of new resources, additional resources and a far greater focus being given to the Australian Federal Police, amongst other agencies, enabling there to be, on behalf of all Australians, a far more solid basis on which to combat this most heinous of crimes, this crime which affects the lives of individuals, this trade in human misery—the trade in drugs.

It is important to note for the record some of the great achievements of the Australian Federal Police since the coming to power of the Howard government in 1996. I would like to put those achievements on the record. I admit my source is the Internet, the great electronic device of crime in the late 1990s as well as, one would hope, that great service to humanity where communication is cheap and readily available.

The AFP page heralds so many great achievements over the last couple of years. From Operation Anthem, 23.7 kilos of heroin were found in wall-hangings on their arrival at Melbourne airport and three people were arrested. Through Operations Molotov and Calculus, 8.4 tonnes of cannabis resin were seized in Queensland and there were 15 arrests; 5,000 marijuana plants were also seized at premises of the principal offender. There was the discovery of five tonnes of cannabis in shipping containers in Sydney. There was Operation Redgum in 1996 regarding drug related crimes in the ACT region. Operation Abilene in 1997: a long-running investigation into 624 kilos of compressed cannabis found in a shipping container which was sent from South Africa to Sydney. Seizure of 142 $20 bills, counterfeit polymer banknotes, which were passed in Sydney and Melbourne. Further investigation by the men and women of the Australian Federal Police led to larger counterfeit note seizures, with two people being charged with currency, firearms, stolen vehicle and drug offences. Cyclops in 1997: 10 tonnes of cannabis resin was seized from a vessel near Port Stephens in New South Wales. Twenty kilos of cocaine were discovered in the suitcases of two US citizens arriving in Sydney from Argentina. Also, 23.4 kilos of heroin were found in crates of furniture which travelled from Malaysia to Sydney.

On and on it goes. In 1998, Operation Stockman: a vessel from China smuggled in 94 kilograms of heroin concealed in three industrial ovens in cargo. Chandelier: a consignment of water pumps arrived in Sydney from France and were found to contain 17.2 kilos of ecstasy. Who would forget Operation Gentle from last year when a Customs-AFP joint operation tracked the movements of an international cocaine trafficking syndicate resulting in the seizure of almost 225 kilograms of cocaine from a yacht at Coffs Harbour in New South Wales. Into this year: more ecstasy, more heroin, more heroin, more heroin.

I raise these matters because they go to the heart of what the modern AFP is all about. It is not so much about trying to get some recalcitrant Irishman or a police officer from Queensland in 1917 who would not protect the Prime Minister of the day. It is all about the international linkages and the intelligence which are required to combat crime, to track crime, to use the other agencies which complement it, such as AUSTRAC, the National Crime Authority, Customs and other agencies. This sort of effort by the Australian Federal Police is probably not well appreciated in the broad community.

The Australian Federal Police are not out on the beat, patrolling in the way we wish our state police officers would do—and I know there is a great lament in Queensland with it still not being case. Australian Federal Police officers tend to be people who are brought from other jurisdictions and are hired by the Australian Federal Police because of their intelligence and their ability to dissect potential criminal matters, to perfect the technology which may be used by criminals to try to hide those criminal matters and to actually unpick and unravel matters sufficient for charges to be laid, for prosecutions to commence and for the courts to then judge. The Australian Federal Police are a very special lot—they are an extremely special lot—and they deserve the very best of support from government in their activity.

This bill before us today aims to simplify so many of the existing complex employment provisions under which these special people are brought together under the umbrella of the Australian Federal Police. The provisions in this legislation provide a framework for greater reliance on clear understandings through industrial agreements. They are consistent with the government's overall stated intentions as far as workplace reforms are concerned. We know what those stated intentions are all about. They are all about reward for effort. They are all about ensuring individuals who work hard get the reward they should get. They are about ensuring there is flexibility in workplace arrangements—that people can trade in and out certain agreed standards of employment for some other standard of employment.

Those sorts of basic conditions, those detailed employment conditions, which are determined under the Workplace Relations Act are far more complex than just remuneration alone. It is very important for Australian Federal Police officers to know that the kind of personal individual treatment which can come from the concept of the change to the employment provisions contained in this measure today is all about trying to give them the kind of focus and reward they deserve.

I am on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, like the member for Denison. I am not going to divulge some of the things which we get briefed upon, but when you hear stories about one single Federal Police officer who has dedicated himself to tracking down, with great urgency, some of the details of a crime which he is now able to successfully prosecute and to find great fraud against the Commonwealth because of tax avoidance and those sorts of matters you start to appreciate you here have a person who is not working nine to five, who is not rostered on between eight and four. This is a person who literally broke his emotional back to make things happen. He was not running the sort of bundy clock arrangement of `Clock on, clock off, overtime is now due'. Here is a guy who said, `I've got a job to do. The clock is running, the Commonwealth is losing money, I'm a dedicated police officer and I'm going to work—and I'm going to work until I get this job done.'

They are the sorts of people that, to my mind, are at the heart of this bill. The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mick Palmer in this current case, should be charged with the responsibility to provide the sort of flexibility that should address those kinds of reasonable concerns from ordinary serving officers. We do not want to see a `one size fits all' approach, a bundy clock type of approach, to industrial relations in this area. It is vital that flexibility exists because there is no way that criminals clock in and out nine to five. The bundy clock does not exist in the criminal world. So it is very important that we offer our representatives in the Australian Federal Police the flexibility they need to do the job they are going to do.

I submit that the legislation before us is worthy of support, because it is part of the overall package of measures this government is putting in place as a whole of government approach in the fight against the trade in human misery, the fight against the trade in illegal drugs coming into this country. They are the reasons that I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to rise to speak on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 and, whilst time does not allow me to address all of the amendments, I intend to address some of the issues contained within it. The bill simplifies the existing complex provisions in the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, providing a framework for greater reliance on industrial agreement consistent with the government's workplace reforms. The bill enacts the AFP commissioner's general power of employment, but detailed employment conditions such as remuneration will be determined through agreements in accordance with the Workplace Relations Act 1996.

speech.para: The bill also recognises and preserves the distinct nature of the AFP as a disciplined force by specifically retaining the commissioner's command powers to the exclusion of the Workplace Relations Act. This is a noble objective, but it will only be as effective as the ability of the commissioner and his line commanders to be professionally committed to the support for the backbone of the AFP front-line troops—the dedicated police officers who, given the appropriate resources, will enforce the law in the same diligent way in which they have done for decades now.

The public has high expectations of police, particularly the AFP, who in my opinion—which is based on knowledge of other police services at a state level—stand head and shoulders above the rest of them. For many years now, much has been said about the need to allocate more resources to the AFP. But at the same time the imposition of so-called efficiency driven cost saving management decisions has seriously curtailed the effective law enforcement capabilities of the professional, dedicated and committed element of the AFP—that is, the police officers themselves.

Governments of all political persuasion have much to answer for in their inability to acknowledge the need to ensure that working conditions as well as adequate resources and remuneration are prerequisites for high morale and motivation not only to achieve the best possible law enforcement outcomes but also to maintain the strength of the force itself, thereby maintaining the incentive to perform to the level expected by the community. Hopefully, these amendments are sufficient to ensure this happens. I do, however, have some reservations about the power carried by the commissioner, because history has shown the top end of management in these organisations have mismanaged the scarce resources at the expense of the front-line officers themselves.

Not long after I came into this place, I raised my concerns about the possibility of 80 per cent of AFP officers on statutory fixed term appointments entitled to the Australian Federal Police Adjustment Scheme, AFPAS, covered in these amendments, resigning from the force. This would have created a massive immediate impact on the ability of government to adequately address the illegal importation and distribution of illicit drugs such as heroin and cocaine, despite the government's well-intentioned and financially committed drug strategy, which should have been addressed a decade ago.

The Howard government has recognised this imminent threat to the decimation of the finest police service in this country by the removal of the statutory fixed term appointment or FTA system. This has impacted to some degree on the rigidity in AFP staffing arrangements and has also impacted negatively on financial management and forward planning. Although to some degree the latter has more to do with lack of management expertise than financial constraints, this is something the government, through its committee structure, needs to investigate if it is to obtain maximum return from the investment made to address, for example, the massive explosion in illicit drugs in this country.

Serving police officers can do the job effectively. However, they need to be guided by forward planning which has both short-term and long-term objectives. The AFP also has to catch up by remunerating its officers in line with salaries comparable with other police services, because salary levels are another element of the disquiet within the force that have to be addressed.

I understand the negotiations regarding salaries are part of the certified agreement discussion currently under way between the AFP and the police association. I trust that these certified agreements or wage negotiations, which are an entirely separate issue, are not linked to the AFPAS to the extent that the AFPAS termination arrangements are used by the commissioner as a lever to extract unfair elements within the certified agreement by the commissioner.

The AFPAS, which is the Australian Federal Police adjustment payment made under the current act, operated as a major incentive for people not to seek reappointment because the AFPAS entitlement is payable only when a person leaves the organisation. The AFPAS was intended to compensate personnel for the loss of further security of employment arising from the FTA system. It was to operate not only as an incentive for people to complete FTAs but also as a corruption deterrent, because it was forfeited if a person was dismissed for corruption or misconduct.

With the replacement of FTAs with a continuing employment regime, the need for an AFPAS disappears. People will make their employment decisions without having to have regard to the artificial constraints imposed by the FTA system and will remove the incentive for a large number of people to leave the AFP in order to access an AFPAS.

If there were a distinct possibility that the considerable powers of the commissioner could be used to determine the time of payment of the AFPAS, the government's sensible decision could be negated and resignations could be revisited. The legislation clearly recognises the AFP as a disciplined organisation in which the commissioner has both the role of a public sector chief executive officer and, more importantly, a commander in every sense of the word. The amendments will enable the commissioner and the organisation to adequately respond to emerging management and law enforcement trends in a rapidly changing environment where the pace of change is going to increase.

The capacity of both the organisation and the police serving in it to not only anticipate change but also participate in those changes in an environment of high morale and with a commitment to achieve the outcomes expected by the community is essential to maintaining the integrity of what I believe to be the most corruption free and professional police service in the nation. These amendments will enable further development of this capacity while appropriately safeguarding the interests of the members of the organisation.

The public—and, I am sure, all members in this place—understand that the extraordinary demands of police work require high ethical standards. We are all aware of the complex and often dangerous circumstances associated with investigating organised crime involved in drug trafficking and related activities and the dangers involved in community policing. This is all the more reason why we have to ensure these amendments not only enforce the integrity of the AFP but also have the ability to attract the right people into the organisation.

Last year the government announced its Tough on Drugs strategy. Included in the funding which came with this announcement was a provision to finance the recruitment of about 50 federal agents from within the ranks of serving police officers. Despite advertisements being placed in national newspapers, the response was disappointing given that there are approximately 41,000 police serving in police services throughout Australia. This has everything to do with remuneration and is a classic illustration of why the level of recruitment over the years has not kept pace with resignations.

The point I am making here is that we must always keep in mind that any amendments to legislation must not only address the issue of accountability for misconduct, testing for drugs and other employment related matters but always address the issue of adequate rates of pay and working conditions that reflect the nation's appreciation of its front-line national police service, which provides the highly motivated and skilled operators who make up the backbone of the AFP.

Obviously, these amendments have focused on the need to lift morale within the driving edge of the AFP by tightening the standards centred around the powers, duties, obligations and responsibilities of AFP employees, including its police officers. In the past, former commissioners and ministers of the Crown have obtained much public political mileage by espousing that the AFP has been underresourced and that the upgrading of police resources and conditions was critical to the development of an effective means for society to not only control and prevent organised crime but allow the AFP to become more proactive in preventing, detecting and destroying it before it destroys the very fabric of our society. As an example of what I am talking about, Major General Ron Grey—who was appointed AFP Commissioner in February 1983—wrote in his first annual report:
Organisational change cannot alone compensate for deficiencies in resources . . . Resources need to be brought more into balance with demands of the Force.
In the period 1984-85, following a national drug summit in the ACT and the Costigan royal commission presenting its final report, Commissioner Grey wrote:

In my view drug trafficking and organised crime emerge as the areas needing more resources . . . I remain very concerned that scarce AFP resources are being siphoned off to support such organisations as the DPP and the NCA . . . Shortages of manpower and funds remain my major concern.

We are talking about a decline in attitude towards the AFP and its most precious resource, its front-line police. That decline—despite what the member for Denison was saying, as the shadow minister for justice and customs, about the current government's lack of commitment to the AFP as such—happened in the mid-1980s, and the decline has continued since then. It is a question that needs to be addressed by all governments if we are to be serious about the massive influx of illicit drugs into this country.

We only have to look at what is happening in Victoria at the moment. An enormous amount of cocaine is coming into Victoria, and I have absolutely no doubt that it will be coming in elsewhere. Dedicated AFP police officers cannot possibly cope with that sort of pressure unless they are adequately resourced, particularly well-trained and capable police offices. It is important that they use their detection and surveillance skills to get on top of this very serious problem.

Let me now refer to a former member of this House, Mr Gareth Evans. When Attorney-General, the then Senator Gareth Evans summed up the conclusions of the 1983 National Crime Commission Conference with the following:

I discerned no disagreement about the fact that police are under resourced . . . There was a general acknowledgment that upgrading of police resources, methods and machinery must be part of any solution to the problem of organised crime . . . It is a question of resources that can and should be made available to police . . . A question to which Government, including I acknowledge the Commonwealth Government, must address their collective minds very quickly.

These legislative amendments will at least go towards addressing some of the workplace related reforms and will be complemented by the certified agreements reached between the commissioner and the AFP association on behalf of its members.

As I said earlier, the commissioner needs to focus on instilling confidence in his organisation, which for years now has been let down because of a continual focus on cost cutting through efficiency programs that tend to curtail the ability of police, for example, to effectively use their considerable law enforcement and investigatory skills to impact on the massive drug trade in this country. There is still a long way to go and, while governments can make the funding available to ensure that their policies on law enforcement are carried out, this will amount to absolutely nothing unless the obvious problems with the management and administrative functions of the AFP are addressed.

Today is not the day for me to elaborate on these issues. The bill before the House limits my contribution on matters associated with the failure of the AFP management to focus its energies and forward planning on what has driven the low morale and threatened the mass resignations which this bill, to the credit of the Minister for Justice and Customs, has to some extent overcome. At some time in the future, I will raise these issues. This will hopefully motivate senior AFP managers to address the deficiencies created by what I believe to be inadequate levels of skilled investigators, low levels of operational police, a lack of transfer of highly motivated skilled investigators within their ranks both inter and intrastate and a general feeling of despair created by poor personnel management. I thank the House for its indulgence in allowing me to speak on this issue. It has assisted me in raising matters that highlight the difficulties being faced by the backbone of the AFP—the front-line police officers themselves. I support the bill.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure tonight to rise in support of the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . It is significant legislation and I congratulate Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs, in having the foresight to address the particular problems and issues that now confront the Australian Federal Police and in introducing a new era in human resources management in the Australian Federal Police. The AFP has operated very much like a bureaucracy. In terms of the contracts that have been offered to the police, if police officers terminated and took a payout at the end of their contract, this would be a significant blow to the police force in the estimated numbers of police that they would lose. Some 10 per cent of police officers, at least, would be expected to resign within a one-year period if all of the contracts that are now in place were activated in terms of the payout that was expected to be made.

speech.para: The Australian Federal Police is a very fine organisation that deserves the support of every member of this House. As someone with a brother who was a member of the NSW Police Force, I am aware of the issues that confront police on a daily basis. It is an occupation which is very demanding, challenging and, in many cases, dangerous. It has an impact on people and, certainly, as those people who have seen police go through very traumatic events will know, this can often leave an imprint on their life for a very significant time. In recognising the Australian Federal Police here tonight, I think it is important for us to not only see them as upholders of the law—in, for example, ensuring that drugs do not enter the country illegally—looking after policing in all its various aspects in the ACT and nationally, but also to look beyond that and see them as individuals who have similar needs to other Australians in terms of their personal security, financial security and the way in which they are treated.

This bill goes a long way towards addressing these issues and implementing them in legislation. This will bring the Australian Federal Police into line with contemporary organisations. Clearly, the normal public service requirements are different from those of the Australian Federal Police—aspects of some of the personal freedoms that we would expect in the public service and in other organisations in the private sector are not present in the Australian Federal Police. Some of those freedoms will be forfeited by people as a result of being in the police force. That aside, however, this bill is about opening up the Australian Federal Police and making it subject to the same types of workplace relations agreements that we have seen in other areas of the economy.

It is important to see this bill as about preserving the core values of the Australian Federal Police and the commissioner in achieving the organisation's values of integrity, commitment, excellence, accountability, fairness and trust. The commissioner has a difficult time in meeting all of those requirements in terms of his or her objectives. But that is what this legislation is all about. It is clear to the government that the public expects the organisation to measure up to its high expectations in terms of commitment and excellence. It demonstrated these qualities when 50 Australian Federal Police officers went to East Timor during August and September of this year to take part in CIVPOL, the multinational team ensuring security in East Timor before and during the independence vote.

Domestically, the Australian Federal Police's most high profile roles are providing policing services to the ACT, providing witness protection nationally and combating drug trafficking, fraud, organised crime and money laundering. It has had a number of successes in recent years, including Operation Linnet. This operation disrupted the activities of a major international drug trafficking organisation through the seizure of 390 kilograms of heroin in October 1998. It was also involved in an international joint operation with authorities from Canada and Hong Kong. This operation seized a further 163 kilograms of heroin in a number of raids in 1998 and 1999. Operation Bronte, a joint operation between the AFP and DIMA, resulted in the detention in May this year of 83 unlawful non-citizens aboard a specifically modified freighter through the interception of maps and other documents at Sydney airport. I am sure that you would agree that this was an outstanding job. In anybody's language, they should be commended for their great achievements in drug enforcement.

The Australian Federal Police are also responding to changing trends. They must relate to those changing trends in criminal activity and, to do that, they must be a flexible organisation. Rapid and easy transportation systems, new communications systems, worldwide financial linkages and the progressive removal of border controls combined with increased trade volumes are factors which increase the challenge faced by the AFP. The dynamic and unpredictable nature of criminal activity means that they need to be constantly changing their approach to be able to carry out the apprehension of crime that we look for in the AFP. In addition to his responsibilities as commissioner of the AFP—as the CEO of the organisation—the commissioner's performance is measured in terms of the overall management and performance of the organisation itself. He also oper ates subject to the requirements of public sector accountabilities.

As to the specific reforms mentioned in the bill, an additional $115 million will be provided over three years to assist the Australian Federal Police to increase their staffing, maximise their capabilities and concentrate resources on fighting crime. A particularly important feature is, of course, the flexible employment arrangements. The Australian Federal Police now come under a workplace arrangement, which is the way most organisations now negotiate in the private sector. The commissioner becomes the employer—as he would in the private sector—and they negotiate with him as conditions apply. It is a sensible arrangement. It shows flexible thinking, foresight and good management of human resources.

The bill ensures that the commissioner is treated specially where the Australian Federal Police is unique but that the organisation is subject to the same discipline as applies to other bodies where it is not. The amendments recognise the need for a balance between general public sector and workplace issues and the need to recognise the unique situation applying to the Federal Police. The bill invests the commissioner with a general employment power in addition to ensuring that more flexible and efficient workplace arrangements can be implemented. It separates the role of command and discipline from matters relating to employment. It also enables the commissioner to deploy Australian Federal Police employees and to assign duties. This reinforces an important element in commanding a police organisation in both domestic and international activities. There are also strong anticorruption measures in the bill, and I think they would receive the support of every member of the House.

One of the major initiatives is the removal of the statutory fixed term appointment system, known as the FTA system. As I mentioned before, this has created a problem with fixed arrangements. It is not unusual in the private sector to have fixed term arrangements and contracts, often for three or five years, but the problem with this piece of legislation is that two aspects of fixed term agreements were untenable. The first one is that the majority of agreements were due for renewal or termination during a one-year period. The second is the incentive attached to the renewal of these contracts which would make it very attractive for people to resign and maximise their own earnings. It allows individuals to take up a lump sum payment which is triggered only on resignation.

If a number of people in the Australian Federal Police are due for re-endorsement of their contracts during the one period and then there is the incentive to get out, what do you think is likely to happen? The answer is that you are going to lose a lot of very fine policemen—policemen who have been trained and have been in all types of situations with the enormous breadth of experience that we see in the Australian Federal Police. It is something that the nation should not be subjected to—something that we should avoid. Both the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs need to be congratulated on recognising the problem and making the appropriate changes to the way the whole system is operated.

Whilst it is not possible to provide a definitive figure on how many of the AFP's 2,800 staff would quit following the end of their fixed terms, an educated guess is that it would be around 10 per cent. If 280 people resigned at any one time from the Federal Police it would be a significant loss to the organisation and would jeopardise the overall performance of a very fine organisation.

AFPAS was intended to compensate personnel for the future loss of employment security arising from the FTA system. It was to operate as an incentive for people to complete their contracts as well as to add to an anticorruption measure. If they did not reach the end of their contract or were precluded from taking up the contract because they had been involved in some corrupt practices, clearly the financial incentive would be important as an anticorruption measure. This has been replaced as part of a continuing employment regime. Under a new workplace agreement, they can now negotiate how they should operate directly with the commissioner. This has resulted in the renegotiation of their general conditions. The $115 million, which is to be provided over three years, will result in a better human resources management environment.

There have been some criticisms by members of the opposition of this particular piece of legislation: firstly, the termination of employment by the commissioner and, secondly, the reasons for dismissal. Proposed section 28 of the bill provides that the commissioner may, at any time by notice in writing, terminate the employment of an AFP employee. Item 1 of schedule 2 to the bill amends the administrative decisions such that, should the commissioner exercise his or her power to dismiss an AFP employee under section 28, the commissioner is not required to give reasons for that dismissal under the act. Of course, it is important to recognise that all rights in relation to unfair dismissal contained in division 3 of part VIA of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 apply for dismissals under section 28 of the bill. These rights include and allow for the provision of reasonable notice and reasons for dismissal.

Then there is the question of the commissioner's orders not being disallowable instruments. It is proposed that, under section 38 of the bill, the commissioner may, in writing, issue orders with respect to the general administration and control of the operations of the AFP. It re-enacts the power to make general orders and general instructions contained in section 14 of the AFP Act. The power to issue orders with respect to the general administration and control of the operations of the AFP is fundamental to the commissioner's command of a disciplined force. It is essentially a legislative recognition of a common law power recognised by the courts.

The parliament has chosen deliberately to operate at arms length from the Australian Federal Police. It cannot on the one hand say that it is operating at arms length and on the other say that it wants to have the disallowable instrument revived. There is a need to be independent. The importance of an independent police force, where command decisions are made by the commissioner, is undermined if the commissioner's orders are subject to parliamentary disallowance. That independence should be sacrosanct. An independent police force means a better operating police force. An independent police force will ensure the integrity overall of the police force and should be supported. These criticisms by the opposition are not sustainable.

There was also the question of the partial removal of the privilege against self-incrimination in relation to the commissioner's orders and other integrity measures. Clearly, there is some concern about the obligation to comply with these orders and with any lawful direction, instruction or order presently in the AFP, and that requirement has been moved into the act. Where an AFP employee or special member is required to give information, answer a question or produce a document in relation to the commissioner's order or a lawful direction, instruction or order, they are not excused on the grounds of self-incrimination.

On the whole, it is a question of the individual and the rights of the individual as opposed to the importance of having an organisation of integrity which is corruption free and has the ability, where there are suspicions of wrongdoing within the organisation, to compel individual police officers to give evidence. Even if it may affect their employment within that organisation, under the requirements of this act, it does not affect any matter that can be taken to court.

It is only an internal provision. It is aimed at ensuring a situation where leads can be followed up and officers can be interrogated. Even if it does mean some self-incrimination, I am sure that, above all, we would want to have an Australian Federal Police which is as corruption free as possible. Living in the real world, we all know that that is always difficult. Despite the fact there are objections from the police union and there may be some concerns, I believe that, on balance, it is an appropriate line of action to take.

The integrity measures under the AFP Act are different from those applicable to other public servants, employees generally or members of the public. In the case of the Police Service Board v. Morris, it was identified that the police service is a public service where members voluntarily undertake the curtailment of freedoms they would otherwise enjoy. It is also incumbent on the commissioner to take a proactive approach to the system of integrity.

The protections in relation to the powers that the commissioner would have limit the circumstances in which information obtained by compulsion may be used in evidence. The AFP disciplinary regulations create a disciplinary offence for the improper use of information. The Privacy Act 1988 regulates the collection, use, disclosure and storage of personal information. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 provides that a complaint may be made to the ombudsman concerning action taken by a deputy commissioner. The protections and safeguards are in place.

We have before us a bill which, I believe, is an enlightened piece of legislation. It enables Australian Federal Police officers to be treated in a way that is not dissimilar from the private sector in terms of their ability to negotiate directly with the commissioner. But, of course, it is subject to the Public Service requirements and to the special conditions that relate to police services around the world. It enables flexibility so we do not have the situation where we have fixed contracts and then people being terminated, losing those significant resources. The legislation before us protects individuals appearing before inquiries and will ensure that our Australian Federal Police service is one of integrity and as corruption free as possible. I commend this bill to the House.
Motion (by Ms Ellis) negatived:
That the debate be adjourned.

talk.start.para: —As your motion has been negatived, you now have the right to speak to the bill as you are on the speakers list. Do you wish to speak?
—No, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I am very pleased to be winding up the debate on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . One thing I regret is that, despite the importance of the bill, there has been little interest shown in it by the members of the opposition. In fact, the member for Canberra, who just sought to change the agenda of the parliament, was down to speak but did not rise to speak on the bill.

speech.para: As I said, this is an important bill. It is a bill designed to modernise and simplify the Australian Federal Police Act. It builds on the existing strengths of the AFP and will deliver flexibility within a framework that will build on the expertise and professionalism of the AFP as Australia's premier police force. In fact, it is part of a package of measures designed to achieve the Prime Minister's objective of having a world-class police force as our Australian Federal Police. The bill recognises the distinctive employment relationship within the AFP, where the commissioner has both command and employment powers, unlike those of other employers. It is incumbent upon police managers of a disciplined force to implement a proactive system of integrity testing to exclude any potential for corruption.

The provisions in the bill for drug testing and disclosure of financial information, while they would ordinarily be seen as a restriction on personal freedoms, represent the community expectations of a police force free from corruption and open to scrutiny. I can recall a couple of years ago, when I had the office of Minister for Justice as well as the office of Attorney-General, launching the voluntary drug testing scheme that was instituted by the commissioner with the support of the Australian Federal Police Association. This was something that the members of the Australian Federal Police were happy to support because it gave the appearance of integrity as well as the test for actuality.

The bill does not take away any rights in relation to unfair dismissal that are available under the Workplace Relations Act 1996. AFP employees will have a right to reasonable notice of termination of employment under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and also to reasons for termination. The Industrial Relations Commission has made it clear in a number of decisions that in order for a dismissal to be fair reasons must be given. Where an adverse revelation or discovery is made through mandatory drug testing or financial disclosure, the commissioner will continue to have a range of discretionary powers at his disposal—from counselling to opportunities for rehabilitation and investigation through to dismissal. This will allow the commissioner to respond in a manner commensurate with the individual's circumstances yet maintain the commissioner's disciplinary responsibilities.

The role of the parliament remains unchanged, with the current convention continuing, whereby ministerial directions under section 13—section 37 in the bill—are tabled. Additionally, such directions will continue to be published in the AFP's annual report. The amendments proposed in the bill reinforce the special nature of policing and provide adequate protections both for AFP employees and the community, to ensure that the AFP continues to maintain its leading role in law enforcement.

The member for Denison, in responding on behalf of the opposition, asserted that there was a lack of clarity between dealing with the employment powers and the command powers vested in the commissioner under the proposed legislation. In fact, the purpose of the bill is to achieve clarity in relation to those two categories of power. The current act intermingles command and employment issues to a point of confusion as to where the commissioner's powers of command and his responsibilities as an employer stand. The bill rectifies these inflexibilities and uncertainties by providing a clear distinction between command and employment issues, with the result of greater certainty.

The member for Denison raised the question of his request for a referral of the bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The member for Denison is well aware, from his former role as Minister for Justice in the Keating government, that I am very keen to see House standing committees consider legislation rather than leaving it to Senate committees. It would have been consistent with my preference that the bill be inquired into and reported on by the House committee rather than leaving it, as is often the case, to a Senate committee to do a rush job.

However, in the circumstances of the House committee, the request, coming as late as it did, was not feasible. The House committee is considering a number of references already, including a reference on copyright enforcement, a reference on the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Bill 1999 and another reference on a matter relating to genetic modification that was given by another minister. On that basis, our inquiries indicated that the House committee would not be able to deal with the matter within a reasonable time frame in order to ensure that this bill was dealt with by the Senate before the end of the year, as the government desires.

The result of this aspect is that the bill will be referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report, and I am told that the committee will report by 6 December 1999. The issues nominated by the member for Denison, as the shadow minister, will be considered by the Senate committee. I suggest, therefore, to the member for Denison that any matter to be referred to the House committee, being consistent with my personal preference for matters in my portfolio, be made a little earlier than this one was.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, misled parliament today when he said that the Auditor-General's inquiry into the MRI scam would be conducted under section 20 of the Auditor-General Act 1997. Tonight, the Auditor-General, Mr Barrett, has confirmed that the inquiry will in fact be conducted under section 18 of the act.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the member for Jagajaga cast an aspersion on the Minister for Health and Aged Care by suggesting that he had misled the House. If she wishes to make such an accusation, she ought to—

—The parliamentary secretary will resume his seat. The member for Jagajaga is aware of the standing orders. Consistent with the ruling I gave yesterday, she has not accused the minister of deliberately misleading the House. It is the term `deliberately misleading' that is unparliamentary.

—It is the case that the Auditor-General, Mr Barrett, has confirmed that he will conduct his inquiry under section 18 of the act, a section which gives him significantly greater information gathering and access powers than he would have had if this inquiry was conducted under section 20 of his act. Dr Wooldridge should have come immediately into the parliament to correct the record and acknowledge his mistake, otherwise he stands tonight accused of trying to restrict the inquiry's powers even before it has begun.

speech.para: Dr Wooldridge has been dragged kicking and screaming into this inquiry. We have been asking questions in this parliament for eight months. This whole mess is the direct result of this minister not taking the advice of his department in the first place. We would not have this scam if this minister had carried out his duties in a proper way. That is why this Auditor-General's inquiry is necessary. That is why it must be conducted under section 18 of the act, to enable the Auditor-General to, in fact, call the minister, to call the minister's staff, to call radiologists, to call the manufacturers of MRI machines. All of these people have to be able to be called and, of course, under section 20 of the act that would have been much restricted.

In case anybody thinks that this was an inadvertent slip by the minister, let us go on and see what he said at the start of the MPI debate. Dr Wooldridge asserted in the debate that under the terms of the Auditor's inquiry—this of course confirms that he did intend that it be under section 20—he, Dr Wooldridge, could not be compelled to cooperate, although he is very willing to do so. This would be the case if the inquiry was conducted under section 20, as the minister would obviously prefer. The conduct of the inquiry under section 18 of the act was confirmed tonight by Mr Barrett—confirmed because Senator Faulkner wrote immediately after question time today to Mr Barrett asking for urgent confirmation that in fact this inquiry would be held under section 18 of the act, not under section 20, because we would have been concerned about the restrictive nature of such an inquiry.

Dr Wooldridge has clearly tried to restrict this inquiry, just like he has tried to refuse to answer questions. Now we have people being referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions because of this minister's incompetence. Today he tried yet again to restrict the Auditor-General's powers. This minister stands condemned for his policy inaction, for not answering any questions and now—most of all—for trying to restrict the Auditor-General's inquiry to one that would have limited the access of the Auditor-General to many important issues. This minister needs to recognise that these are very serious issues indeed. It is a scam; it is a scan scam, and it is time he came in here and corrected the record.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to Herbert Henry Hollingsworth, the last Light Horseman from New South Wales, who passed away on 1 October at the age of 101. He was a resident of the Sutherland Shire. I attended Mr Hollingsworth's funeral on Friday, 8 October with the member for Hughes.

speech.para: Mr Hollingsworth was born on 14 April 1898 at Aberdeen in the Upper Hunter Valley. He was orphaned at an early age. His twin sisters, who affectionately nicknamed him `Mickey Drip', were sent to live with relatives on a dairy farm. In 1917 he was too young to enlist, so he took on his mother's maiden name, `Bowden', and put his age up by two years and became a trooper in the 2nd Light Horse Regiment of the Australian Imperial Force. He served in the heat and dust of Palestine and in the swampy lower Jordan Valley before being sent to Beersheba. He formed a close bond with his horse, whom he named `Mick'.

He was among the reinforcements sent to replace casualties from the 12th Light Horse Regiment, which was massively depleted during the famous charge on Beersheba on 31 October 1917. By the time he joined the 12th Light Horse, the regiment already enjoyed a reputation for heroism amongst Allied forces in the Middle East. The attack was an unprecedented charge across three kilometres of open ground against entrenched infantry supported by artillery, machine guns and strafing aircraft. The Turks, expecting the Australians to dismount at 1600 metres, set their rifle sights accordingly, but were surprised when mounted soldiers kept advancing at high speed, eventually overrunning the defences and capturing the vital water supply of Beersheba.

The charge on Beersheba has been immortalised in the Simon Wincer film, `The Light Horseman', which recorded how 800 Light Horsemen achieved in one hour what 60,000 British failed repeatedly to do, making legends of many of those involved. Mick Hollingsworth stayed with that regiment and took part in further offensives in Jerusalem and in Syria. After the Armistice, he was transferred to the 7th Light Horse Regiment, which was charged with identifying the bodies of fallen Australians. His regiment also collected much of the material which forms the permanent collection at the Australian War Memorial. This collection is priceless to modern historians studying the period and instilling in young Australians the sacrifices that the ANZACs made for us.
As the Prime Minister's message to the congregation—which was read by the member for Hughes, who is with us tonight in the chamber—stated:
The Australian Light Horseman has a special place as part of our ANZAC tradition and the history of a young country forging its own independence.

Sadly, Mr Hollingsworth was forced to destroy his beloved horse when he was given his orders to return. Although he understood the logistical problems and the threat of bringing disease back to Australia through bringing his horse Mick with him, it was something he truly never got over.

Mick Hollingsworth returned to Australia in 1919. He worked for the Aberdeen Meatworks, then from 1926 to 1930 with the Department of Main Roads. From 1939 he worked for the Water Board, before retiring in 1961.

He will be sadly missed by the City of Newcastle RSL Club, of which he was a founding member. Mr Hollingsworth is survived by his daughter Joan Rich, his grandchildren Alan and Lorraine and his great-grandchildren Simon, Sarah, Jason and Amy. He is also survived by three other Light Horsemen.

talk.start.para: —I have a letter here from Mrs Veronica Nixon in my electorate of Port Adelaide headed `Public hospital system in crisis'. I would like to read into the parliamentary record a few paragraphs that she has written. She says:

speech.para: Dear Mr Sawford

You are well aware that our Public Hospital System is literally ill and the future diagnosis would suggest that under the Federal and State Coalition policy things for `the battlers' will only deteriorate further . . .

I write to you as a `survivor' who recently underwent 2 separate heart bypass operations in the past 12 months. My experience is similar to the many other working class of this State in that I suffered what I consider unnecessary stress, inconvenience and exaggerated delay before eventually receiving what is surely the basic right of all tax payers—good Public Hospital treatment on a needs basis.

Can you possibly imagine the torment I went through, following a complication with my initial heart bypass operation, to have to wait for 7—that's correct, 7 weeks to have a second procedure? During that difficult time I was admitted to Queen Elizabeth Hospital with angina pain a total of 5 occasions—the Doctors apologising for not admitting me for more intense treatment but having to release me, at some degree of risk, for want of a lack of bed space.
My procedure has now been successfully performed at Flinders Medical Centre . . .
In the course of my treatment I was informed on numerous occasions that if I had private medical insurance my bypass procedure/s would have been performed within a matter of days!
Isn't that a great shame? She continues:
As it was, apparently my operations were performed ahead of the normal wait, which at this time is something approaching 7 months . . .

For this to happen, there must be a urgent reversal in the current health policy of both Canberra and Adelaide so as to meet the needs of ALL AUSTRALIANS—not one for the wealthy/self insured and a second class public health system for the `rest'. This is nothing short of playing ideology ahead of the lives of Australian battlers, the people you are elected to represent and provide the basics of health, well being and education.

By the way, you'll no doubt be interested in the knowledge that the Coalition tactics have forced me through fear to take out private Medibank insurance currently costing $34-36 a fortnight from my Social Security pension. So it's good bye to the occasional `luxuries' previously enjoyed such as vacations visiting my family and the odd night out as I seek to gain peace of mind through financing my future health risks—a disgraceful state of affairs given that I am already through Medicare and taking into account the social responsibility of Government.

Mr Sawford, as our local Federal member, I appeal to you to take up the plight of myself and fellow battlers to ensure that we again enjoy our right to public hospitalisation when we need it and not when through the Coalition's manipulation they deem it appropriate.
It is very sad that we have a two-tiered hospital system in this country and it is to the shame of all of us in this House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I believe that we in this House, as leaders and major decision makers in this country, need to be strong advocates for change. We need to support, encourage and embrace change in our communities, in our electorates and in this country as a whole in a positive effort to keep abreast of worldwide trends and technology advances. Under whatever name—re-engineering, resizing, cultural change, restructuring or turnaround—change is undertaken almost inevitably to help the changer cope in a new or more competitive and challenging marketplace.

speech.para: I have been involved in making necessary changes in order to compete, both in business and in public life. I know that change is not something that is easy to achieve. I have been fortunate enough to have obtained a copy of a paper by John P. Kotter entitled `Leading change: why transformation efforts fail', which has been of considerable assistance to me in playing the role of a leading figure in the change process as it is required today in business and particularly in rural communities.

In this paper, the author identifies eight major steps to successful change, and I take this opportunity today to share them with honourable members. Step 1 is establishing a sense of urgency. This involves removing those involved in the change from their comfort zones in the current system and facing the realities of the future. Step 2 is the formation of a powerful guiding coalition. It involves assembling and encouraging a group with the power to lead the change required. In a business, this group may be a mix of management and workers. In a community, you need to choose innovative, progressive people from different groups within those communities. Step 3 is to create a vision by deciding and defining where you want to go with the change—a direction and a strategy to get you there.

Step 4 is to communicate the vision to those whom it will affect. Step 5 is to give others the power to act on that vision, getting rid of obstacles to the change and encouraging risk taking and non-traditional ideas and actions—thinking outside of the square. Step 6 to successful change is to plan for short-term wins and to reward those who achieve those wins. Step 7 is to consolidate the improvements and to produce further change by changing systems that do not fit that vision and encouraging those who prove capable of implementing the vision. Step 8, the final step, is to institutionalise the new approach, making and reinforcing connections between new behaviours and the success achieved. Follow these steps, ensuring success at each level, and more success through change is guaranteed. It has proven to be a method that works as well for small business as it does for a whole community or a multinational company.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to congratulate Steve Bracks and the Victorian Labor Party for their election result and, as I understand it, the swearing in today at 11 a.m. of the first Bracks Labor government. I have to admit, though—and I may have said this in the chamber before—I was surprised, one could almost say shocked, at the extent of the swing against Jeff Kennett and the Victorian coalition. I certainly did not expect to see Labor in power in Victoria, and I say that with no disrespect to the various players involved.

speech.para: I certainly thought the swing was much too much to be expected on one occasion. In the lead-up to the election over the last year or two, the public perception of the Kennett government was such that I though they were unassailable. However, with the benefit of hindsight, we can all start to understand what happened and speak with the wisdom of age that comes to all of us as we rejustify what we said in the context of what actually occurred. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, many of us are getting better and better at that over time, particularly when we have to explain results such as those in Victoria. But, in the context of what did happen in Victoria, I think there are some lessons for politicians of all persuasions that need to be looked at.

Jeff Kennett certainly tried to project an image of being absolutely unassailable—totally in control, totally in charge—but, in the process of projecting that image, in his own way he was also totally out of control and out of anyone else's influence—other than the big end of town—and certainly in a situation where he appeared to be very much running his race rather than anybody else's. So that issue of actually being seen to be representative of the people and in touch with their feelings, aspirations and needs was something that was missing, as was the capacity to be able to govern for all Victorians rather than for just some Victorians.

The issue of major concern to the coalition nationally is the rural and regional base of the coalition in Victoria, which effectively deserted them. This follows the situation in the last state election in New South Wales where, again, in rural and regional New South Wales the coalition was deserted. When we look at Queensland and the circumstances surrounding the phenomenon of One Nation, we see there was a serious problem for the coalition in what would normally have been their base.

Some years ago John Howard talked about the battlers—the battlers who were, in John Howard's view, Labor voters who were feeling betrayed and deserted by the actions of the federal Labor government. I suppose we are now seeing an extended variation on that theme in terms of the bush battlers—the bush battlers who have historically been very strong coalition supporters and who have now started to realise that in fact the coalition is not delivering at all in terms of the needs of their community. That raises an issue for not only the federal coalition but also the remaining state coalition governments, of which there are now very few. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise a matter which is of great concern to my constituents—my electorate being on the Gold Coast—namely, petrol pricing. Along with all other members, I have received, unbidden, some written material from petrol companies in recent times—a letter dated 11 August from Shell and a media release dated 2 September from Caltex. In both of these communications the petrol companies were trying to justify the sharp rise in petrol pricing and saying that there was no opportunism in it.

speech.para: I have previously corresponded with petrol companies on the subject of the pricing of fuel on the Gold Coast where, typically, prices rise on Wednesday or Thursday and stay high right through the weekend in order, one assumes, to exploit the tourists. Various responses have been received by me when I have said this to the fuel companies. So, to put it beyond any doubt, with some assistance I have managed to put together the morning and afternoon prices of nine petrol stations on the Gold Coast over a five-week period. I shall shortly be seeking leave to incorporate the table in Hansard as a record of how fuel prices vary on the Gold Coast.

One of the particular beefs I have had—and I stated this in a letter to the Shell company in August this year—is that, on any day of the week, fuel prices vary significantly, and apparently randomly, between Gold Coast, Brisbane, Ipswich and Sunshine Coast outlets. For example, I made a trip to Nambour in April on a Tuesday when petrol prices on the Sunshine Coast highway were all 5c per litre lower than the prices being charged on the Gold Coast on that particular day. There was a time—over a period of 10 years—when I visited Brisbane every Sunday. You could always buy your fuel for several cents per litre cheaper in Brisbane on a Sunday than on the Gold Coast. I want to refer to some of the justification that was used in Caltex's media release. They say:

Pump prices often appear to jump up together after they have been discounted heavily for several days. In fact, the prices do not jump together but closely follow each other. Both the discounting and jumps are the result of a highly competitive market when competitors' prices are readily visible on price boards.
The market works in various ways—

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —A week ago I took up an invitation from the Mount Jerrabomberra Preservation Society to inspect Mount Jerrabomberra. This mountain is on the outskirts of Queanbeyan and is visible from Parliament House. It has never been logged, cleared or grazed and, as a result, its environmental value is extremely high. Indeed, in 1992, as a result of its botanical diversity, the Australian Heritage Commission listed it on the Register of the National Estate. It noted its significant stands of rare and vulnerable native plant species and their communities. It is a beautiful place—a beautiful place, however, which is being cleared for residential subdivisions. Regrettably, it is privately owned and, even more regrettably, it was the subject of a dodgy residential rezoning going back to the time of the New South Wales Greiner Liberal government.

speech.para: I cannot believe or accept that there are no other alternative places for new residential estates. Given the abundance of land in the Queanbeyan area which has been cleared and therefore no longer has much environmental value, surely it is nonsense to suggest that Mount Jerrabomberra has to be carved up to give people somewhere to live. I realise that, in order to protect the mountain, it needs to become a publicly-owned asset. I have spoken to Mr Steve Whan, who is Labor's key activist in the Queanbeyan and Eden-Monaro areas. I agree with his view that perhaps the best way forward for Mount Jerrabomberra may lie in a joint venture between the federal government—using some of those billions of dollars the Natural Heritage Trust now has as a result of selling half of Telstra—the New South Wales state government and the Queanbeyan Council.

I have been informed that clearing has been resumed at Mount Jerrabomberra for even more residential subdivisions. This is not good enough and has to stop. Australia really ought to be an environmental showcase, a beacon to the rest of the world, but this is being threatened by reckless and short-sighted land clearing, of which Mount Jerrabomberra is a classic example.
The New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service opposed development of Mount Jerrabomberra back in 1988. It noted:

The potential impact on fauna will be severe. The bird list appears comprehensive with a surprisingly large number of native bird species so close to a settled area. It would indicate that the area is highly significant for wildlife conservation both locally and regionally, not just for resident species but also as a "resting spot" for migrant fauna.
It further observed:
The difficulty of finding another site as suitable as this, with a natural community virtually intact and with such good public access, is hard to over estimate.

I believe it is necessary that this clearing stop and that the Queanbeyan Council, the New South Wales government and the federal government work together to try to protect what is clearly an asset of considerable value for people in this area and for the nation as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased today to congratulate the winners of the Sixth Annual Northside Chronicle Business Achievers Awards, which were recently held at the Kedron Wavell Services Club in my electorate. The finalists and the winners representing our hardworking and dedicated small business community need to be commended. Some 400 people attended this particular event, and businesses and their employees were represented at the awards. The evening was highly successful and professionally organised by Quest newspapers.

speech.para: While I am speaking about Quest newspapers, I think it was highly discourteous of them to, four years in a row, not invite me as the federal member for Petrie who represents half of the businesses in attendance. However, they did have the courtesy to invite the member for Lilley, Wayne Swan, despite the fact that half of the businesses represented were from my electorate. I did get an invitation from my hairdresser, which is the only reason I attended these awards. My hairdresser has won an award two years in a row. Unfortunately, this year he did not win. So Brett Roberts and all of those from Making Headlines, keep trying. I want you to go into the hall of fame, and I am sure that you will.

The reason for my rising today is to congratulate those fine businesses from my electorate—despite the Quest's obvious overlooking of the fact that I am the elected representative of that particular area. I would like to congratulate the Yuen family from the Master Health Club. These days, with this job, it is a bit difficult to get there but, on the occasions that I have been there, I have found it to be a wonderful gym and I must praise its professionalism. Congratulations to Robert and Noel Percy from the Aspley Nursery, which is just round the corner from where I live. Ron Payne has the freshest fruit in Aspley and I want to congratulate him for winning that particular section.

I also want to congratulate Danny Liddel and his team from the Bracken Ridge Natural Health Therapies, Lone Star Steakhouse and Saloon, and also the Bracken Ridge Tavern run by Michael and Jenny White, who do a fabulous job. I was present at the hoteliers award when they took out the award for the best establishment in the gaming section. So congratulations again for achieving two awards in one year. In the real estate section, Chris Herron and her team from Raine and Horne Carseldine-Bracken Ridge deserve a very special mention.
Being in business is very tough indeed these days and the reason that these businesses do well is the dedication and commitment of their staff, and I wish to thank them.
